Oxford transcription team, 1992-1998: Peter Robinson, Elizabeth Solopova, Lorna Stevenson, with contributions from James McCabe, Hubert Stadler, Cathy Swires, Paul and Maureen Watry, Laura Wright, Diana Wyatt and Simon Horobin
Sheffield transcription team, 1992-1998, led by Norman Blake: Michael Pidd and Estelle Stubbs, with Linda Cross, Claire Thomson and Simon Horobin
De Montfort transcription team, 1998-2005: Peter Robinson, Barbara Bordalejo, Orietta Da Rold, Gavin Cole, Pip Willcox, Jennifer Marshall, Takako Kato, Jacob Thaisen, Nicole Green

Brigham Young University transcription team, 1995-2006, led by Paul Thomas: Sara Black, Jessica Cox, Barbara Christiansen, Kerry Clift Spencer*, Heidi Elldredge, Leona Fisher Sankhla, Kela Flint*, Melissa Gallup, Shannon Harris, Rebecca Johnson, Mary Jorgensen, Darin Merrill*, Wesley Pack*, Jared Perkins, Jon Penny, Randall Rogers, Ryan Rowberry*, Sara Slack, Carie Soderquist Jackson*, Kat Southerland, Matt Tenney, Briton Wright, John Young. Adam Mickiewicz University, Poznan, transcription team, 2007-2010: (names to be supplied), with support from Adam Mickiewicz University and the The Polish Ministry for Science and Higher Education, grant N104 045 32/4256.
Nila Vazquez Gonzalez, University of Murcia.

University of Sheffield, 1994-1999, led by Norman Blake: Michael Pidd and Estelle Stubbs, with Linda Cross, Claire Thomson, Orietta Da Rold and Simon Horobin. In partnership with the Canterbury Tales Project, at that time led by Norman Blake in partnership with Peter Robinson and Elizabeth Solopova (up to 1998), and using images and other resources supplied by the Project, the Sheffield team transcribed eight manuscripts in full (Ad3, Corpus, Dd, Gg, Ellesmere, Ha4, Hengwrt, Lansdowne), sections of some seven other manuscripts, and all manuscripts of the Franklin's Tale. No part of these transcripts is contained in this iteration of the Project.

div.l: And pouder marchaunt tart and gallyngale
Wel coude he knowe a drauȝt of londoıı̄un ale
He coude roste and sethe ⁊and boyle ⁊and friȝe
Make mortrews and well bake a pie
But gret harm was it / as þoute me
For on his shene amormal had he
For blankmanger mad he with the beste
¶ A shipman was ther wonnynge fer bi west A Shippman
For ouȝt I wot he was of Der Dertemouthe
He rod vp on arounci as he couthe
In a goune of faleynge to þe kne
And a dagger hangid bi a lace had he
A boute it his vndir vndir his arme adoūn
The hote somer had mad his visage broūn
And certeinli he was a good felawe
Ful many a drauȝt of wyn̄ hadde he drawe
Fro burdeux ward / while the chapman slepe
Off nyce conscience took he no kepe
For yef that he fauȝte and hadde the hiȝer hand
By water he sente hem home into eủery land
But of his craftes to rekene wel the tides
His stremes and his daungeres him besides
His harborwe and his mone and his lodemanage
Thernas non suche fro hulle to Cartage
Hardi he was and wise I vndirtake
With manye atempest hadde his berd be shake
He knew the hauens as þey were
Fro Gotlond to þe cape of fene stere
And eủery Crike in britaigne ⁊and in spayne
Hys barge i cleped is mawdaleyne
¶ With vs ther was a dottour of fisikDoctor phisik
In al this world was non hym lyk
To speke of phisik or of surgerie
For he was gronded in astronomie
He kepte his pacient a ful gret del
In houris bi his magic naturel
Well coude he of fortune ascendent
Off his ymages for his pacient
He knewe the cause of eueri maladie
Were it of hote or cold or moist or drye
And where hit engendred or of what humour
He was a werry ꝑperfite practisour
The cause i knowe and \of/ the cause þᵉ rote
Anon̄ he gaff þe sik man his bote
Wel redy he hadde his apoticaries
To sende his dragges and his lituarich
For eủery of hym mad othir for to wynne
Hir frenship was not new to begynne
Wel knew he the old Esculapius
And discorⁱdes and ek Rufus
Old ypocras haley and galyen
Serapioıı̄un Razis and auycen̄
Auerois damascien and Constantyn̄
Bernard catisden̄ and Gilbertyn
Of his diot mesurabel was he
For hit was no suꝑperfluite
But of gret norisshinge and digestible
His studie was but litil on the bible
In sang ueyn and peers clad was he al
Wᵗith taffata and wᵗith sendal.
ȝet he was but esy of dispense
kepte þᵗat he wan in pestelence
or gold in phesik is acordia
Therfore he loued gold in special
The wyf of reap̉er¶ A good wyf ther was biside Bathe
But she was sumdel deeff and that was schaþᵉ
Off cloth makynge she had suche haunt
She passed hem of ypris and of gaunt
In all that parsh wiff was ther non
That to the offeringe bifore hir shuld gōn
And ief ther dide serteyn so wroth was she
That she was out of all Charite
Hir couer cheues ful fyne were of ground
I dorste swere they were worth ⁊and pound
That on sonday were vp on hir hed.
Hir hosen weren of scarlet red
Full streite ydrawe and shoos ful moist ⁊and newe
Bold was hir face and faire and red of hewe
She was a worthy wom̄an all hir lyue
Husbondes att chirche dor͗e she had fyue
With outen othir compaigne in youthe
But þer of nedeth not to speke as nowthe
And thries hadde she be at Ierusalem
She hadde passed many a stronge strem
At Rome she hadde ben and at boloigne
In Galeis at seynt Iame and at coloigne
She couthe meche of wanderynge by þᵉ way
Gat couthed she was soth for to say
Vp on an amblere esili she satt
Wympled wel and on hir hed an hatt
As brod as ony bokeler or ᵃtarge
A foot mantil about hir hepes large
And on her heles apeyre spures sharpe
In felawschippe wel couthe she langage ⁊and carpe
Off Remedies of loue she couthe perchaunce
For she couthe of þe art the old daunce
¶ A good man was ther of religioıı̄un
And was a poure ꝑperson of a toune
But riche he was of holy thouȝt ⁊and werk
He was also alerned man a Clerk
That Cristes gospel trewly dede preche
Hys parisshens deuoutely wolde he teche
Benigne he was and woundir diligent
In aduersite also full pacient
And so was he preued many sithes
Ful loth was hym to cursse for his tithes
But rathir wold he ȝeue out of doute
Vn to his \pore/ parisshens aboute
Off his offerynge and ek of his substaunce
He couthe in litil thyng haue suffisaunce
Wide was his parssh and houses ferre a sondre
But he sparet not for rayn ne thondre
In sikenesse ne in mishiff to visite
The ferrest in his parsh miche ne lite
Vp on his feet and in his hond a staff
This noble ensaumple to his sheep he ȝaff
That firste he wrouȝte and afterward he tawȝte
Out of the gospell he tho wordis rauȝte
And ek this figure he adde\d/ mor ther to
That if gold ruste what shal Iren do
For ief a preest be foul on whom we truste
No woundir is thouȝ alewed man ruste
And shame it is if þe prest take kepe
A shetene shepherde ⁊and a clene sheepe
Wel auȝt a prest ensaumple for to yeue
Bi his clennesse how his sheep shuld leue
He ne set not his benefice to hire
Ne lett not his sheep acombred in þᵉ mire
Ne ranne not to londoıı̄un to seynt Poules
To geten hym a chauntrie for soules
Or with a bretherhed to be wiþ holde
But dwelte at hom and kepte wel his folde
So that no wolff make it not miscarie
He was a shepherde and not amercynarie
And thouȝh he holy were ⁊and vertuous
He was not to sinful men to dispitous
Ne of his speche daungerous ne deigne
But in his techynge discret and benigne
To drawe folk to heuēn by faiernesse
Bi good ensaunple that was his besinesse
But it were ony ꝑpersone obstinat
What so he were of high or lowe estat
Hym wolde he snybbe sharpely for þᵉ nons
A bettir prest y trowe that nowher nou is
He waited after no pomp̄e ne reuerence
Ne maked hym a spiced conscience
But cⁱstes lore and his aposteles twelue
He taughte / but firste he folwed it hymselue
¶ Aspiola.Wiþ h̄y þer was aplow man þᵗat was his brothyr
That had i lad of donge ful many a fothir
A trewe swynker and a good was he
Leuynge in pees and in parfit charite
God loued he best with all his herte
At all tymes þow he gamed or smerte
And than his neigh bore riȝt as hym selue
He wolde thressche an þer to dike and delue
For cⁱstes sake to eueri pore wight
With outen hire if it lay in his migh
His tithes payed he ful fayre and wel
Bothe of his ꝓpropre swynke and catel
In a tabard \he rede/ vp on a mere
¶ Ther was also a Reue and a millere
A sompnor and a pardoner͗e also
Amaunciple and my self ther were no mo
The millere was astout carl for þᵉ nones
Ful bigge he was of braıı̄une and bones
That preued well oueral ther he cam
At wrestelynge he wolde haue a wey þᵉ ram
He was short shuldred a ꝓpropre þik knarre
Ther was no dore that he ne wolde heue of harre
Or breke it with arynnynge ayens his heed
His berd as ony sowe or fox was red
And therto brod as it were a spade
Vp on his coppe riȝt of his nose he hade
A werte / and ther on stood a tuft of heres
Red as the bresteles of a sowes ers
His nosethrillis blak were and wyde
A swerd and a bokeler͗e he bare bi his side
His mouth as large was as a gret forneys
He was a gre Iangelere and a goliardeys
And that was most of synne and of harlotrie
Wel coude he stele corn̄ and ek tolle thrie
And ȝett he hadde a thombe of gold ꝑparde
A whit cote and a blew hod wered he
A bagge pipe well couthe he Blowe ⁊and soun̄
An ther with he brouȝte vs out of toune
A Gentil maunciple ther was of þe temple A maunciple
Off wheche achatours me myȝt take ensaumple
For to be wis in beynge of vetaile
For whethir he payde or tok bitayle
Alwey he awayted to his achate
That he was afore and in good estate
Now is nat this a ful fayre grace
That suche alewed mans witte shal pace
The wysdom of an heep of lered men
Of maistres had he more thanē thries ten
That were of lawe expert an curious
Off wheche ther weren a dozen in þᵗat hous
Worthi to be stewardes of rente and lond
With ony lord that is in Ingelond
To make hym leue by his ꝓpropre gode
In hounore detteles but if he were wode
Or lyue as scarcely he can desire
And able for to helpe all ashire
In ony caas that myȝt falle or happe
And ȝett þis maunciple sett her alder cappe
This Reue was a sclendir colerik man
His berd was shaue as nyȝe as euer he can
His here was bi his eres ful round I shorn
His tope was dokked like a prest biforn̄
Ful long were his legges and ful lene
Lik a staff þer was no calf sene
Wel couthe he kepe a gerner and a bynne
Ther was non auditour þat couthe on hym wyn̄e
Wel knewe he bi þe drowȝte and bi þᵉ rayn
The ȝildigge of his seed and of his greyne
His lordes sheep his neet and his dayrie
His swyn his hors his stoor and his pultrie
Was holi in his Reues gouernȳgge
And bi the couenaunt þe rekenynge
Sith that his lord was twynti ȝeres of age
Ther couthe noman hym brynge in arerage
Ther was no baile ne herde ne othir hyne
That he ne knewe his sliȝt ne his coūyne
They were agast of hym as of þe deeth
His wonnynge was full fayre vpon an heth
With grene trees shadwe was hys place
He couthe wel better thanne his lord purchace
Ful riche he was astored priuili
His lord he coude plese subtely
To yeue and lene of his owne good
And haue a thank and ek a cote and an hood
In youthe he hadde lerned a gode myster
He was a ful good write a Carpenter
This Reue was vp on̄ a wel good stoot
That was apomli gray and hiȝt scot
A longe surcote of peers vp on he he hadde
And bi his siþe he bare a rusty blade
Off northfolke was this Reue of wheche I telle
Beside a toune men clepe baldiswelle
Tucked he was as affrere aboute
And euer he rod þe hendereste of oure route
¶ A sompnoure was þer with vs in þat place
That hadde ared Cherubynnes face
For sauceflem he was wiþ eyen narwe
As hote he was and as lecherous as is asparwe
With scaled browes blake and pillid berde
Of his visage Childeren were a ferd
Ther nas quiksiluer litarge ne brimston
Boras ceruce ne oile of tarter non
Ne oynement þat wolde clense orbite
That him myȝt helpe of his whelkis white
Ne of þᵉ knobbes sittynge on his chekes
Wel loued he garlik oynoıı̄uns ⁊and eke likes
And for to drinke stronge wyn red as blood
Thanne wolde he speke and crie as he were wod
And whanne that he wel dronken had þᵉ wyne
That wolde he speke no word but latyne
A fewe termes he hadde two or three
That he hadde lerned out of sum decre
No woundir is for he it herde alday
And ek ye knowe wel þᵗat a Iay
Can clepe watte as wel as can þᵉ pope
But who so coude him in oþir thing grope
Than̄e had he spent all his philosophie
Ay questio que iuris wlde he crie
He was agentil harlot and a kynde
A betir felawe shuld men nowher fynde
He wolde suffre for a quarte of wyne
A good felawe to haue his concubyne
Atwelue month and excuse him att fulle
Ful pⁱriuili afinche cowþe he pulle
And if he fond owher a good felawe
He wolde techen hem to haue non awe
In suche caas off þᵉ erche dekens curs
But if mannes sowle were in his purs
For in his purs he shall pounyshed be
Purs is þe erche dekens helle seide he
But well y wot he lied riȝt in dede
Off curssynge ouȝte eủery man to drede
For curssynge woll sle riȝt as a soylynge sauyþ
And also were him of a significaunt
In daunger hadde he att his owne wille
The yonge gerles of his diocise loude or still
And knewe hir conseill and was all hir red
A garlond had he set vp on̄ his hed
As gret as it were vp on̄ an ale stake
A bokeler͗e hadde he mad him of a cake
¶ With hem þer was agentil ꝑpardoner
Off rouncivale his frend and his comper
That streiȝt was come from þe court of rome
Well loude he song com hedir loue to me
This sompnor bar to hym a stiff burdoıı̄un
Was neuer tromppe half of so gret a soıı̄un
This ꝑpardoner hadde heer as ȝelwe as wax
But smoþe it hyng as doth astreke of flax
Bi vnces hynge his lokkis þᵗat he hadde
And ther with he his shulders ouerspradde
But thynne it lay bi culpoıı̄uns bi on ⁊and on̄
But hode for Iolite wered he non
For it was trusset vp in his wallette
Hit semed he rode all of þᵉ newe Iette
Disheuele saue his cappe he rod all bare
Suche glarynge yen had he as an hare
A vernicle hadde he sewed vp on his cappe
His walet lay before him in his lappe
Brett ful of ꝑpardoıı̄un come from rome all hote
A voys he hadde as small as hath a gote
No berde hadde he ne neuer shuld haue
As smothe it was as it were late ishaue
I trowe he were a gildinge or a mare
But of his craft fro Berewik in to ware
Ne was þer suche an othir ꝑpardonere
For in his male he bare apilwe bere
Wheche he seide þat was our͗e ladi vaile
He seide he hadde agobbet of asayle
That seynt petʳ hadde whanne he wente
Vp on þe see til oure lord ihıı̄un crist him hente
He hadde a cros of laton ful of stones
And in a glas he hadde pigges bones
But wiþ these relekis whanne he fond
A poure ꝑperson dwellynge vp on lond
Vp on day he gat more monye
Thanne ꝑperson gate in monthis tweye
And þus wiþ feyned flaterie and Iapes
He made þe ꝑperson and þe peple his apes
But truly for to tellen att laste
He was in chirche anoble ecclesiaste
Wel coude he rede apistil or a stori
But alderbest he song an offertori
For wel he wiste whane þat song was songe
He moste preche and wel enfile his tonge
To wynne siluer as he wel coude
Ther fore he song þe merilier and loude
¶ Now haue y soteli told yow in a clause
The estate þe araye þe noumbre and þe cause
Whi þat assembled was þis compaignye
Atte southwerk att þis gentil hostelerie
That hiȝtte þe tabbard biside þe belle
But now is tyme for yow to telle
How þat we bare vs þat firste nyȝt
Whanne we were in þat osterie a liȝt
And after wil I telle of oure viage
And all þe remenaunt of oure pilgrimage
But first I prey Iow of youre curtesie
That ȝe ne rette it not in velonye
Thow I pleynly speke of þe matere
To telle yow her wordis and her chere
Ne þowȝ I speke her wordis properly
For þis knowe \ȝe / as wel as I
Who so shal telle atale aftir aman
He moste reherse as nigh as euer he can
Eueri word yef it be in your͗e charge
Al speke he neuer so rudely noþur so large
Or ell he moste telle his tale vntrewe
Or feyne þinges or feynde wordis newe
He may not spare þowȝ he were his broþur
He moste as wel seye oo word as an othur
Crist spak hym self full brode in holy writt
And wel ȝe wote no velonie is hit
Eke plato seith who so can him rede
The wordes mote be cosen to þᵉ dede
Also y prey iow foȝeue it me
Al haue y not set folk in her degree
Here in þis tale as þei shuld stonde
Mi witte is short ȝe may wel vndirstonde
¶ Gret chere mad oure ost vs eủerychone
And to þe soper he sette vs anone
He serued vs wel and faire wᵗith þᵉ beste
Stronge was þe wyne ⁊and wel to drinke vs leste
A semeli man was oure ost with alle
For to ben a Marchall in an halle
A large man he was with yen stepe
A fairer burgeys was not in shepe
Bold of his speche wis and wil y tauȝt
And of manhod him wanted nauȝt
Ek þer to he was ameri man
And after soper pleyen \he/ began
And spak of merþe among oþer þinges
Whanne he hadde mad our͗e rekenynges
And seide þus now lordynges trewly
Ye ben to me ryȝt welcome hertely
For bi my trouþe if þat I shal not lie
I siȝe not this \ȝer/ so merie a compaignie
Attones / in þis her borwe as is now
Fayn̄ wolde y do yow mirthe wiste y how
And of a merþe I am ryȝt wel beþought
To do yow ese and it schall coste you nouȝt
Ye gon to Caunturbury god yow spede
The blisful martir quyte yow your͗e mede
And well y wot as ye gon by þᵉ wey
Ye shapen yow to talen and to pley
For treuly comfort ne merþe is nōn
To ryde by þe wey as dōmm as a stōn
And þerfore wil I make yow disport
As I sede arst / And do yow some comfort
And yf yow likith all bi on assent
For to stonden att my Iugement
And for to werken as y shal yow seye
To morwe whan ye ryden bi þᵉ weye
Now bi my faders soule that is ded
But ye meri be y will yeue you myn hed
Holde vp your͗e honde with outen more speche
Oure conseill was not longe \for/ to seche
It semed not vs to make it uise
And graunted þer to wᵗith owten more avise
And bad hym seye his ver dit as him leste
Lordyngꝭes quod he harkenyþ for þᵉ beste
But take it not in I prey yow in disdayn
This is þe poynt to speke it short and playn
That eueri of yow to shorten wᵗith his weye
In his viage shal telle tales tweye
To canturbery ward I mene it so
And homward shal tellen oþer two
Off auentures þat whilome haue hym befalle
And whiche of him þat berith him best off alle
That is to seyn þat tellith in þis caas
Tales of best sentence and most solas
Shal haue a sopper at oure alþer coste
In this place here sittynge bi þis poste
Whanne þat we come ageyn̄ fro caıı̄unturbery
And for to make yow the more mery
I wil my silf goodly with yow ryde
Riȝt at myn owne cost and be youre gide
And who so wil my Iugement wiþ seye
Shal paye al þat we spende bi þe weye
And ȝf ie wouche sauf þat it be so
Telle me anon with outen wordis mo
And y will erly shape þerfore
These þynges were graunted and oure oþes swore
Wiþ glad herte and prayen him also
That he wouchesauf for to do so
And þat he wolde Be oure gouernoure
And of oure tales Iuge and reportoure
And sette a soper at/ a certeyn pris
And we wolde reuled be atte his deuys
In hiȝ an lowe and þus by bi on assent/
We ben acordet to his Iugement
And þer vp on þe wyne was fett anon̄
We dronken and to reste wente eủerychon
Wiþ outen ony lenger tarynge
Amorwe whanne þᵉ day ganne sprynge
Vp ros oure ost and was oure alder cok
And gaderde vs to geder on a flok
And forþ we reden alitil mor þe paas
Vn to þᵉ waterynge of Seynt Thomas
And þer oure ost be gan his hors to areste
And seide lordes harkeneþ if ie leste
Ȝe wot youre forward and I ȝow it recorde
Yeff euesonge and morwe songe acorde
Lat se now who shal telle þe firste tale
As euer I mot drynke wyne or ale
Who so be rebel to my Iugement/
Shalle paye for all þat bi þe weye is spent
Now drawe we cutte or þat we ferþ̉er twynne
He þat hath þe shortest shal begynne
Sir knyȝt quod he my maister and my lord
Now drawith cutte for þat is myn acord
Comyþ ner quod he my lady prioresse
And lat be ȝe sir clerk your͗e shamefastnesse
Ne studieth not ley on hond euery man
To drawe anon euery man bigan
And shortli for to tellen as it was
Were it bi auenture or scort or caas
The soþe it is þe kut fel to þe knyȝt
Off wheche ful bliþe and glad was eủery wiȝt
And tellen he moste as it was reson
By forward and bi composicion
As ȝe haue herd what nediþ wordis mo
And whanne þe godeman saw þat it was so
As he þat wis was / and obedient/
To kepe his forward bi his fre assent
He seide sone I shall biginne þe game
What welcome bi þe cutt in goddis name
Now late vs ride ⁊and herkene what y seie
And with þat word we riden forth our͗e weye
And he began wiþ riȝt ameri chere
His tale anon and seide as ȝe may here
Here endith the ꝓproheme of alle þᵉ tal And begynneth the knyghtes tale
Whilom as olde stories tellen vs
Ther was a Duc þat hight Theseus
Of Atthenes he was lord ⁊and gouernour/
And in his tyme suche a noble conquerour
That gretter non was vnder þe sonne
Ful many a contre hadde he wonne
What with his wisdom and wᵗith his chiualerie
He conquerde þᵉ regne of femenye
That whilome was cleped Sithia
And wedded þe quene ypolita
And brouȝte hir home wᵗith hym in to his contre
With moche glorie and gret solempnite
And ek hir ȝonge suster Emelie
And þus with victorie and melodie
Lat y þis noble Duc/ to Atthenes ride
And all his ost in armes him beside
And certis if it not long to here
I wold haue told yow fully þe manere
How wonne was þe regne of Femynye
Bi Thesius and bi his chiualrie
And of þe gret batel for þe nones
Bitwyx Athenes and Amaȝones
And how biseget was Ipolita
The faire hardi quene of Sithia
And of þe feste þat was at hir weddinge
And of þe tempest at hir home comynge
But al þat þyng I moste as now forbere
I haue god wot a large feld to Ere
And weyke ben þe oxen in my plow
The remenaunt of my tale y slonge y now
I will not letten eke non of þis route
Late eủery felawe tell his tale aboute
And lat se now I wo shal þe sopper wynne
And ther y lefte I wille ageyn bigynne
¶ This duc of whom I make mencion
Whanne he was come almost to þᵉ toıı̄un
In al his most wele and in his most pride
He was war as he caste his eyen aside
Where there kneled in þe hyȝe weye
A Companye of ladies by twey ⁊and twey
Euery after oþer clad in cloþis blake
But suche a cry / and suche a woo þey make
Þat in þis werld is creature lyuynge
Þat \herde/ / suche an oþer waymentynge
And of þis cry wolde þie neuere stinte
Til thei the rene of his bridel hente
What folk been ȝe that at myn hom comynge
Pertorben þus my feste with criynge
Quod theseus / haue ȝe so gret Envye
Off my honure þat þus compleyne ⁊and crie
Or ho haþ yow mysdoıı̄un or offended/
Tellith hit me if it may be amended
And whi ȝe be þus do thus in blak /
The eldiste ladi of hem all spak
Whanne she hadde swouned with a dedli cheere
That it was routhe for to see and heere
She seide lorde to whom Fortune hath ȝeuen
Victorie / and as a conquerour to lyuen
Nouȝt greueth vs youre glorie and ȝour honoᵘur
But we biseke þe merci and socour
Haue merci on oure woo and oure distresse
Some drope of peti þorwȝe your͗e gentilnesse
Vp on vs wreched women lete now falle
For certis lord þer is non of vs alle
That she ne hath bene a Duchesse or a quene
Now be we caitiues as it is wel sene
Thanked be fortune and hir fals whele
That non estate assureth to be weel
Now certes lord to a bide youre prᵉsence
Here in þis temple of þe goddesse clemence
We haue ben waytynge all þis forteneyȝt
Now helpe vs lord/ siþ it is in þy myȝt
I wrecche þat wepe and waile þus
Was somtime wiff of kyng Capaneus
Þat starff att thebes cursed be þat day
And alle we that bene in þis array
And maken all this lementacioıı̄un
We loste oure husbondes at þat toıı̄un
While þat þe sege þer aboute lay
And ȝeite now olde Creon weylaway
That lord is now of thebes þe Cite
Fulfilled of ire and of iniquite
He for dispite and for his Tyrannye
To dōn þe dede bodies velonye
Of alle owre lordes þat bēn slawe
Hath alle þᵉ bodies on an hepe I drawe
And will not suffre bi nōn assent
Nothir to be beried noþur brent
But make houndes ete hem in dispite
And with þat word wiþ outen mor respite
Thei fellen gruff and cried pitousli
Haue on vs wrecched women som merci
And late oure sorwe synken in þyn herte
Thus genal Duc doūn of his corsour͗e sterte
With herte petous whan he herde hem speke
Hym thouȝte þat his herte wolde breke
Whan̄e he sawe hem so pitous and so mate
That somtyme were of so gret a state
And in his armes he hem alle vp hente
And hem conforte in ful good entente
And swore his oþ̉er as he was trewe knyȝt
He wolde do so ferth forthli his myȝt
Vp ōn þe Teraunt Creōn hem to wreke
That alle þe peple of grece shuld speke
How Creon was of thesius serued
As he that had his deth ful wel deserued
And riȝt anon wiþ outen ony more a boode
His baner he displayde and forþ rode
To thebes ward and all his oft beside
No neer Attenes wolde he go no ride
Ne take his ese fully half a day
But onward in his wey þat neyȝt he lay
And sente anono I polita þe quene
And Emelie hir ȝonge sistir shene
In to þᵉ toıı̄un of Athenes to dwelle
And forth he rit þer is nomore to telle
The red statu of mars wiþ spere ⁊and targe
So shineth in þe white baner large
Þat alle þᵉ feldes glitteren vp an doıı̄un
And bi his Baner boren is his pinōn
Off gold ful riche / in/ wheche þer was ibete
The mynntawere þe wheche he wanne in grete
Thus rit þis Duc þus rit þis conquerour͗e
And in his oste of Chiualerie þe floᵘur
Til the come to thebes and a lyȝt
Faire in a feld þer he þouȝt to fiȝt/
But shortli for to speke of þis þyng
Wiche Creon þat was of thebes kyng
He fauȝt and slouȝe hym manly as a knyȝt
In pleyn batel and putte þe folk to fliȝt
And bi assente he wan þe Cite aftir
And rente adoıı̄un boþe wall ⁊and sparre ⁊and raftir
And to þe ladyˢ he restored ageyn
The bones of hir frendes þat weren sleyn
To don̄ obsequies as was þo þe gise
But it were al to longe for to diuise
The gret sorwe and waymentynge
That þe ladies made at hir brennyng
Of þe bodies / and þe gret honoure
That theseus þe noble conqueroure
Doth to þe ladies whan̄e þey from him wente
But shortli for to telle myn entente
Whanne þat þis worþy Duc Theseus
Hath Creon slaȳn and wonne thebes þus
Stille in þat feld he tok al nyȝt his reste
And dede with all þe contre as him leste
To ran sake in þis taas of þe bodies dede
Hem for to stripe of harneys and of wede
The pilours diden besili him cure
After þe bateile and disconfiture
And so be fel þat in þe thaas þey founde
Towȝ girt with many a gʳeuous wounde
Two ȝonge knyȝns liggynge bi an by
Boþe in armes wrouȝt ful richeli
Of whiche arcita hiȝt þat ōn
And þat othir knȝyt hiȝt Palamōn
Nat fully ded / ne fully quik they were
But bi hir cote armours and bi her gere
The heraudes knewe hem best in special
As þei that were of þe blode rial
Of thebes and of nᵒ susters I boren
Our of þe taas þe pilours haue hem torn̄
And han hem caried softe in to a tente
Of thesius and he ful sone hem sente
To Athenes to dwelle þer in presoıı̄un
Perpetuel with outen any raunsoıı̄un
And whan̄e þis wordi duc hadde þus y don̄
He toke his oste and hom he ryt anōn
With laurer crowned as a conqueroure
And there leuyth in ioye and honoure
Terme of his liff what nedeth wordes mo
And in a tour of angwiush euer in wo
Dwellen þis Palamon and arcite
For eủeremor͗e þer may no man him quite
This passed ȝer by ȝer and day bi day
Til it fel one in þe mouþe of may
That Emelye þat was fayr͗e to sene
Thanne is þe lilie vp on his stalke grene
And fressher thanne þe may wiþ floures newe
For with þe rose colour stroff hir hewe
I not weche was þe fairer of hem two
Er it were daye as was hir wone to do
She was arisen and all redi diȝt/
For may will haue no slogardie anyȝt/
The seson prickith eủery gentil herte
And makith hit up oute of his slepe to sterte
And seiþ arise and do þyn obʆseruaıı̄unce
This makith Emelye for to haue remembraıı̄unce
To don honour to may and for to ā rise
Clothyd she was fressh for to deuise
Hir ȝowe heer was broided in a tresse
Be hynde hir bak a ȝerde longe y gesse
And in þe gardyn att þe sonne vp rist/
She walked vp and doıı̄un and as hir list
She gader up floures ꝑparti white and red
To make a sotil garland for hir hed
And as an aungel heuenly she song
The grete toure þat was so þikke and strong
Whiche of þᵉ castel was þe cheef dongeoıı̄un
There as þe knȝtis weren in presoıı̄un
Of whiche i told iow and telle shall
Was euen Ioynyne to þᵉ gardyn wal
There as thes Emelie had hir planynge
Briȝt was þe sonne in þe mornynge
And Palamon this woful presonere
As was his wone bi leue of his gaylere
Was resen and romed in þe chaumbre so high
In whiche he all þe noble Cite sigh
And ek þe gardeyn ful of braunches grene
There as þe fressh Emelie þe shene
Was in hir walk and romed vp and doıı̄un
This sorwefull presonere þis Palamon̄
Goth in this Chaumbre romynge to and fro
And to him silf compleynynge of his wo
That he was born̄ full ofte seyde allas
And so bifel bi auenture or caas
That þorwȝe a wyndowe ful þikke and many a barre
Of yren gret and square as ony sparre
He caste his eye vp an Emelia
And þer wiþ all he bleynte and cride A
As thowȝ he stongen were vn to þe herte
And wiþ that cri Arcite anon vp sterte
And seide cosyn myn what eiliþ the
That art so pale and dedly vn to see
Whi cridest þou who hath þe don offence
For goddis loue take all in pacience
Oure presoment for it may non oþ̉er wise be
Fortune haþ yeue vs this aduersite
Some wikked aspect or disposicioıı̄un
Of Saturne bi sum constillacioıı̄un
Hath yeue vs þis þowȝ we hadde it sworn̄
So stod heuene whan̄e þat we were born̄
We moste endure it þis is þe short and playn̄
This Palamoıı̄un answerde and seyde ageyn
Cosyn for sothe of þis oppinion
Thou hast a vayn Imaginacioıı̄un
This preson caused me not to crie
But y was hurt ryȝt now þorwȝ out myn eye
In to myn herte that will my bane be
The fairnesse of þat ladi þat y see
Ȝonde in þe gardyn rome to and/ fro
Is cause of my crynge and my woo
I wote neuer yeff she be woman or goddesse
But trueli venus is it as y gesse
And þerwith on knes doun he felle
And seide Venus if it be þy Wille
You in þis gardyn þus to transfigure
Before me so woful a creature
Out of þis preson helpe þat we may scape
And ief so be our͗e desteine be shape
Bi eterne word / to dien in preson/
Of oure lynage haue some compassion
That is so lowe brouȝt bi tirannye
And with þat word Arcite gan aspie
¶ Where as this ladi romed to and fro
And with þat siȝt hir beaute hurte him so
That if Palamon were wonded sore
Arcite is hurt as moche as he or more
And wiþ a siȝe he sigeþe pitousli
The fressh beaute sleþ me sodeynli
Of hire þat romed in yonder place
And but I haue hir merci and hir grace
That I may se hir atte leste wey
I am but ded þer is nomore to sey
This Palamon whanē he þo wordes herde
Dispitousli he loked and answerde
Whethur seiste þis in Ernest or in pley
This Palamon gan knytte his browes twey
It were quod he no gret honour
For to be fals or for to be traitour
To me / that am þy cosyn/ and þyn broþur
I sworn/ ful depe and eueri of vs til oþur
That neuer for to dien in þe peyne
Til that deth deꝑparte shal vs tweyne
Nother in loue to hynder othur
Ne in no nothur caas my leue brothur
But þat þou shuldist treuly forþer me
In euery caas so shuld I. do the
This was þyn oth and myn also certeyn
I wote ful well þou darst it not wiþ seyn
Thus art þou of my conseil oute of doute
And new þou woldist falsly ben a boute
To loue my lady whom I loue and serue
And euer shal til my herte sterue
Now certis fals Arcite þou shat not so
I loued hir first/ and told þe of my wo
As to my conseill and my broþur sworn̄
To forþer me as y haue told be forn̄
For whi thou art bounde as a knyȝt
To helpe me yef it lay in þy myȝt
Or ell art þou fals y der well sayn
This Arcite full proudely spak ageyn̄
Thou shalt be raþur fals þan̄e y
And þou art fals y telle þe vittirly
For paramour I loued hir first or þou
What wilt þou seie þou wiste not ȝet now
Whethur she be a woman̄e or goddesse
Thyne is affeccion of holynesse
And myn ys loue as to creature
For whiche i tolde þe my aduenture
As to my cosyn and to my broþur sworn̄
I suppose þat þou louedest hir be forn̄
Wost þou not þe olde clerkis sawe
That who shal ȝeue ony louer lawe

note.supplied: No put se ꝑpersration of Lou

div.l: Loue is a gretter lawe bi my pan
Thanne may be yeue to ony erthely man
And þerfore positiue science and suche decree
Is broke all al day for loue in eủery degre
Aman moste nedes loue maugre his hed
He may nat fle it / þouȝ he shulde be ded
Al be she maide or wedue or wiff
And ek it is not likeli al þi liff
To stonden In hir grace nomore shal y
For wel þou wost þi silf verrely
That þou and y ben dampned to preson
ꝐPerpetuli vs ganyth no raunsoun
We striue as dede þe houndes for þᵉ bon
They fauȝte alday and ȝet her part was nōn
Ther come a kite while þey were so wroþ
That bare awey þe bon̄ from̄ hem boþ
And þerfore at kynges court my brothur
Euery man for him self þer is non oþur
Loue if þe liste for I loue and eueri I shal
And treuly broþur this is all
Here in þis presone we moste endure
And euery of vs take his auenture
Gret was þe strif and longe be twyx hym twey
Ief þat y hadde leiser for to seye
But to þe affect it happend on a day
To telle it yow / as shortly as I may
¶ A worthi duc þat hyȝt ꝐParotheus
That felawe was vn to duc theseus
Syth that þilke day þat þey weren childrēn lite
Was come to Athenes for to visite
And for to play as he was wont to do
For in þe world he loued no man so
And he loued him as tendirli ageyn̄
So wel þei loued as olde bokes seyn̄
That whan̄e on was ded soþely to telle
His felawe Wente and souȝte him doıı̄un in helle
But of that storie me listid nomore to write
But þer othens loued/ wel arcite
And had hym knowe atte thebes ȝere bi ȝere
And fenaly att request and prayere
Of ꝐParotheus With outen ony raunsoun:
Duc theseus let him out of presoun
Frely to go Wher þat him liste oueral
In suche a gise as y yow telle shal.
This was þe forward pleynli for endite
Betwene duc thesius and him arcite
That yef so were þat arcite were founde
Euere in his lif be day or nyȝt or stounde
In ony contre / of this thesius
And were cauȝt they were acorded þus
That with a swerd he shuld lese his hed
Ther was nōn othir remedie ne red
But takith his leue and homward him spedde
Late him beware his hed lith to wedde
How gret a sorwe suffrith now arcite
The deth he felith þorw his herte smyte
He wepeth and wailiþ and crieth petousli
To slen him silf he waitith pryuely
He seide alas þe day þat I was born
Now is my preson wers þan it was be forn̄
Now is me shape eternaly to duelle
Nouȝt in purgatorie but in helle
Alas that euery knew I ꝐParotheus
For ell had y duelled with theseus
I fetered in his preson eueremo
Thanne hadde I bene in blesse and not in wo
Only þe siȝt of hir þat y serue
Thowȝ þat I may neuer hir grace may deserue
Wolde haue sufficiþ ryȝt I now for me
O dere cosyn Palamon qduod he
Thyne is þe victorie of þis auenture
Full blisful in preson maist þou endure
In preson certes nay but paradise
Wel hath fortune turned þe þe dyse
That haste þe siȝt of hir and I þᵉ absence
For possibil it is sith þou hast hir presence
And art a Knyȝt worthi and able
That bi some caas sith fortune is chaungeable
Thou maist to thi desire some tyme attēyne
But y that am exeled and bareyne
Off all grace / and in so gret dispeire
That þer nys erthe water fier ne ayre
Ne creature that of him makid is
That may me helpe or comforte in þis
Wel ouȝte I sterue In wanhope and distresse
Fare wel my lif my lust and my gladnesse
Alas why pleynen folk in comune
On puruyaunce of /god of fortune
That ȝeueth hem ful ofte in many a gise
Wel better þanne they canne deuise
Some men desiren to haue richesse
That cause is of his morder and of sikenesse
And some man wolde oute of his preson faȳn
That in his hous is of his meyne slayn
Infinite harmes bene in þis matere
We wot nat what we praien here
We faren as he that dronken is as a mous
A dronken man wote wel he hath an hous
But he wote not wheche is þe wey thider
And to a dr͗onken man þe wey is sleder
And certes in þis world so faren we
We seken faste aftir felicite
But we gon wrong ofte treuely
Thus may we seyn al and trewli y
That wende and had a gret opinioıı̄un
That if I myȝte scapen of preson
That I had ben \in/ ioye and ꝑparfit hele
There I am now exiled from my wele
Sith that y may not see yow Emelie
I am but ded / ther nys no remedie
¶ Vp on that other side Palamon
Whanne he wiste that Arcite was gon̄
Suche sorwe he makiþ þat þe grete tour͗e
Resounyth of his ȝowlynge and clamour͗e
The pure feters on his shenes grete
Were of his bitter salt teres wete
Alas quod he arcite coseyn myn̄
Of all our͗e striff god wot þe frute is þyn
Thou walkest now in thebes att þy large
And of my woo þou ȝeuest litil charge
Thou maiste sith þu hast wisdom̄ and manhed
Assemble alle the folke of our͗e kynrede
And make a werre so sharp on þis cite
That bi some Auenture or tretee
Thou maist haue hir to ladi or to wiff
For whom y moste nedes lese my lyff
For as by wey of possibilite
Sith thou art at large of preson free
And art a lord grete is thyne auauntage
More thanne is myn þat stryue her in a cage
For I mote wepe and wayle while I leue
With all the woo that preson may me ȝeue
And with peyne that loue me ȝeueþ also
That doubleth \al/ my torment and my wo o
There with þe fere of Ielousie vp sterte
With Inne his breste and hente hem bi þe herte
So woodly that lik he was to be holde
The box tre or þe asshene ded and colde
¶ Tho seide he o creuel goddis that gouerne
This world / bi your͗e word eterne
And write in þe the table of athamaunt
Your͗e parlement/ of your͗e eterne graunt
What in mankynde is more to be holde
Thanne is þe shepe that rouketh in þe folde
For slayn is man ryȝt as an oþer beste
And duellen eke in preson under arrest/
And suffren alday siknesse and aduersite
And of tyme gilteles parde
What gouernaunce is in þis prescence
That gilteles tormenteth innocence
And ȝit encresith this al my penaunce
That man is bounden̄ to his obseruance
For goddes sake for to letten of his wille
There as a beste may al his lust fulfille
And whanne a beste is ded he feliþ no payne
But aftir his deth man moste wepe and playne
Thou in this werld he haue care and woo
With outen doute be may stonde soo
The ansuere of þis lette y do diuinys
But wel y wott in this werld grete peyne is
Allas y se all day a serpent or a theff /
That many a trewe man hāth doōn mischief
Go where him liste att large and may torne
But I mot be in preson þorwȝ Saturne
And þorwȝ Iūno ielous and wode
That hath distroyed wel nyȝ all my blode
Off thebes wiþ his waste walles white
For Ielosie and fēer of him arcite
Now will I stynte of Palamōn alite
And lat hym in his preson stille duelle
And of arcite forth y will þow telle
The Somer passeth and þe nyȝtes longe
Ay encreseth þe peynes stronge
Boþe the louer and þe presoner
I not who hāth þe wofuller mister
For shortly for to seyn of this Palamon
ꝐPerpetuelli is dampned to preson
In cheynes and in feteres to be ded
And arcite is exiled vp his hed
For eueremore/ out of þat contre
Ne neueremore shal his ladi see
Yow louers ax y now þis questioıı̄un
Who hath þe wors arcite or Palamon
That on may see his ladi day bi day
But he moste in duelle in preson for ay
The oþer wher hym liste may ride and goo
But sen his ladi shal he neuer mo
Now demeth as ȝe may ȝe þat can
Whanne arcite to thebes come was
Full ofte a day he swouned and seyde alas
For seen his ladi shall he neuer mo
And shortly to concluden all his woo
So mechell sorwe hadde neuer creatur͗e
That is or shal be while þe world may dur͗e
His slepe his mete his drynke is hym beraft/
That lene he wexiþ and drye as dōth a shaft
His yen holugh and gresili un to biholde
His colour falwe and pale as asshen colde
And solitarie he was and euer alone
And waylynge he was al nyȝt makynge his mone
And yef he herde song or ony instrument/
Thānne wolde he wepe þer nyȝt noman him stint
So feble were eke his spirites and so lowe
And chaunged so þat no man coude knowe
His speche nor his voice þouȝ men it herde
And in his gere for all þe world he ferde
Nat only lik to louers maladie
Off Hereos/ but rathur like manye
Engenderd of humour malencolik
Biforn̄ his celle fantastik
And shortly turned was vp so doūn
Bothe abitē and disposicioıı̄un
Of this woful louer Daūn arcite
What shuld I of his woo alday endite
Whanne he hadde endured aȝer͗e or two
This cruel torment and þys peyne ⁊and wo
At thebes in his contre / as I seide
Vp ōn anyȝt to slepe as he him leide
Him þouȝt / þat þe venged god mercurie
Biforn him stood / and bad him be merie
His slepi ȝerde in hande he bare vp ryȝt/
An hatte he wered vpon his heres briȝt/
Arraied was þis god as he toke kepe
As he was whanne þat argus toke his slepe
And seide him þus to Athenes shalt þou wende
There \is/ þe shapen of all þy woo and ende
And with þat word Arcite a woke and up sterte
Now treuly ho\w/ sore þat/ me smerte
Quod he / to Athenes wil y fare
Ne for drede of deth ne shall y spare
To se my ladi that y loue and ʆserue
In hir presence I recche not þouȝ I sterue
And with þat word he toke a gret mirroure
And sawe that chaunged was his coloure
Whanne he saw his visage torned in an oþur kynde
And ryȝt anon it ran in his mynde
That sigh his face so disfigured
Off maladie þat/ he hadde endured
He myȝt wel if that he bare him lowe
Leue in Athenes euermoore unknowe
And seen his ladai wel neȝ day bi day
And ryȝt anoōn he chaunged his aray
And clad him as a pore laborer
And alone saue only a Squyer
That knew his preuite and all his caas
Weche was disgised as he was
To Athenes is he gon þe nexte wey
And to þe court he wente vpon a day
And att þe gate he proferde his serūyce
To drogen and drawen what so men wol deuise
And shortly of this mater for to seyn̄
He fell in office with þe chaumburleyn
Wheche that dwelling was wᵗith Emelie
For he was wise and sone coude aspie
Off euery servuant þᵉ wheche ʆserued here
Wel coude \he/ hewe wode and water bere
For he was myȝti and ȝong for þe nones
And þer to he was strong and bigge of bones
To don what ony man cand deuyse
Aȝere or two he was in þis seruyce
Page of the chambre of Emelie þe bryȝte
And Philostrat he seide that \t/he hiyȝte
But so wel beloued a man was he
Was neuer in þat court of his degre
He was so gentil of condiciıı̄un
That þoruȝ out al þe court was his renoıı̄un
Thei seide þat it was a charite
That thesius wolde haunce his degre
And putte him to worshipful seruise
That he myȝte his vertue excersice
And thus his name wiþ inne a while spronge
Boþe of his dedis and of his gode tonge
That theseus had taken him so ner
Off his chambre he mad him Squyer
And gaff him gold to maynteyne his degre
And eke men brouȝte him out/ of his contre
Fro ȝer to ȝer prevely his rente
But honestly and warly he it spente
That noman wondred how þat he it hadde
And in ȝere in þis wise his lif he ladde
And bare him so in pees and eke in werre
Ther was noman þat Thesius hath derre
And in þis lif lett y now Arcite
And speke y will of Palamon a lite
¶ In derknesse and orible preson
This vii ȝere sittiþ Palamoıı̄un
For peyned what/ for woo and distresse
Who felith double woo heuynesse
But Palamıı̄un that / loue distreynyþ so
That wood/ out of his witte he goth for wo
And eke þer to he is a presoner
Perpetueli and not only for a yer
How coude ryme in Engelish proꝑperly
His martyr dom̄ forsoþe not I
Therfore I passe as liȝtely as I may
It befel þat in þe vii ȝere of May
The iii nyȝt as olde bokes seyn̄
That all þe storie telliþ more pleyn̄
Where it be auenture or destene
As whanne a thyng is shape it shal be
That sone aftir mydnyȝt Palamon
Bihelpe of afrynd brak presoun
And fleeth the Cite as faste as he may go
For he hath ȝeue his geilere drynke so
Off a clarre mad of certeyn wyn
With nercotikes and opie of thebes fyn̄
And al that nyȝt / þouȝ men wolde him shake
The gailer myȝt þoruȝ no man awake
And thus he fleeth as faste as heuer he may
The nyȝt was short/ and dreibe faste to day
That nedes coste he moste him self hide
And to a groue A litill ther be syde
With dredfull foote thanne stalkith Palamoıı̄un
For shortly this was his opinion
That in þat groue he wolde him hide alday
And in þe nyȝt/ thanne wolde he take his way
To thebes ward his frendis for to pray
On thesius to helpe him to werre ay
And shortly he wolde lese his lyff /
Or wynne Emelie to his Wiff
This is ᵗaffecte and his entent playn
Now wil y torne to Arcite ageyn̄
That litil wiste how neyȝ was his care
Til that fortune hath brouȝt brouȝt him in a snar͗e
The besi larke messanger of day
Salueþ in hir song þe morwe gray
And firi Phebus risiþ vp so bryȝt
That all þe orient laugheþ of þe siȝt
And wiþ his stremes drieþ in þe greues
The siluer dropes hangen on þe leues
And arcita þat in þe court/ rial
With thesius his Squeyr͗e principal
Is resin and lokeþ on þe mery day
And for to don his obseruaunce to may
Remembrynge un to þe poynt of his desir͗e
He on his couser stertlynge as þe fier͗e
Is reden in to þe feldes him for to pleyn̄
Out of þe court were it a myle or tweyn̄
And to þe greue of wheche y ȝow told
Bi auenture his wey he gan to holde
To make him a garland of þe greues
To were of þe wodbynde or of hauthorn leues
And loude he songe aȝēn þe sonne shene
May with al þei floures grene
div.note: Arcties
div.l: Welcome be þou fayr͗e fressh may
In hope that I some grene gete may
And from his couser wiþ a lusti herte
In to þe groue ful hastely he sterte
And in a path he romed vp and doıı̄un
Ther as by auentur͗e was þis Palamoıı̄un
Sutyngge in a bush þere no man myȝt him se
For sore a ferd of his deth was he
Nothing he knew þat it was arcite
God wote he wolde haue trowed ful lite
But soth is seid goon sith many ȝers
That feld hath yen and wode haue eres
Hit is fayr͗e aman to bere hym euene
For all day meten men at vnset steuene
Full litel wote arcite of his felawe
That was so nyȝ to here all his sawe
For in þe bussh he sat ful stille
Whanne þat arcite had romed al his fille
And songen all þe roundel lustely
In a studie he fel sodeynly
As dōn þese louers in her queynte geres
Now in þe croppe now in þe breres
Now vp now doıı̄un as a boket in a welle
Riȝt as þe friday soþeli for to telle
Now it shewiþ now it reynyþ faste
Ryȝt so gan geri Venus ouercaste
The hertes of hir folk ryȝt as hir day
Is gereful / riȝt so chaungēth she array
Selde is þe friday al þe weke like
Whanne þat arcite had songen and gan to sike
And sette him doıı̄un with outen ony more
Alas qd he that day þat I was bore
How longe Iuno thorwȝ þi cruelte
Wilt þou werien tebes þe cite
Allas is brouȝt to confusioıı̄un
The blod rioial of cadme ⁊and amphioıı̄un
Off cadmus wheche þat was þe firste man
That thebes bilte or first þe toıı̄un bigan
And of þe toune first was crowned kyng
Of hys linage am y and his ospryng
Off þe verry lyne as of þe stok rioal
And now I am so caytiff and so thral
That he þat is myn mortel enmye
I serue hym as a Squyer͗e poralye
And ȝet doth me Iuno wel more shame
For y dar nat be knowen myn owne name
But þer as I was wont to hight Arcite
Now hiȝt I Philostrat not worþ amyte
Allas þou fell mars allas Iuno
Thus hāth your͗e Ire our͗e lynage al for do
Saue only me and wrecched Palamoıı̄un
That thesius martirith in preson
And ouer all þis to sle me outirly
Loue hath his firi dart so brennyngly
Stikeþ þorwȝ oute my careful trewe herte
That shapen was my dēth / erst þāne my sherte
Ȝe sle me with your͗e ye Emelye
Ȝe bene þe cause wherfore I mot dye.
Off alle þe remenaunt of myn oþer care
Ne sette I not þe mountaunce of a tare
So þat y couthe do to yow ony plesaunce
And with þat word he fel doune in a tᵃraunce
Alonge tyme // And after ward vp sterte
This Palamon þat þowȝte þorwȝ his herte
He felte a cold swerd / sodenly glide
For Ire he quoke no lenger wolde he bide
And whanne he hadde herd arcites tale
As he were wood wiþ face ded and pale
He stertte out of þe busshes thikke
And seide arcite fals traitour wikke
Now art þou hent þou louest my ladi so
For whom I haue all þis care and wo
And art myn cosyn and to my conseyl sworn
And y ful ofte haue told the here bi forn
And hast bi Iaped also duc Thesius
And falsly changed hast þy name thus
I wil be ded or elles þou shalt dye
Thow shalt / not loue my lady Emelie
But I will loue hir only and no moo
For y am Palaman thi mortal foo
And though y now \no/ wepen haue in þis place
But ouȝt of preson am astert by grace
Qᵈuod This arcite with ful dispitous herte
These wheche þou wilt for þou shat not asterte
Whanne he him knewe and hadde his tale herd
As fers as a lion he pullid out his swerd
And seide thus bi god þat sittith aboue
Ner þou art sike and also wood for loue
And that þou now \no/ hast wepen in this place
Thou sholdist neuer out of þys greue pace
That þou ne shuldist dien of myn hond
For y defie thi swerd and þy bond
Wheche þou seist þat I mad with þe
What verry fole þenke þat loue is fre
And y will loue hir mawgre all þy myȝt/
But for as moche as þou art aworþy knyȝt
And wilnest to darreyne hir bi bateyle
Haue here my trowþe to morw y wil not faile
With ouȝte witynge of any othur wiȝt
That here y wille be founden as a knyȝt
And brynge harneys ryȝt y now for þe
And chese þe beste and leue þe werste for me
And mete and drynke þis nyȝt y will þe brynge
I nowȝ / for þe and cloþes for þy beddynge
And yef so be that þou my ladi wynne
And slee me in þis wode that y am ynne
Thow maist wel haue thi ladi as for me
This Palamon answerde y graunte it þe
And þus thei be deꝑpartid til a morwe
Whan̄e eny of hem hat leid his feith to borwe
O cupide out of all charite
O regne þat wolde no felawe haue with þe
For soth is seid þat loue \ne/ lordeshepe
Wil not haue his thankes no felow shippe
Wel fynden þat arcite and Palamon
Arcite is reden anon \in/ to the toıı̄un
And on þe morwe or it were day liȝt/
Ful preuyly iiᵒ harneys hath he diȝt/
Bothe sufficient harnys and mete to darreyne
The batyl in þe feld be twyx him tweyne
And on his hors alone as he was born̄
He carieth all his harnys him be forn̄
And in þe groue atte tyme and place sette
This arcite and Palamon̄ be mette
Chaungen gan þe colour͗e in hir face
Ryȝt as the honters in þe regne of trace
That stōnden att gappe with a spere
Whanne honted is a lion or a bere
And here hym come russynge in þe greues
And brekith breers and eke leues
And thenkith here comyth my mortel enmy
With outen fayle he mote be ded or y
For or y moste slen̄ hym atte gappe
Or he moste slee me ief þat me my shappe
So ferde they in Chaungynge of hir hewe
As fer as euery of hem othur knewe
Ther was no gooday \ne/ no saluynge
But streyȝt/ with outen worde or rehersynge
For euery of hem helpith to arme oþur
As frely as it were his brothyr
And after þat/ wiþ sharpe speres stronge
They foyned eueri att oþur wonder longe
Thow myȝtist/ wene that þis Palamon
In his fightynge were a wod lyon̄
And as a cruel tigre was arcite
As wilde bores gōnne þey togedir smyte
They frothen white as fome for Ire wode
Vp to þe ancle fouȝte þey in þe blode
And in þys wise I lette hym fyȝtynge duele
And forth I wille of thesius telle
The desteny minister general
That executeh in þe werld oueral
The puruyaunce that god hath sent biforn̄
So stronge it is that/ þow al \a/ world haþ sworn̄
The contrarie of athynge bi ȝe or nay
Ȝette somtyme it shall fall on a day
That fallith not ofte with Inne a Mᵈ ȝere
For certeynly oure aspectes here
Be it of werre or pees or hate or loue
Al is this ruled bi þe siȝt aboue
This meny now by myȝti Thesius
That to honte is so desirous
And nameli att gret herte in may
That Inne his bedde þere dawith hym no day
That he ne is clad and redi for to ryde
Wyþ honte and horn and houndis him biside
For in his hontynge he hath he suche a dilite
That it is all his Ioye and his appetite
To be him self the grete hertis bane
For aftir mars he serued now Dyane
Cleer was þe day as y haue told you \or/ þis
And Thesius with all Ioye and blis
With his ypolita þe fayre quene
And Emelie clothud al in grene
On hontynge be they reden rialli
And to þe groue þat stod þer faste bi
In wheche þer was an hertte as men him tolde
Duc Thesius þe ryȝte wey haþ thider holde
And to þe launde he rydith hym ful ryȝt/
For thider was þe herte wont haue his fliȝt/
And ouer a broke and so forþ on his way
The duc wil hane att/ him acours or tway
With houndes suche as him leste to comaunde
And whanne þe duc/ was comen in to þe launde
Vnder the sonne he loked up anon̄
He was war of Arcite and Palamoıı̄un
That fouȝten breme as it were boles two
The bryȝt swerdes meved to and fro
So sodeynly þat with þe leste stroke
Hit semeþ as it woll fellen an oke
But what they were nothyng he \ne/ wot/
This Duc his coursur wiþ his spor̉ers smot
And att a sterte he was betwyx him two
And pulled out his swerd and cried hoo
Nomore vp peyne on lesynge of ȝour͗e hed
Bi myȝty mars ȝe shul anon be ded
That smytith ony stroke þat y may see
But tellith me what mister men ȝe be
To be so hardi for to fyȝten here
With outen Iuge or oþur officere
As it were in a listes rially
This Palamōn answerde hastely
And seide ʆsere what nedeþ wordes mo
We haue þe deth deserued boþe two
To wofull wrecches be we two caityues
That bene encombred with oure owne lyues
And as þou art aryȝtfull lord and Iuge
Ne ȝene vs noþur merci nethir refuge
But slee me first for seynt charite
But slee my felawe ek as wel as me
Or slee hym fyrst for þouȝ þou knowe him lite
This is thi mortel foo this is Arcite
That fro þy lond is banysshed on his hed
For wheche he hath deʆserued to be ded
For this is he þat cam to þi gate
And seide that he hiȝte Philostrate
Thus hath he Iaped þe ful many a yere
And þou hast mad him þy chif Squyere
This is he that loueþ Emelie
For sith þe day is come þat y shal die
I make pleynly my confessioıı̄un
That y am thilke woful Palamoıı̄un
That hath þy preson broke wikkedli
I am þy mortal enmye and þat am y
That loueþ so hote Emelie þe bryȝte
And now shal y die present in hir syȝte
Wherfore I alle my deth and my Iewis
But slee my felaw eke in þe same wise
For boþe we haue deserued to be sleyn
This worþy duc answerde þus ageyn
And seide this is a short conclusioıı̄un
Ȝoure owne moūth be ȝoure confessioıı̄un
Hath dampned yow and y wil it record
Hit nedeth nouȝt to pyne yow wiþ acord
Ȝe shul be ded bi myȝt mars þe red
The quene anōn for verry wommanhed
Gan for to wepe and so dede Emelie
And all þe ladies of þe compaignye
Grete pite was it as þouȝt hem alle
That euer such a chaunce shuld falle
For gentilmen þey were of grete estate
And nothyng but for loue was hir debate
And sawe hir blody wounded wide and sore
And all criden boþe lesse and more
Haue merci lord vp on̄ vs women alle
And on hir bare knes þey gan don falle
And wolde haue kyst his fete þer he stood
Til att laste a slaket was his mood
He hath consedred shorty in a clause
The trespas of hem boþe and eke þe cause
For þite renneth sone in gentil herte
And thow he for Ire quoke and sterte
For all þouȝ that hir þe her gilt accused
Ȝet in his reson he hem boþe excused
As thus he þouȝte wel þat euery man
Wil helpe him in loue ȝef he can
And eke deliuer him silf out of presōn
And eke in herte he hadde compassioıı̄un
Of women for þey wepten euerichoıı̄un
And in his gentil herte he þouȝte anōn
And sotely to him self seide fy
Vp on a lord / that will haue no merci
But be a lion boþe in word and dede
To hem that bene in repetaunce and drede
As wel as to a proud dispitous man
That wil mayntyne þat he first be gan
That lord is litil of discrecioıı̄un
That in suche caas can no diuisioıı̄un
But weyeth pride and homblesse aftir ōn
And shortly whaune his Ire was þus gōn
He gan to loken wiþ yen lyȝt/
And spak these worded all an hight
To god of loue / a benedicite
How myghti and how gret a lord is he
Ageyne his myȝt there gaynes non obstacles
He may be clepe a lord for his miracles
For he can maken at his owne gise
Off euery herte as him liste to diuise
Loo here this Arcite and this Palamoıı̄un
That quytely were out of my preson
And myȝt haue leued in thebes rially
And weten þat y am her mortel Enmy
And that her deth lith in my myȝt also
And ȝet hath loue mawgre her yen to
Brouȝte hem hether boþe for to die
Loke is not þis a gret folie
He may bene a fole but if he loue
Be holde for goddis sake þat sitith aboue
See how þey blede be þey not wel arayed
Thus hath hir lord þe god of loue hym payed
Hir wages / and hir fees for her seruise
And ȝet þey wenen for \to/ be ryȝt wise
That seruen loue for aute þat may be falle
But this is ȝet þe beste game of alle
That she for whom þey haue all þys Iolite
Can hem as mekel þank þerfore as me
She wot nomore of all þis hote fare
Be god þan̄e wot a cowe of an hare
But al mot ben asayd hote and cold
A man moste bene a fole ȝonge or old
I wot it bi my silf a ȝore a gōn
For in my tyme a seruaunt was y on
And therfore sith I knowe of loues peyne
And wot how sore it can a man distreyne
As he þat hate ofte be cauȝt in his laas
I yow for yeue al holy this trespaas
Att request of þe quene þat knelith her͗e
And eke of Emelie my suster dere
And ȝe shull boþe anōn to me swere
That neuer more ȝe shull my contre dere
Ne make werre vp ōn me night ne day
But be my frendes in al þat ȝe may
I yow forgeue þis trespas eủerydel
And they him sworn̄ his alkyng fayre and well
And hym of lordshipe and of merci preyde
And hem grauntith grace and þus seide
To speke of rial linage / and riches thouȝ þat,
Thouȝ that she were a quene or a princes
Eueri of yow boþe is worþy douteles
To wedden her / whanne tyme is / but naþeles
I speke as for my suster Emelie
For whom ȝe haue þis strif and Ielosie
Ȝe wot your͗e silf she may not wedden two
Att ones / þow ȝe fiȝten euermore
That on of yow be him loth or leff
He mot nedes pipen in an yui leff
That is to mene she may not haue yow boþᵉ
Al be ȝe neuer so Ielouse ne so wroþe
And therfore y yow putte att this degre
That euery of yow shal haue his destene
As him ys shapen and harkneyþ in what wyse
Loo heer your͗e ende / of þat I shal deuise
¶ My wille is þis for plat conclusioıı̄un
With outen ony more replicacioıı̄un
Yet if that yow likith takith it for þe beste
That eueri of yow shall gōn where þat him leste
Freli with outen raunsoun or daungere
And þis day Lti wekis and no nere
Eueri of yow shall brynge an C knyȝtis
Armed for þe listes att alle riȝtes
Alle redi to darreyne hir by bateyle
And þis behote y yow with outen fayle
Vp on my trouþe and as I am a knyȝt/
That whethur of yow þat that hath myȝt/
That is to seyn that/ whethur he or þu
May with his .C. as y seide ryȝt now
Sle his contᵃrarie / or out of listes driue
Hym shall y gyue Emelie to wyue
To whom that fortune haþ yeue so fayre gᵃrace
The listes shall I make in þis place
And so god wiseli on my soule rewe
As y shall euene iuge be and trewe
Ne ȝe shull non othur ende with me make
That on of yow shall be ded or take
And if ie thenkith þat this is wel seid
Sey your͗e auise and holde iow wel apayd/
This is your͗e ende and your͗e conclusion
Who lokith now lyȝtly but Palamon
Who spryngith vp for Ioye but Arcite
Who so coude it telle or who so coude it endite
The Ioye that is mad in þe place
Whanne Thesius had don so fayre a gᵃrace
But doıı̄un on knes wente eủery maner wyȝt/
And thankeþ him wiþ al hir herte and myȝt/
And namely þe thebanes ofte sithe
And thus with good hope and herte bliþᵉ
They toke her leue and homward gan þey ryde
To thebes ward with olde walles wide
I trowe men wolde deme it necligence
Iif y forȝete to telle þe dispence
Of thesius þat goth so bisily
To make vp þe listes rially
That suche an oþur theatre as hit was
I dar wel seye in þe werld never þer nas
The circuite a myle was aboute
Walled with ston and diched al wiþ oute
Round was þe shap in maner of a compas
Ful of degrees þe hiȝte of XLti paas
That whanne aman was sett on a degree
He shuld not lette his felow to se
Estward þer stod \a tom/ of marbul white
Westward ryȝt/ suche an othir in þe opposite
And shortly for to concluden suche a place
Was non in erthe ne so litil aspace
For in þe land þer was no crafti man
That geometrie ne ars metrik can
Ne portrayour ne kerủere of ymages
That thesius gaff him boþe mete ⁊and wages
The theatre to make and to deuise
And for to don his ryȝt sacⁱrifice
He Estward hath vp ōn þe gate aboue
In worshippe of venus goddesse of loue
Don make an auter and an oratorie 23 23 21
And also westward in memorie
Of Mars he makitħ haþ such an oþur
That coste largely of gold afothur
And Northward in atoret of þe wal
Off Alibaster white and red coral
An oratarie Riche for to see
In worshippe of diane of chastite
Haþ thesius do wrouȝt in noble wise
But ȝit had I forgeten for to diuise
The nobil kervynge and þe portraytures
The shapp þe conntenaunce of þe figures
That were inne þe oratories þre
First in þe temple of venus maistow see
Wrouȝt in þe wal ful pitous to be holde
The broken slepes and þe sikes colde
The sacryd terees and þe waymenyngge
The firste strokes of þe desirynge
That loues seruauntes in this liff enduren
The othes that hir comenauntes assuren
Plesaunce and hope desire fulhardinesse
Beaute ⁊and yoūthe baudrie and richesse
Charmes and force lesynges flaterye
Dispence and besinesse and Ielousie
That wered of ȝolwe goldes a garland
And a cokcowe sittynge on hir hond
Festes Instrumentes caroles and daunces
Lust and array with aƚƚ circunstaunces
Off loue wheche y Rekened and Rekene shal
By ordre were peyntid on þe waƚƚlle
And mo þanne y can make of mencioıı̄un
For shortly alle þe mount of citheroıı̄un
There Venus haþ hir pryncipal dwellynge
Was shewid on þe wal in port̉reynge
With all þe gardeyn̄ and the lustinesse
Not was forgeten þe porter r͗e ydelnesse
Ne narcisus þe fayre ayer͗e agon̄
Ne ȝit þe folye of kynges Salomon
Neȝett the strengthe of hercules
The enchauntementes of medea and cerces
Ne of turnus with þe hardi feers corage
The poet Cresus caytiff in seruage
This may ȝe sen þat wisdom̄ ne richesse
Beaute ne liȝt strengthe hardinesse
Ne may wiþ venꝰus holde chaumpartie
For as hir liste þe werld may she agye
Lo al þis folk so cauȝt were in her las
Til they for woo Ful ofte seide allas
Suffichith here ensaumplis on or two
And thouȝ I couþe Rekene a thousand mo
The statue of venus glorious to see
Was naked fletynge in þe see
And fro þe nauel doun̄ al kevered was
With walles grene and bryȝt as ony glas
A Citole in her hous had she
And on her hed ful semely for to see
A Rose garland Fressh and swete smellyngge
Aboue hir hed dowes flicerynge
Biforn hir stod hyr sone cupido
Vp on his shulders weynges hadde he two
And blynd he was as it is offte sene
A bowe he bare and arwes bryȝte and kene
Whi shulde y not telle yow al
The portratur͗e that was vp on̄ þe wal
With Inne þe temple of mars þe rede
Alle peyntid was þe wal in lengtþe and eke in brede
Lik to þe estrees of þat gresli place
That hiȝte þe grete temple of mars in tᵃrace
In thilke colde frosti regioıı̄un
Ther as mars hatħ his soueraigne mansioıı̄un
First on þe wal was peyntid a forest
In wheche þer was noþur man no best
With knotti knarri bareyne trees olde
Off stubbes sharpe and hiduos to falle
In wheche þer ranne arombil and a swougħ
As thouȝ a storme shuld breste eủery bougħ
And dounward on an hille vnder a bent 22
Ther stod þe temple of mars armypotent
Wrouȝt all of borned stel wheche þe entre
Was longe and streite and gasteli for to see
That made aƚƚ þe gates for to rise
The northeren lyȝt in at þe dore shon̄
For wyndowe on þe walle was þer non̄
Thur wheche men myȝte any lyȝt deserne
The dore was of athamaunte eterne
I clenched ouertwart and endelonge
With yren towȝ for to make it stronge
Euery piler þe temple with sustene
Was tonne gret wiþ yren bryȝt and shene
Ther saw I þe derk ymagynynge
Of felonie and al þe compassynge
The cruel yre red as ony glede
The pykepurs and eke þe pale drede
The smylere wiþ þe knyff vnder þe cloke
The shepen with þe blake smoke
The Treson̄ of morderynge in þe bed
The open werre with woundes al be bled
Contek with blodi knyff and sharp manace
Al ful of chirkynge was þe sori place
The sleer of him self ȝet saw y there
His herte blod was spreynte al in his here
The nayle dreuen in þe shode anyȝt
The colde deth with moutħ gapynge vpryȝt
Amyddis þe temple sat myshaunce
With discomfort and sori contenaunce
Ȝet saw y wodenesse laughynge in his rage
Armed compleynte outhees and fers outerage
The careyne in þe bussħ wyþ þe þrote y korue
A mᵗ slayn and not with qualmed y storue
The tiraunt with þe pᵃray birafte
The toun̄ distroyed þer was no þyng lafte
Ȝet saw y brent þe shippes hoppestoures
The hunte strangled wiþ þe wilde beres qȝ

div.l: (base) The Sowe freten the child / right in the Cradel
(base) The Cook yscalded / for al his longe ladel
(base) ¶ Naught was forgeten / by the Infortune of Marte
(base) The Cartere / ouer ryden / with his Carte
(base) Vnder the wheel / ful lowe he lay adown
(base) Ther were also / of Martes deuysioun
(base) The Barbour / and the Bochier and the Smyth
(base) That forgeth sharpe swerdes / on his styth
(base) ¶ And al aboue / depeynted in a tour
(base) Saugh I Conquest sittyng in greet honour
(base) With the sharpe swerd / ouer his heed
(base) Hangynge / by a subtil twynes threed
(base) ¶ Depeynted was / the slaghtre of Iulius
(base) Of grete Nero / and of Anthonius
(base) Al be / that thilke tyme / they were vnborn
(base) Yet was hir deeth / depeynted ther biforn
(base) By manacynge of Mars / right by figure
(base) So was it shewed / in that purtreyture
(base) As is depeynted / in the Sertres aboue
(base) Who shal be slayn / or ellis deed for loue
(base) Suffiseth oon ensample / in stories olde
(base) I may nat rekne hem alle / thogh I wolde
(base) ¶ The Statue of Mars / vpon a Carte stood
(base) Lyke vnto the figure of vigynys
(base) Armed / and loked grym / as he were wood
(base) And ouer his heed / ther shynen two figures
(base) Of sterres / that been clepyd in Scriptures
(base) That oon Puella / that oother Rubeus
(base) This god of armes / was arrayed thus
(base) A wolf ther stood / bifore hym at his feet
(base) With eyen rede / and of a man he eet
(base) With subtil pencel / was depeynted this storie
(base) In redoutynge of Mars / and of his glorie
(base) ¶ Now to the temple / of Diane the chaste
(base) As shortly as I kan / I wol me haste
(base) To telle yow / al the discripsioun
(base) Depeynted been the walles / vp and doun
(base) Of huntyng and of shamefast chastitee
(base) Ther saw I. / how woful Calistopee
(base) Whan that Diane / agreued was with here
Was torned from a woman to a bere 23
And aft̉er was she mad þe lodesterre
Thus was it peynted I can yow no ferre
Hiw sone is eke a sterre as men may see
Ther saw y diane y torned to a tre
I mene not þe goddesse diane
But penneus dowȝtir wheche hiȝt dane
Ther saw y attheon an herte maked
For uengaunce that he saw diane al naked
I sawe how his hoıı̄undes haue him cauȝt
And freten hym for þey knewe hym nauȝt
Ȝit peȳnted was a litil ferþer more
How Atthalaunt hunted þe wilde bore
And Melagre and many an othur mo
For whiche diane wrouȝte hym care ⁊and wo
There saw I many a worþy storye
Wheche me list not drawe to memorie
This goddesse on an herte ful wel an high seet
With smale houndes all aboute her feet
And vndernethe hir fete she hadde a mone
Wexynge it was and it shuld wane sone
In gaudi grene hir statue clothud was
With bowe in honde and arwes in a cas
Hyr yen kaste she ful lowe adoūn
Ther Pluto had his derke regioıı̄un
A womman trauelynge was hir befornᵉ
But for hir child was so longe vnbornᵉ
Ful pitously lucena ganshe calle
And seide helpe for þou maist best of alle
Wel coude he peynte lyuely þat it wrouȝte
With manye a florey ne he þe coloures bouȝte
Now ben þe listes mad and off thesius
That att his grete coste arayed thus
The temples and þe theatre eủerydel
Whanne it was don̄ him liked wonder wel
But stynte y wille of thesius alite
And speke y wille of Palamōn and arcite
The day approchith of hir retornynge
That eueri of shuld and knyȝtes brynge
The bateile to darreyne as y yow told
And to athenes hir comenaıı̄untes to be hold
Hath eueri of hem brouȝt an C knyȝtes
Wel armed for to werre at all ryȝtes
And sekerly er trowed many a man
That neuer sith þe werld began
That for to speke of knyȝthod of hir hond
As feer as god hath mad see or lond
Nas not of so fewe men so noble compaignye
For eueri of hem loued chiualrie
And wolde his þankes hane a pasant name
Hath prayed for to bene at þat game
And wel was hym þat þer to chosin was
For if þ͗e feel to morwe suche a caas
Ye knowen wel þat eu͗ey lusti knyȝt /
That loueth paramoures and hath his myȝt
Were it in Engelond or eƚƚ where
They wolde hir thankes willen to be there
To fiȝten for a ladi bēnndicite
Hit were a lusti siȝt for to see
And ryȝt so ferde þei with Palamon̄
With hym þer come knyȝtes many on
Some wel be armed in an haburgon̄
And in a brestplate and a lyȝt gipon̄
And som will haue a peyr͗e platis large
And some wil haue a pruce shild or a targe
Some will ben armed on his legges wele
And some an Ax and some amace of stele
Ther nys non̄ newe gise that it nas old
Armed were they as y haue yow told
Eueri of him aft̉er his oppinion̄
Ther maiste self þu se the comynge with Palamon̄
Ligurge him self þe grete kyng of Tᵃrace
Blak was his berd and manly was his face
The cercles of his yen in his hed
They glowden bitwyx ȝolwe and red
And lik a griffon loked he a boute
Witħ kempe heres on his browes stoute 24
His lemes grete his brawne harde and stronge
(base) Hys shuldres brode / hise armes rounde and longe
(base) And as the gyse was / in his contree
(base) Ful hye / vpon a Chaar of gold stood he
(base) With foure white Boles / in the trays
(base) In stide of Cotearmure / ouer his harnays
(base) With nayles yelwe / and brighte as any gold
(base) He hadde a Berys Skyn / colblak / for old
(base) His longe heer / was kembed bihynde his bak
(base) As any Rauenes fethere / it shoon for blak
(base) A wrethe of gold / greet of huge wighte
(base) Vpon his heed / and ful of stones brighte
(base) Of fyne Rubyes / and of dyamauntz
(base) Aboute his Chaar / ther wente white Alauntz
(base) Twenty and mo / as grete as any steer
(base) To hunten at the leoun / and the deer
(base) And folwed hym / with mosel faste ybounde
(base) Colered of gold / and turrettes filed rounde
(base) An hundred lordes / hadde he in his route
(base) Armed ful wel / with hertes stierne and stoute
(base) ¶ With Arcita / in stories as men fynde
(base) The grete Emetrius / the kyng of Inde
(base) Vpon a Steede bay / trapped in steel
(base) Couered in a clooth of gold / dyapred weel
(base) Cam ridynge / lyk the god of Armes Mars
(base) His cote armure / was of clooth of Tars
(base) Couched with perlys white / and rounde and grete
(base) His sadel was / of brend gold newe ybete
(base) A Mantelet vpon his shulder hangynge
(base) Bretful of Rubies reede / as fyr sparklynge
(base) His crispe heer / lyk rynges was yronne
(base) And that was yelow / and glitred as the sonne
(base) His nose was heigh / hise eyen bright Citryn
(base) His lyppes rounde / his colour was sangwyn
(base) A fewe fraknes / in his face yspreynd
(base) Bitwixen yelow / and som del blak ymeynd
(base) And as a leoun / he his lookyng caste
Off xxvᵗⁱ ȝere his age y caste
His berd was wel bigonne for to sprynge
His voice was as a Trumpet thundrıı̄unge
Vp on his hed he werde of laurer grene
A garland Fressh and lusti for to sene
Vp on his hand he bare for his dilite
An egle tame as any lelie white
An houndred lordes hadde he with him þere
And al armed saue hir hedes in al her gere
Ful richely in al maner thynges
For trustith wel þat ducꝭes erles ⁊and kynges
Were gaderd in this noble compaignye
For loue and for encrees of chiualrie
Aboute this kyng þer ranne on eủery part
Ful many a lion and leopard
And in this wise these thebeannes alle ⁊and some
Bene on þe sonday to þe Cite come
Aboute prime and in þe toune a lyȝt
This Thesius this duc þis worthi knyȝt
Whanne he hadde hem brouȝt in to his cite
And Inned every man aft̉er his degre
He Festitħ hym and dotħ so gret labour͗e
To esen hem and to don̄ hem alle honour͗e
That yet men wenen þat nomans witt
Off non estate couþe amende hit /
The minstralcie þe seruice at feste
The grete yeftes to þe meste and leste
The Riche array of thesius paleys
Ne who sat first ne last vp on̄ þe dees
What ladies fayrist bene ne best daunsynge
Or wheche of hem can best daunce or synge
Ne who most felyngli spekith of loue
What hawkes sitti þou þe perche aboue
What houndes liggen in þe flour͗e a doun̄
Off al this now make y no no mencioıı̄un
But al þe effect þat þenkiþ me þe beste
Now comyth þe beste herkenyþ yef ie liste
The sonday nyȝt or day began to sprynge
Whanne Palamon þe larke herde synge
Alþouȝ it were nouȝt day bi owres two
Ȝit songe the larke and Palamon ryȜ tho
With hool hertte and with an hiȜe corage
He roos to wenden on his pilgrimage
Vn to þe blisfull Cithara benigne
I mene venus honurable and digne
And in hir our͗e he walketh forþ a paas
Vn to þe tmeple th** þe listes was
And doun̄ he kneled and with homble chere
And with hertte sore seyde as ye may here
Fairest of faire o lady myn Venus
Dowȝtir of Ioue and spouse to Vulcanus
Thou gladere of the mount of citheron
For þilke loue þou haddest to Adon
Haue pite on me of my bitter peynes smerte
And take myn humble prayer at þyn herte
Allas y haue no langege for to telle
The affect neþe tormentz of myn helle
Myn herte may not myn harmes be be wrye
I am so confused I can not seye
But merci ladi bryȝt þat knowest wel
My þuoȝt and myn harmes þat I feel
Consider on aƚƚ þys and rewe vp on my sore
As wisli as I shaƚƚ for euermore
Hensorth my myȝt thi trewe ʆseruaunt be
And holde werre alwey wiþ chastite
That make y myn a vow so ȝe me helpe
I kepe not of armes for to ȝelpe
Ne y axe not to morwe to haue victorie
Ne renoun̄ in this caas ne veyne glorie
Of price of armes blowen vp and doun
But y wolde haue ful possessioıı̄un
Off emelie and die in her seruice
Fynde þou þe maner how and in what wise
I recche not but it may better be
To haue victorie of hem or þey of me
So that I haue myn lady in myn armes
For thouȝ so be that mars is god of armes
Youre vertu ys so gret in heuene aboue
That if thou list I shal wel haue my loue
Thi temple shal I worshippe euer mo
And on þyn auter where I ryde or go
I wil do sacrifice and feres bete
And if ye wiƚƚ not so my lady swete
Thanne praye y yow to morwe wᵗith a sper͗e
That arcite me þoruȝe þe herte bere
Thanne recche y not whan I haue lost my liff
Thouȝe þat Arcita wynne hir to his wiff
This is þe affect and ende of my prayer͗e
Ȝyue me my loue þou blisful lady dere
Whanne þe orison was don̄ of palamon̄
His sacrifice he dede and þat anon̄
Ful pitously with al circumstances
Aƚƚ telle y not as now his obseruaunces
But att laste þe Statue of venus shoke
And mad a signe wher bi that he toke
This his prayer accepted þat day
For þouȝ þe signe shewed a delay
Ȝit wiste he wel that grauntid was his bone
And with glad herte he wente hym hom̄ ful sone
¶ The thred our͗e in equal Palamon̄
Beganne to venus temple for to gon̄
Vp roos þe sonne and vp roos emelie
And to þe temple of diane gan she hiȝe
Hir maidenes þat she thider wᵗith hir ladde
Wel redeli þe fere wiþ hem þey hadde
The encence þe clotħ and þe remenannt al
That to þe sacrifice longen shal
The hornes ful of metħ as was þe gise
Ther wanted not to don hir sacrifice
Smo kynge þe temple ful of clothes faire
This Emelie with herte debonayre
Hir bodi wissh wᵗith water of a welle
But how she dede hir ryȝtt y dar not telle
But hit be ony thyng in gen̉eraƚƚlle
And ȝit it were agame to here it al 26
To him þat menyþ wel it were nocharge
But it is good a man to be at large
Hir bryȝt here was kempt vntressed al
A Coronne of a grene oke serial
Vp on her hed was sett faire and mete
To fires on þe auter gan she bete
And dede hir thinges as men may beholde
In stace of Thebes and his bokes olde
Whanne kyndled was þe fire wiþ pitous chere
Vn to diane she spak as ye may here
O chaste goddesse of þe wodes grene
To whom boþe heuene and helle and erthe is sene
Quene of þe regne of Pluto derk and lowe
Goddesse of maydenesse that my herte hast knowe
Wel many aȝere and wost what y desire
kepe me fro thy vengeance and þy Ire
That Attheon þat is about cruelly
Chast goddesse wel wost þou þat y
Desire to be amaiden al my liff
Ne neuer wiƚƚ y be loue ne wiff
Thou wost y am ȝet of þy compagnye
A mayde and loue huntynge and venerie
And for to walken in þe wodes wilde
And not to be a wyff and be with childe
Nouȝt wol y knowe of compaignie of man
Now helpe me lady sith ȝe may and can
For þo in formes þat þou hast in þe
And Palamon̄ þat hath suche loue to me
And Arcite þat loue me sore
This gᵃrace praye þe wiþ outen more
As sende loue an pees / be twene hem two ij
And fro me torne her hertis so
That all hir hote loue and desir͗e
And all hir besy torment and her yre
Be queinte or turne in to an oþ̉er place
And yef so be þou wiƚƚ not do my gᵃrace
Or yf my destyne be shapen so to do
That I most nedes haue ony of hem two
As sende me hym / þat most desired me
Be holde godesse off clene chastite
The bitter teres on my chekes falle
Sith thow art mayden and keꝑper of vs alle
Thow my maydenhod kepe and wel preʆserue
And while y leue a mayden y wiƚƚ þe serue
The fires brenne vpon̄ þyn auter clere
While Emelie was þus in her prayere
But sodenly she sawe a thynge queynte
For ryȝt anon̄ / on̄ of þe feres queynte
And quekene agayn̄ and aftir anon
That other fire was queynt and al agoon̄
And as it queynte it made awhistelynge
As don̄ þese wete brondes in her brennynge
And atte brondes ende / out ran anon̄
As it were / blody dropes many on̄
For whiche / so sori was Emelie
That she was nyȝ mad and gan to cⁱrie
For she ne wiste what it signyfied
But only for fere thus she cried
And wepte þat it was pite for to here
And there wiþ al diane gan opere
With bowe in honde ryȝt as an hunteresse
And seyde douȝtir stynte þy heuynesse
Amonge þe goddes hiȝe it is affermed
And bi eterne word wrete and confermed
Thow shalt ben wedded to on of þe
That hane for þe so moche care and wo
But vnto wheche of hem I may not telle
Fare wel y may no lenger dwelle
The feres wheche on þe auter brenne
Shull declaren or þat þou go henne
Thyn auenture of loue as in þis caas
And with þat word þe arwes in þe cace
Off þe godesse clateren and faste rynge
And forth she wente and made a vanysshynge
For whech þis Emelie astonyed was
