And ouer aƚƚ this yet seide he mekil mor͗e
To his affecte ful wisly to en horte
The peple þat þey shuld hem reconforte
Duc thesius wiþ aƚƚ his bisi cure
Castith now wher͗e the sepultur͗e
Of gode arcite may best maked be
And most honurable and to his degre
And att laste he toke conclusioıı̄un
That there as first Arcite and palamon̄
Had for loue the bateyle hym betwene
That in þe selue groue suete and grene
There as he hadde his amorous desires
His compleynte and for loue his hote fires
He wolde make a fere in þe wheche þe office
Funeral / he myȝt all complice
He lett anon̄ comaunde to hakke and hewe
The okes olde and ley hem on a rewe
In culpons weƚƚ arayed for to brenne
His officers wiþ swifte fote þey renne
And redi anon̄ to his comaundement
And aftir this thesius hath y sent
Aftir abere and it ouer al spradde
With cloth of gold þe richiste þᵗat he hadde
And of þat same sute he clad Arcite
Vp on his hondis his gloues white
Ek on his hed a coroun̄ of laurer grene
And in his hond a swerd ful bryȝt and shene
He leide him bare þe visage on þe bere
Ther with he wepe that pite was to her͗e
And for þe peple shuld sen hym alle
Whan̄ne it was day he brouȝte hym to þᵉ halle
That rorith of þe cⁱrie and þe soun̄
Tho cam this woful Thybean þis Palamon̄
With floteri berd and ruggi asshy heres
In clothis blake I dropped aƚƚ with teres
And passyng othur of wepynge Emelye
Was reufullest of alle þe compaignye
In as moche as þe seruice shuld be
The more noble and riche in her degree
Duc thesius lete in stedes brynge
That trapped wer͗e in stele al gletterynge
And couerd witħ þe armes of daun̄ Arcite
Vp on̄ þe stedes Grete and white
There seten folk on whiche on bare his shild 36 36 34
An othir his spere in his hondis hild
The thredde bare witħ hym his bowe turkeys
Off brente golde was the caas and þe harneys
And ryden forth a paas wiþ rewful chire
Toward þe groue as ye shaƚƚ aftur her͗e
The nobleste of þe grekes þat þer͗e wer͗e
Vp on̄ hir shulders Cariden þe bere
Wiþ slak paas and eyn wete and rede
Thorwȝ out þᵉ Cite bi þᵉ maister strete
That sprad was al with blak and woıı̄undir hiȝe
Riȝt with þe same is þe strete wrye
En þe riȝt hond wente holde egeus
And on þat othur side duc Thesius
Witħ vesseƚƚ in hir hond of gold fuƚƚ fyne
And fuƚƚ of hony mylke blode and wyne
Eke Palamoıı̄un witħ wel grete compaignye
And aft̉er þat cam wofuƚƚ Emelye
With fire in honde as was pegyse
To do þe office of feneral seruyce
Higħ labour͗e and full grete apparalynge
Was att ʆseruyce and att firste makynge
That with his grene Topp the heuene rauȝte
And xxᵗⁱ fademe of brede the arme strauȝte
This is to seye the bowes were so brode
Off stree first was þer͗e leid many a lode
But how the fire was maked up on̄ hiȝᵗe
Ne eke the names how þe trece hyȝte
As oke virre birche aspe holm̄ popeler͗e
Wilowe emle plane assħ box chesteyne laurer
Mapel thorn̄ beche hasel Ew whipultre
How þey wer͗e feld shaƚƚ not be told for me
Ne how the goddes ronne vp and doun̄
Disherited of hir habitacioıı̄un
In wheche they woneden in reste and pees
Nymphes fawnes and amadries
Ne how þᵉ bestes nethe briddes alle
Fledde for fere whanne the wode was falle
Ne how the ground agast was of þᵉ lyȝt
That was not wont to see þe sonne bryȝt
Ne how the fire couched was with stree
And thanne with drie stikkis clouen athre
And wiþ grene and spicerie
And thānne wiþ cloth of golde and perrye
And gerlandes hangynge many a flour͗e
The mirre þe encense wiþ so moche odour͗e
Ne how þat Arcite lay among aƚƚ this
Ne what richesse aboute his bodie ys
Ne how þat Emelye as was þe gise
Put in þe fiere of funeral ʆseruice
Ne how she swouynge made þe fire
Ne how she spak ne what was hir desir͗e
Ne what Ieweƚƚ men in þe fire caste
Whānne þe fire was mad and brent faste
Ne how some caste in her shildes ⁊and some hir sper͗e
And of hir vestementis wheche þey wer͗e
And cuppes ful of milke ⁊and wyne and blod
In to þe fere that brente as it were wod
Ne how þe grekes with An huge route
Thries reden al þe fire aboute
Vp on þᵉ left hond wiþ a gret showtynge
And thries wiþ þe speres claterynge
And thries how þe ladies gonne crie
Ne how that lad was homward Emelie
Ne how arcite was brent to Asshen cold
Ne how that þe liche wake was hold
Al þat nyȝt ne how þe grekes play
The wake pley ne kepe y not to sey
Who wrasteles best with oile anoynte
Ne how þat bare him best in no disioynte
I wiƚƚ not tellen alle how þey gon̄
Hom̄ to athenis whan̄ne þe play is don̄
But shortly to þᵉ poynt wiƚƚ y wende
And make of my longe tale an ende
By processe and by lengthe of certeyn ȝers
Alle stynte is þe mornynge and the teris
Of grekes bi on gen̉eral assent 35
Thanne semed me þer was a parlement
At Athenes vp on acerteyn poynt and caas
Among wheche poyntes spoken was
To haue wiþ certeyn contre aliaunce
And fulli of Thebanues obeisaunce
For whiche þis noble Thesius anoıı̄un
Lete sende aftir gentil Palamoıı̄un
Vnknowe to hym what was þe caas ⁊and whi
But in his blac clothys sorwefully
He come at his comaundement in hye
Tho sente Thesius for Emelie
Whanne they wer͗e sett on þe hieste wal on þᵉ place
And thesius hadde abiden aspace
Or ony word come from his wise breste
His yen sette he there as him list
And wiþ a sad visage he siked stille
And after ward reȝt thus he seide his wille
¶ The first mener of þe cause aboue
Whanne he first made þe fayr͗e Cheyne of loue
Grete was þe affect and hyȝe was his entent
Wel wiste he why and what þer͗e he ment
For wiþ þat fayr͗e Cheyne of loue he bond
The fire the ayere þe water and þe land
In certeyn bondes þat þey may not flee
That same prince and þat same mouer qduod he
Hath stablisshyd in þis wrecched werld a doun̄
Certeyn̄ dayes of dominacioıı̄un
To alle that engendred in þis place
Ouer þe wheche day þey may not pace
Alle mowe they ȝet tho dayes abregge
There nedetħ non auctorite to legge
For hit is proued by experience
But þat me leste to declar͗e my sentence
Thanne may men by this ordre discerne
That is mouer stable is and eterne
Weƚƚ may men knowe but it be a fool
That eủery partie darveynce from his hool
For nature hath not take his bigynnyngge
Off no partie or of cantel of a thynge
But of a thyng that ꝑparfiit is and stable
Descendynge so til it be coeumpable
And therfore his wyse puruyaunce
He hath so wel besert his ordenaıı̄unse
That the spere of thynges of progressiounes
Shullen enduren bi successiounes
And nouȝt eterne wiþ outen ony lye
This maist þou vndirstonde and seen at eye
Lo the ook þat is so longe a norisshynge
Fro the tyme þat it begynnyþ first to sprynge
And hath so longe a lif as ye may see
Ȝet att laste wasted is þe tree
Consedretħ also how þe harde ston̄
Vnder our͗e foot on wheche we trede and gon̄
Ȝet wastid it as it lith by þe weye
The brode reủere somtyme waxit drye
The grete toun̄es sewe wane and wende
Thanne may we see that aƚƚ this þyng haþ ende
Of man and woman sen we wel also
That nedetħ in on of þᵉ termes two
That is to seyn in youthe or eƚƚ in age
He moste be ded as wel þe kyng as a page
Some in his bed some in þe depe see
Some in þe large feld as ye may see
There helpith not al gotħ þe same weye
Thanne may y see that aƚƚ thyng shal dye
But what makyþ this but Iubiter þe kyng
This is prynce and cause of aƚƚ thyng
Conuertynge aƚƚ thyng vn to hys propir wille
For wheche it is darreyued soth to telle
And here ageyns no Creatur͗e alyue
Off no degree auayled for to steyne
Thanne is hit wysdom̄ as it thenkyth me
To make vertu of necessite
And take it welle that we may not esshewe
And namelicħ that to vs alle is owe And who so
And who so grucchetħ ouȝt he dotħ folye 36
And rebel is to hym that al may gie
And certeinly a man hath most honour͗e
To dyen in his excellence and his flour͗e
Whane he is seker of his good name
Than̄ne hatħ he doıı̄un his frend ne hym no shame
And gladder oȝte his frend to be of his detħ
Whanne witħ onour͗e ȝolden vp is þᵉ bretħ
Thanne whanne his name appalled is for age
For aƚƚ forgeten is his vasselage
Thanne is it best as for a worthy fame
To dyen whan̄ne he is best of name
The contᵃrarie of this is worshippfulnesse
Why gruchen we whi haue we heuynesse
That gode Arcite of cheualrie þe floure
Depart is with duet and honour͗e
Out of this foule prisoıı̄un of this liff
Whi gruchen here his coseyn and his wyf /
Of his wilfare that louen hem so wel
Can he hem thank nay god wote neuẻre a del
That bothe his soule and eke hym offende
And ȝet they mowe not hir lustes not amende
What may I concluden of this longe serie
But aft̉re woo I rede us to be merye
And thanke Iubiter of aƚƚ his grace
And or we departe fro this place
I Rede we make of sorwes two
O parfit Ioye lastynge euẻre mo
And loketh now wher͗e most sorwe is Inne
There wille I first amende and bygynne
Suster qduod he this is my first assent
With al a vice here of my ꝑparlement
That gentil Palamoıı̄un your͗e owene knyȝt
That serued yow with wiƚƚ herte ⁊and myȝt
And euẻre hath doıı̄un fitħ ȝe him first knewe
That ye shuƚƚ of ȝour͗e grace vp on him rewe
And take him for husbond and for lord
Lene me your͗e hond for this is myn acord fi

div.l: (base) Lat se now / of youre wommanly pitee
(base) He is / a kynges brother sone pardee
(base) And thogh he were / a poure Bachiler
(base) Syn he hath serued yow / so many a yeer
(base) And had for yow / so greet aduersitee
(base) It moste been considred / leueth me
(base) For gentil mercy / oghte to passen right
(base) ¶ Thanne seyde he thus / to Palamon the knyght
(base) I trowe / ther nedeth litel sermonyng
(base) To make yow / assente to this thyng
(base) Com neer / and taketh youre lady by the hond
(base) Bitwixe hem / was maad anon the bond
(base) That highte matrymoigne / or mariage
(base) By al the conseil / and the Baronage
(base) And thus / with alle blisse / and melodye
(base) Hath Palamon / ywedded Emelye
(base) And god / that al this world hath wroght
(base) Sende hym his loue / that hath it deere aboght
(base) For now is Palamon / in alle wele
(base) Lyuynge in blisse / in richesse / and in heele
(base) And Emelye / hym loueth so tendrely
(base) And he / hir serueth so gentilly
(base) That was ther no word hem bitwene
(base) Of Ialousie / or any oother teene
(base) Thus endeth Palamon / and Emelye
(base) And god saue / al this faire compaignye Amen
(base) ¶ Here is ended / the knyghtes tale
Whanne the knyȝt had his tale told
In al the compaignie was ther yong ne olde
That he ne seide it was a noble storie
And worthi to be drawe in memorie
And namely the gentell eủerychone
Oure ooste lowȝ and swore so mote y gone
This goth wel vnbokeled is þe male
Late se now how shal telle now an othur tale
For trewly this game is well bigonne
Now telle ye ʆsire monke yef ye conne The ꝓprologꝭes of þᵉ Meller
Somwhat to quyte with the knyȝtes tale
The Miller that for dronke was al pale
So that vnethe vp on his hors he sat
He wolde auale nothur hood ne hat
Ne abide noman for his curtesie
But in pilatis voice be gan to hie
And swore bi armes bi blode and bi bones
I can a nobil tale for þe nones
With the wheche I wil now quyte þe knyȝtes tale
Oure oste sawe that he was dronken of ale
And seide Robyn abide gode brothur
Sum beter man shal telle vs first an othur
And abide an late vs werke trustili
Bi goddes sowle qd he þat wil not y
For y wil speke or ell goo my wey
Oure oste answerde telle on a deuelwey
Thou art a fool thi witte is ouer come
Now harkenyth quod þe Miller alle and some
But first I make a protestacioıı̄un
That I am dronken I knowe wel by my sowoıı̄un
And therfore yef that I mispeke or say
Wite it ale of southwerk I yow pᵃy
For I wil make a legende or a lif
Bothe of A wriȝte and of his wyf
How a clerk sette þe wryȝtes cappe
The carpenter answerde stinte þy clappe
Late be thy lewed dronken harlotrie
Hit is a synne and eke g a gret folie
To appeiren ony man or to defame
And eke to brynge in suche name
Thow maiste I now of oþur thynges seyen
This dronken meller spak ful sone ageyne
And seide gode brothur osewolde
Who so hath no wyf is no cokowolde
But y seye not therfor that þou art on
There bene ful gode wyues manyon
Whi art thow angry with my tale now
I haue a wyf ꝑparde as wel as tho
Ȝet wolde y not for alle the oxen in my plow
Take vp me more thanne y now
As demen of my self that y wer on
I wille bileue verrily that y am non
An husbond shal not be inquisitif
Off goddes preuite nor of his wif
So he may fynde goddes foysen there
Off the remenaıı̄unt nydith not to enquer̉re
What shulde y seye more but þe miller̉re
He wolde for noman his wordis forbere
But telle his cherles tale in his maner̉re
Me forthenkith that y shall telle it her̉re
And therfore eủery gentil wyȝt y praye
Demeth for goddes loue what y saye
Of euel entent but for y mote reherce
Here tall alle be they bet̉er or wesse
Or ell falsen some of my matire
And therfore who so liste not for to her̉re
Torne ouer þe leef and chise an othir tale
For ye shuld fynde y nowe boþᵉ grete ⁊and smale
Off storiall thing that touched gentilnesse
And eke moralite and holynesse
Blame not me yef that ye chese amys
The Millere is a cherle ye wote well al this
So was þe reue and eke oþur mo
And of harlotrye they tolde boþᵉ two
Auysith yow and put me out of blame
And eke men shall not make of ernest of game
Whilome ther was dwellynge in oxenford
A Riche gnuffe that gestis held to bord
And of his craft he was a carpenter
With hym ther was dwellynge apore scoler
Had lerned art but all his fantasie
Was torned to astrologie
And couthe a certeyn of conclusiones
To deme bi int̉errogaciones
Yef that men asked of certeyn oures
Whethur men shuld haue drouȝte or ell showres The Miller
Or yef men shuld axe him what shuld falle
Off euery thyng men may not rekene alle
This clerk was cleped hende nycolas
Of derne loue he couthe and of solas
And ther to he was slyȝe and ful priue
And lik a mayde meke for to see
A Chaumbre had he in þat hostelerie
Al alone wiþ outen any compaignye
Ful fetisly diȝt with herbes swete
And he him self as he it were þe rote swete
Of licorice or of ony situale
His almageste with his bokes gret ⁊and smale
His astrelapre langynge vn to his art
Hys augrym stones layn fayr a part
On shelues couched att his beddis hed
His presse couerd with a faldynge red
And al aboue ther lay agay sautrie
On wheche he made a nyȝt melodye
So swetely that al the Chaumbur ronge
And angelus ad virginem he songe
And afir that he song þe kynges note
Wel ofte blissed was his mery throte
And thus þe suete clerc his tyme spente
Aftir his frendis fyndynge and his rente
This Carpenter hadde wedded a newe wif
Whiche that he loued more þane his lif
Of xviij ȝeres she was of age
Ielowse he was and kepte hir narwe in cage
For she was ȝong and wild and she was old
And demed him self be lik a cokewold
He knewe not catoıı̄un for his witte was rude
That bad men shuld wedde hir similitude
Men shuld wedde aftʳ hir estate
For youthe and elde bene ofte at bate
But sith he was falle in þe snare
He moste endur as othur folk her care
Full fayre was þys yonge wyff with alle
As any weselle hir body gent and smalle
A seinte she wered barred all of silk
A barmecloth as white as ony mylk
Vp on her lende ful many agore
White was hir smok and browded al afore
And ek behynde her colere all aboute
Of cole blak silk with Inne and eke wᵗith oute
The tapes of þe white volipere
Were of þe same sute of hir colere
Her felet brod of silk and sett ful hie
And sekerly she hadde a lecorous eye
Full small y pulled were hir browes two
And tho were bent and blak as ony slo
She was moche more blisfull for to se
Thanne is þe new pere on þe Ionette tree
And softir þanne is þe wolle of þe wethur
And there hunge a purs bi hir girdil of lethur
Tassed with silk apparaled with latoıı̄un
In all this world to seke vp an doun
There is noman so wise that coude thenche
So gay appopelette or suche a wenche
Full bryȝt was the shynynge of hir hewe
As in the tour the noble forged newe
But of hir song she was so loude and yerne
As any swalwe sittynge on a berne
Therto she coude skyppe and make game
As ony kede or calf folwynge þe dame
Hir mouth was suete as ony bracot or meth
Or hoorde of appell leide in hay or heth
Wynsynge she was as is a Ioly colt
Longe as amast and vpryȝt as a bolt
A broche she bare on hir loue coler
As brood as is the boos of a bokeler
Hir shoos were laced on hir leges hie
She was a premerole a pigges nye
For ony lord to liggen in his bed
Or ȝit for ony gode ȝoman to wed
Now sire and eft ʆsire so bifel this caas
That on a daye this hende Nicolas The Miller
Fil with this ȝonge wif to rage and play
While that hir husbond was att Osenay
As clerkes ben ful subtel and ful queynte
And pruuli he cauȝt hir bi the quente
And seide y wis but if I haue my wille
For derne loue of þe lemman I spille
And helde hir harde bithe haunche bones
And seide lemman loue me wel at ones
Or I wille dien so god me saue
And she spronge as doth þe colte in tᵃue
And with hir hed she wried faste a way
She seide I will not kisse þe bi my fay
Fy late be ꝙquod ich late be nicholas
Or y will Crie out herow and allas
Do wey your hondes for your curtesye
This nicholas gan merci for to crie
And spak so fayre and profred him so faste
That him hir loue graunted att laste
And swore hir oth bi seynte thomas of kent
That she wolde be att his comaundement
Whan̄n she may hir leiser wel aspie
My husbond is so full of Ielosie
That but ye wayte wel and be priue
I wot ryȝt wel I am but ded ꝙquod she
Imote be ful derne as in this caas
Nay there of care ye not ꝙquod nicolas
A clerk hadde letherlich beset his while
But yef a coude a Carpenter bigile
And thus they were a corded and I sworn
To wayte a tyme as I haue told bi forn
Whan̄n nicolas had don thus eủery dele
He thakked hir a boute þe lendis wel
He kiste hir swete and toke his sawtrie
And pleyth faste an makith melodie
Than fel it thus that / to þe parishirche
Cristes owne werkes for to worche
This gode wif wente vp on an haly day
Hir forhed shon as bryȝt as any da
So was it wasshe whanne she lete hir work
Now was there of þe paris chirche a clerk
The wheche that was cleped absolon
Crulled was his here and as þe gold it shon
And stronded as a fanne large and brod
Wel streite and euene lay his Ioly shode
His rude was red his yen gray as goos
With poules wyndowes Coruen in his shoos
In hosen red he wente fetisly
Clad he was ful smal and proꝑperly
All in a kirtull of lyȝt waget
Full fayr and thikke ben þe poyntis sett
And there vp on he hadde a gay surplis
As white as is þe blosme on þe ris
A meri child he was as god me saue
Wel coude he late blod or clyppe or shaue
And make a charter of lond or a quitaunce
In twynti manes coude trippe and daunce
Aftir the scole of oxenford tho
And with his legges caste to and fro
And pleyn songes on a smale ribibe
Therto he song somtyme a loude quinyble
And as wel coude he pleyn on a geterne
In all the toune þer nas brewehous ne tauerne
That he ne visite with his solas
There as any gay tappster was
But treuly he was somdel squaymous
Of fartynge and of his speche somdel daungerous
That absolon þat Ioly was and gay
Goth with a censer on þe holy day
Censynge þe wyues of þe parissh faste
And many alouely loke on hem þey caste
And namely on þe carpenters wyf
To loke on her him þouȝte amery lyf
She was so propir swete and licorous
I dar wel sayn ȝef she hadde ben a mous
And he a catte he wolde hir hent anon
The parissh clerc this Ioly absoloıı̄u
Hath in his herte suche aloue longynge
That of no wyf toke he non offerynge
For curtesie he seide he wold non
The mone whanne it was nyȝt ful bryȝt shon
And absolon hath his geterne take
And paramours he thouȝt to a wake
And forth he goth Ioliff and amarous
Til he come to þe carpenters hous
A litil aftir þe cokkis had crowe
And dresshed him vp bi ashot wyndowe
That was vp on the carpenters wal
He singith in his voice gentil and small
Now dere lady ief thi wille be
I pᵃy yow that ye wille rewe on me
Ful well a cordaunce to his geternynge
The carpenter awoke and herde him synge

Whanne that our͗e hoost had herd this ʆsermonynge
He gan to speke as lordly as akyng
He seide what amontith all this witt
What shulde we speke alday of holy writt
The deuel made a Reue for to preche
Or a sowter shipman or aleche
Say forth thy tale and tarye no lenger thi tyme
Loo depforth and hit is half wey prime
Loo grenewich that many a shrew is Inne
It were altyme thy tale fo to bigynne
Now seres ꝙquod osewold the Reue
I pray you that ye yow not greue
Thow y him answere and somdel sette his howe
For leuful is wiþ force for to showe
This dronkon miller͗e hath I told vs her͗e
How that bigiled was a Carpenter͗e
ꝐPar auentur͗e in scorn̄ for ik am on
And by your͗e leue y shall him quyte anon̄
Ryȝt in his Cherlis termes will y speke
I preye to god his nekke mot he breke
He can̄ wel in myn ye sen astalke
But in his owne he can not se a balk
AT Trumppyngton̄ not fer fro Cambrigge
Ther rennyþ a brook ⁊and ouer þᵗat is a brygge
Vp on wheche broke þer stant a mille
For this is soth verraly þat y yow telle
A miller͗e was þer͗e dwellynge many a day
As ony pecok he was proud and gay
Pipen he couthe and fisshe ⁊and nettes bete
And torne cupes and wel wrastel and shete
Ay bi his belt he bare a long panade
And of a swerdawerd a swerd ful trnchaunt was þe blade
A Ioly popper bare he in his pouche
Ther was noman for ꝑperil durste him touche
A Sheffeld thwitel bare he in his hose
Round was his face and cammuse was his nose
And pilled as an ape was his skulle
He was a market dassher atte fulle
Ther dorste noman handes vp on him legge
That he ne swor he shuld anon̄ abegge
A thef he was forsoþe of corn̄ and mele
And that asly and vsaunt for to stele
His name was hote deynous symkyn
A wyff he hadde come of noble kyn
The ꝑperson of þe toun̄ her fadir was
With hir he ȝaf full many a panne of bras
For that symkyn shuld in his blod alie
She was fostred in an nonnerie
For symkyn wolde no wiff haue as he seide
But she were well norisshed and amayde
To saue his estate and yomanrie
And she was as proud as is a pie
A wel faire syȝt was it vp on hem two
On holy dayes beforn̄ hir wold he goo
With his typpet wounden a bout his hed
And she come aftir in a gite of red
And symkyn had hosen of þe same
There durste noman clepe hir but dame
Was non̄ so hardy man that goth bi þe wey
That with hir dorste on̄s rage or ple
But yef he wolde be slayn of symkyn̄
With panade or wiþ knyf or boydekyn
For Ielousie folk ben ꝑperlous euer mo
Algate þey wolde her wyues wend so Noᵃta
And eke she was sumdel smotirliche
She was as digne as water in a dicche
As ful of hoker and bismar͗e
Hir thouȝte a lady shuld hir spar͗e
What for hir kynrede and hir norcerie
That she had lerned in þe nonnerie
A douȝtir had they betwyx him two
Of xxᵗⁱ wynter age age with outen ony moo
Sauyng a Child that was half yer͗e of age
In Cradil it lay and was a ꝓpropre page
This wenche thikke and wel I growen was
With Cammoys nose and yen gray as glas
With buttokkes brode and brestes round and hie
But ryȝt fayr was hir here I will not lye
The ꝑperson of þe toun̄ for she was fayr͗e
In purpos was to make hir his ayr͗e
Bothe of his catell and his mesuage
And straunge he made hit of hir mariagemarigemariage
Hys purpos was to sette hem hiȝe
In to some blod of noble noble auncetrie
For holy chrche good mot be dispendit
On holy chirche blod þat is descendit
Therfore he wolde his holy blod honoure
Thowȝ that he holy chirche shuld deuoure
Grete sokyn hath þis millere out of doute
Off whete and malt of al þe contre aboute
And namely ther was a grete collage
Men clepēn hit þe soler halle at Cantebrygge
There was hir whete and hir malt y grounde
And on a day it happed in astounde
Sike lay the mancuple on a maladie
Men wende wisteli þat he shuld die
For whiche this miller͗e stale boþe mele and corn̄
An hundrid tyme thanne more þan biforn
For there biforn̄ he stale but curteisly
But thanne he was a thieff outragisly
For whiche the wardeyn chidde and mad fare
But þer of sette þe millere not a tare
He craked bost and swor it was not so
Thanne wer͗e ther͗e yonge pore scolers two
That dwelleden in þe halle of whiche y seye
Testiff they were and lusti for to pleye
And only for hir merthe and reuerie
Vp on the wardeyn besily they crie
To yeue hem leue but a litil stounde
To go to mille and se hir corn̄ y grounde
And hardely they durste leye hir nekke
The millere shuld not stele half a pekke
Of corn̄ ne be slegh ne force him be reue
And att laste þe wardeyn ȝaf him leue
Iohn hiȝt that on̄ and aleyn hiȝt þat othur
Off o toun̄ were þey bore that hiȝt strothur
Ferre in þe north y can not telle where
This alyen makyth redi all his gere
And on þe hors his saak he caste anon
Forth goth aleyn þe clerc and also Iohn
With good swerd and boker͗e by his side
Iohn knew þe wey him neded no gide
And att mille the sak a doun̄ alyȝt
Aleyn spak first al hayl symond in syȝt
How faire thy thy dowȝtur and thi wyff
Aleyn welcome ꝙquod symkyn bi my liff
And Iohn also how now what do ȝe here
Bi god symond ꝙquod Iohn nede has na pere
Him be houes to serue him self þᵗat has na swayn
Or ell he is a fole as clerkis sayn
Our͗e manciple I hope will be ded
Swa werkes ay the wanges in his hed
And therfor͗e am y come and eke aleyn
To grynde our͗e corn̄ and to carie hit ham ageyn
I pray you sped vs henne what ȝe may
Hit shall be don̄ ꝙquod symkyn by my fa
Whatt woll ȝe do while that it is in hande
By god ryȝt bi þe hopper woll y stande
Quod Iohn and see how the corn̄ gas in
Ȝit saw y neuer by my fadirkyn
How the hopper wagges to and fra
Aleyn answerde Iohn wilt þou swa
Thānne wille y stanne binethe by my croun
And se how þe meles a doun̄
In to þe trouȝ that sshallshall sall be my disport
For Iohn in faith y may be of your͗e sort
I am as yuell amiller͗e as ar ȝe
This millere smyled of hir nycite
And thouȝt all this is but for a wile
Thei wene than noman may him bigile
But bi my thrift ȝet shall I blere her ye
For all þe slyȝt of hir philosophie
The more queynte crekes that they make
The more whanne I stele wolle I take
In stede of flour͗e yit wolle I yeue hem bren
The gretest clerkys ben not wisest men
As whilome to þe wolf spak the mar͗e
Off all hir art ne counte y nouȝt a tar͗e
¶ Out of the dore he wente priuily
Whānne that he saw his tyme softely
He lokith vp and doun̄ til he haue founde
The clerkes hors wher͗e he stod y bonde
Be hynde þe mille vnder a leuesel
And to the hors he goth him faire and wel
He strepith of þe bridil ryȝt anon̄
And whānne þe hors was loos he gynnyþ to gon̄
Toward þe fen þer͗e wilde maris renne
And furth wiþ we he thurwȝ thikke and þurwȝ thenne
The miller͗e goth ageyn no word ne seyde
But doth his note and with his clerkys pleyde
Til that hir corn̄ was fayr͗e and well Igrounde
And whānne þe mele was sakked and I bounde
This Iohn goth oute and fyndith his hors away
He gan to crie herow and welawa
Our͗e hors is lost aleyn for goddes bones
Steppe on thi fete come of man at ones
Allas our͗e wardeyn hath his palfrey lorn̄
This aleyn al for gat boþe mele ⁊and corn̄
What whilk wey is he gon he gan to crie
All was out of his mynde his husbondrye
The gode wiff cam lyppynge Inward at a renne
She seide allas your͗e hors is gon̄ to þe fenne
With wilde mars as faste as he may go
Vnthank come on his hed that him bond so
And he that shulde beter haue knyt þe reyne
Allas aleyn ꝙquod Iohn for cristis peyne
Ley doun̄ thi swerd and y will myn also
I is full full full swift god wate as is þe roo
By goddes herte he sshallshall sall not scape vs bathe
Why ne had thou put the capil in þe lath
Ilhayle aleyn bi god thou is a fonne
Thise sely clerkys haue ful faste y ronne
Toward the fen bothe aleyn and eke Iohn
And whanne the millere sy that þey were gon̄
He half a bushel of hir flour͗e hath take
And bad his wiff to knede it in a kake
He seide y trowe þe clerkes were a ferd
Ȝit can a myller͗e make a clerkes berd
For all his art ȝit late hem go hir wey
Lo wher͗e he goth ȝe lete the children̄ pley
They gete him not so lyȝtly by mycroun̄m croun̄my croun̄̄
This sely clerkis ronnen vp an doun̄
With kepe kepe stand stand Iossa war͗e þe rere
Ga whistil thow and y sshallshall sall kepe him here
But shortly til it was verrey nyȝt
They coude not thow they dede with al hir myȝt
Hir capil cacche he ran awey so faste
Til in a dicche they cauȝte him at laste
Wery and wete as best is in þe rayn
Comyth seli Iohn and wᵗith him comith aleyn
Allas ꝙquod Iohn the day that y was born̄
Now are we dreuen til hething and til scorn
Oure corn̄ is stole men wol vs folis calle
Bothe the wardeyn and our͗e felaws alle
And namly the miller͗e wellaway
Thus pleynth Iohn as he goth bi þe way
Toward the mille and bayard on his hond
The millere syttynge by þe fire he fond
For it was nyȝt and fether myȝt þey not
But for þe loue of god they him be souȝt
Off herberw and of ese for hir peny
The miller͗e seide ageyn yef ther be eny
Suche as it is ȝit shall ye haue your͗e part
Myn hous is streite and ye haue lerned art
Ȝe conne by argumentis make a place
A myle brod of xxᵗⁱ fete of space
Late se now ȝef this place may suffice
Or make it rowme with speche as is your͗e gise
Now symond seide Iohn by seynt Cutberte
Ay is thow mery and that is fayr͗e answert
I haue herd seie men shall of twa thinges
Take suche as he fynt or take suche as he bringes
But specialy y prey the host dere
Gete vs some mete and drynke and make vs cher͗e
And we wolle payen trewly at fulle
With empti hondis men may no hawkis tolle
Lo here our͗e siluer redy for to spende
This miller͗e to þe toun̄ his douȝtir sende
For ale and bred and rosted hem a goos
And bond hir hors it shuld nomor͗e go loos
And in his owne Chaumbre he mad a bed
With shetys and with chalouns fayr͗e spred
Nouȝt from his owne bed x fote or twelue
His dowȝtir had a bed by hir selue
Ryȝt in the same Chaunbre by and by
Hit myȝt not be no bet and cause why
There was no romer herberwe in þe place
They soupen and they speken hem to solace
And dronken euer strong ale atte þe beste
About mydnyȝt wente they to Rest
Wil hath this miller͗e verneyst his hed
Ful pale he was for dronken and not red
He yoxeht and spekith þoruȝ þe nose
As he were on þe quakke or the pose
To bed he goth and with him goth his wyff
As ony Iaye sheheshe liȝt was and Iolyf
So was hir Ioly whistill well y wet
The cradell att hir beddes fete is sett
To rokken and to yeue the Child sowke
And whanne dronke was þe alealþe ale in þe Crowke
To bedde wente þe douȝtir ryȝt anon̄
To bedde goth aleyn and eke Iohn
There is no more him nedith no dwale
This miller͗e hath so bibed ale
That as an hors he froutith in his slep
Ne of his tayle behynde he tok no kep
His wif bare him a burdon̄ ful stronge
Men myȝte hire routhyng her a forlonge
The wenche routhiþ eke ꝑper compaignie
And þe clerc þat herde this melodye
He rokked Iohn and seyde slepest thow
Herest thow euyr swilk song er now
Loo swilke a compen ys betwyx hem alle
A wilde fire on hir bodies falle
How harkened euer swilk a ferly thyng
Ye they shull haue the flour͗e of yuell endyng
This lange nyȝt there tides me no reste
But ȝit no force all shal be for þe beste
For Iohn seyde he as euer mote y thriue
Yef that y may ȝone wenche woll y swyue
Som esement hath lawe shapen vs
For Iohn there ys a lawe that saith thus
That yef aman be in o poynt agreued
That In anothur he shall be releued
Oure corn̄ is stolen sothely it is no nay
And we haue had an euel fitt to day
And sith y shall haue non̄ amendement
A geyn my losse y will haue myn esemen
By goddes sawle it shall non othur be
This Iohn answerde aleyn̄ auyse the
This miller͗e is a ꝑperlous man he seide
And yef that he be out of his slepe abreide
He myȝt don̄ vs bothe a velonye
And he answerde I Counte him not worth a flie
And vp he sterte and to þe wenche he crepte
This wenche lay vp ryȝt and faste slepte
Til he so nyȝ was or she myȝt aspie
That it had ben to late for to crie
And shortly for to seyn they wer͗e at on
Now pley aleyn for y will speke of Iohn
This Iohn lith stille a forlonge wey or two
And to him̄ self he makith routhe and wo
Allas ꝙquod he this is a wikked Iape
Now may y seye þat y is but an ape
Ȝit hath my felawe somwhat for his harm
He hath a the millers dowȝtur in his arm
He auntred him and hath his nedes sped
And y lye as a draff sak in my bed
And whanne this iape is told an oþur day
I shall be holde a daff a cokenay
I wolle arise and auntered by my faith
Vn hardi Is vnsely thus men saith
And vp he ros and saftely he wente
Vn to þe cᵃradell and in his hand it hente
And bare it softe vnto his beddis feet
Sone aftir the wiff hir routhynge leet
And gan awake and wente hir out to pisse
And come ageyn and gan hir cradil misse
And groped here and ther͗e but she fond non
Allas ꝙquod she I had almost mysgon̄
I hadde almost gon to þe clerkys bed
Ey bn̄enedicite than hadde y foule sped
And forth she goth til she þe cᵃradel fond
She gropeth alwey ferthir with hir hond
And fond the bed and thouȝt not but good
By cause that the cᵃradell bi hit stoo
And nyste where she was for hit was derke
But faire and well she crepte in to clerk
And lith full stille and wolde haue cauȝt a slep
With Inne awhile this Iohn þe clerk vp leep
And on this gode wyff he leithe on sore
So meri a fitte ne had she not full yore
He prikkith harde and depe as he were madde
This Ioly liff these two clerkis ladde
Til that þe iij cok be gan to synge
Aleyn wax weri in the dawnynge
For he had swonke alle þe longe nyȝt
And seide fare well maleyn my swete wyȝt
The day is come I may no lenger bide
But euer mo wher so y go or ryde
I am thyn owne clerc so haue y hele
Now dere lemman ꝙquod she go fare wele
But or thow goo o thyng y wolle þe telle
Whanne thow wendest homward by þe melle
Ryȝt att þe entre of þe dore be hynde
Thou shalt a cake of half a bushel fynde
That was y maked of þyn owne mele
Whiche that y helpe my sire for to stele
And good lemman god þe saue and kepe
And with that word almost she gan to wepe
Aleyn vprist and thouȝt or it dawe
I will go krepen in by my felawe
And fond þe cᵃradel with his hond anon̄
By god thouȝt he all wrong I haue mysgon̄
Myn hed is toti of my swynk tonyȝt
That makith me y go not aryȝt
I wot wel by the cᵃradil y haue mysgo
Here lyth the millere and his wyf also
And forth he goth in twynti deuell wey
Vn to þe bed there as the miller͗e lay
He wende haue cropen in by his felaw Iohn
And by the millere in he crepe anon̄
And cauȝte him by þe nekke and softe spak
He seide thou swynes hedswynesswynes hed þou Iohn a wake
For cristes soule and here a noble game
For by that lord that called is seynt Iame
As y haue thries in this shorte nyȝt
Swyued the millers dowȝtir bolt vp riyȝt
While thow hast as a Coward ben agast
Ye fals harlot ꝙquod the miller͗e hast
Fals traitᵒor fals Clerk ꝙquod he
Thou shalt be ded bi goddes dignite
Who durst be so bold to disꝑparage
My douȝtir that is Come of suche linage
And bi the throte bolle he cauȝte aleyn
And he hente him dispitously ageyn̄
And on the nose he smote him with his fest
Doun̄ Ran the blod strem vp on hys brest
And in the flore with mouth and nose to broke
They walwe as don two pigges in apoke
And doun̄ they gon̄ and vp ageyn anon̄
Til that the miller͗e spurned at a ston̄
And doun̄ he fel bakward vp on̄ his wyf
That wiste nothing of all this nyce striff
For she was falle a slepe a litil wyȝt
With Iohn the Clerk that waked had al nyȝt
And with the falle out of hir sleep she braide
Help holy Cros of bromholm she seide
In manus tuas lord to þe y calle
Awake symond thee fend ys on me falle
Myn herte is broke help I am but ded
There lith on vp on my wombe and anothur on myn hed
Helpe symkyn for the fals Clerkis fiȝte
This Iohn sterte vp as fast as euer he myȝte
And grasped by the walles to and froo
To fynde a staff / and she sterte vp also
And knewe the Estrees beet thānne Iohn
And by the walle a staff she fond anon̄
And saw a litil shinerynge of alyȝt
For att an hole in shon þe mone bryȝt
And by that lyȝt she saw hem bothe two
But sekerly she nyste who was wh
But as she saw a whit thyng in hir eye
And whanne she gan this white thing to aspie
She wende the clerk had wered a voluper
And with the staff she drow ner and ner
And wende haue hit this aleyn att fulle
And smot the miller vp on the sculle
That doun̄ he goth and Crieth harow I dye
These Clerkes bett him well and lett him lye
And greyden hem an toke hir hors anon̄
And eke hir mele and on hir wey they gon
And att mille ȝit they toke hir Cake
Off half abushell flour͗e full wel y bake
Thus is þe proud millere wel y bete
And hath y lost þe gryndynge of þe whete
And hath payed for þe soper eủery dele
Off aleyn and of Iohn that bete him wel
His wif is swyed and his douȝtir als
Lo wheche it is a myller͗e to be fals
And therfor͗e this prouerbe is seith ful soth
He dar not wene well that yuel doth
A giler shall hym self bigiled be
And god that sitt hiȝe a boue in magiste
Saue alle this compaignye gret and smale
Thus haue y quytte the millere in my tale

div.note: The ꝓprolog͗e of þᵉ Cook
div.l: The cook of london̄ while the reue spak
For Ioye him thouȝte he clawed him on his bak
Ha ha for cristes passion̄
This miller͗e hath a sharp conclusion
Vp on his argument of herbigage
Wel saide salamon in his langage
Ne brynge not eủery man in to þyn hous
For herborwynge benight is ꝑperilous
Wel ouȝt a man auysed for to be
Whom that he brouȝte in his priuite
I pᵃray to god so graunte me sorwe and car͗e
Ȝef euer sith I hiȝt hogge of war͗e
Herde y amiller͗e better set a worke
He hath a Iape of malice in þe derke
div.note: "leaf out" in modern hand

div.fw: The ꝓprolog͗e of the Man of Lawe
div.l: And for there is no theef with outen a lowk
That helpeth hym to waste and to sowk
Of that he bribe can or borwe may
Anon he sente his bed and his array
Vn to a cowper of his owen sort
That loued dice and reuel and disport
And had a wyff that held for countenaunce
A shoppe and swyued for hir sustenaunce
Owre oost saw wel that the sonne
The ark of his artificiall hath ronne
The fourthe part and half an houre ⁊and more
And thow he were not depe isterte in lore
He wiste it was the xviij day
Of appril that is messanger to may
And sawe well that þe shadwe of eueri tree
Was as in lengthe the same quantite
What was the body erect that causid hit
And therfore by þe shadwe he toke his witt
That Phebus that shon so bryȝt
Degrees was fyue and xlti clombe on hiȝt
And for that day as in that latitude
Hit was x of cloke he gan conclude
And sodeinli he pliȝt his hors abouȝte
Lordynges qd he y warne yow all this route
The iiij partie of this day is gon
Now for the loue of god and of seynt Iohn
Lesith no tyme as ferthermore as ȝe may
Lordinges the tyme it wastith niȝt and day
And stelith from vs priuili slepinge
And what thoruȝ necligence in oure walkynge
As doth the streem that tornyth neuer ageyn
Descendynge frōmm the mountayn into þe playn
Wel can senec and many a philisophir
By waylen tyme more thane golde in cophir
For loss of catel may recouered be
But loss of tyme shendith vs qd he
Hit wol not come ageyn with outen drede
Nomore thanne wolde malkennes maidenhed
Whānne she hath loste it in hir wantownnesse
Sere man of qd he so haue y blesse
The time passith faste Ser y wis
Sheis vs a tale anōnn as forward is
Ye ben submittid thoruȝ your fre assent
To stonden in this caas at my Iugement
Aquyteth yow of your beheste
Thānne haue ye don your deuer atte leste
Oost qd he depardux ich assente
To breke forward is nouȝt myn entent
Biheste is dette and y woll holde fayn
Al myn beheste y can not better sayn
For suche lawe as aman yeueth an othur wiȝt
He shulde him self vsen hit bi ryȝt
This woll our tixt but natheles certeyn
I can ryȝt now no thrifti tale seyn
That chauncer thowȝ he can but lewedli
On metres an on rymynge crafteli
Hath seide in suche englissh as he can
Of olde tyme as knowith many aman
And ief he haue not seid hem leue brothur
In o book he seide hem in an othur
For he hath told of louers vp and doun
More thanne Ouide made of mencioıı̄un
In his episteles that ben ful olde
What shulde y tellen hem syth they ben told
In yonghe he made of ceys and alicone
And sith hath spak of euerichone
These noble wyues and þese louers eke
Who so that wolde his large volumes seke
Cleped þe seyntes legende of cupide

div.l: (base) Here bygynneth the Somnours tale
(base) Et incipit fabula
(base) LOrdynges ther is in Yorkshire as I gesse
(base) A Merssh contree called holdernesse
(base) In which ther wente a lymytour aboute
(base) To preche and eek to begge it is no doute
(base) And so bifel that on a day this frere

(base) And specially abouen euery thyng

(base) And wroot the names alwey as he stood

Oure sistir dere lo here write I ȝour̉e name

And what men ȝeue hem he leide it on his bak
And whan̄ne he was out at þe dore anon̄
He planyd awey þe names eủerychon
That he be forn̄e hadde writenwritenhadde writen in his tablis

Nay þer þou lixt now sompnoʳur quod þe frere

Telle forth þi tale ⁊and spare it not at al
So þryue I quod this somnoʳur so I shall
So longe he wente from hous to hous til he
Cam to an hous þere he was wont to be
Refresshid more þan in an hundrid placis
Syk lay þe bond man whos þe place is
Bedered vp on a couche lowe he lay
Deus hic quod he / o Thomᵃas frend good day
Seide this frere curtisli and softe
Thomᵃas quod he god ȝelde it þᵉe ful ofte
I haue on þis benche faren ful weel
Here haue I feten ful many ameri meel
And from þe benche he drof a wey þe cat
And leide adoıı̄un his potent and his hat
And eke his scripe and sette him softe adoıı̄un
His felawe was walkid in to þe toun
For with his knaye in that hostelerie
Whẻre as he shepe him þilke nyȝt to lie
O der̉e maistir quod þis sike man
How haue ȝe fare siþ marche bigan
I siȝ ȝou not this xiiii nyȝt and more
God wot quod he laborid haue I ful sore
And speciali to þin saluacioıı̄un
Haue I seid many aprecious orisoıı̄un
And for oure oþer frendis god hem blesse
I haue to day ben at ȝour̉e churche at messe
And seide a sermon to my symple witt
Not al aftir þe tixt of holy writt
For it is haʳrd to ȝou as I suppose
And þerfor̉e wole I telle ȝow al þe glose
Glosing is a ful fayr̉e thing certein
For þe letter̉e sleep as clerkis seien
There haue I tauȝt hem to be charitable
And spende heer good þere it is resonable
And þer I siȝ our̉e dame a wher̉e is she
Ȝondir in þe yerde I trowe þat she be
Seide this man and she wole come anōon
Ey maistir welcome be ȝe bi seint Ioon
Seide this wiff how fare ȝe hertli
This frere arisiþ vp ful curteisly
And hir enbrasid in his armes narwe
And kissit hir swete ⁊and chirkiþ as asparwe
Wiþ his lyppis / dame quod he riȝt wel
As he þat is ȝour̉e seruaunt eủerydeel
Þankid be god be god þat ȝaf soule and lyf
Ȝit say I not to day so faire a wyf
In all þe chirche so god saue me
Ȝhe god amende þe fautis good sire qᵈuod she
Algatis weclome be ȝe bi my fay
Graıı̄unt merci dame þis haue I foıı̄unden alway
But of ȝour̉e gret goodnes by ȝoure leue
I wol pʳray ȝow þat ȝe not ȝou grene
I wolde wiþ Thomᵃas speke a litil þrowe
These curates ben so necligent and so slowe
To gropen tendirli a concience
In shrifte in prechinge is my diligence
And stodie in petirs wordis and in poulis
I walke and clense mens soulis
To ȝelde ihūihesu crist hys propir rent
To spede his word is al myn entente
Now bi ȝour̉e leue dere sire quod she
Chidiþ him wel for seint charite
He is euer angeri as a pismere
Thouȝ that he haue al þat he can desire
Thouȝ I him wrie al nyȝt and make him warm̄
And ouer him leie my legge and eke myn arm̄
He gronyþ lik our̉e bore in our̉e stiȝ
Oþir disport of him riȝt nōon haue I
I \may/ notnotmay not plese him in nomaner caas
O thomᵃas ie vous di thomᵃas tomas
This makith þe fend þis must ben amended
Ire is athing he god gretli defendid
And of that wol I speke aword or two
Now maistir quod þe wyf or þat I go
What wol ȝe dyne I wol \go/ þerþergo þer aboute
Now dame quod he now ie vous di saunȝ doute
Thouȝ I haue no more of a capon but þe lyủere
And of ȝour̉e whit bred but ashyuere
And aftir þat arostid piggis hed
But þat I wolde for me no beste were ded
Thanne hadde I with ȝow hoomli sufficiaunce
I am aman of litil sustinaıı̄unce
My spirit hath his fostering in þe beble
Mi bodi is ay so redi and so penyble
To wake that my stomak is distroyed
I pray ȝou same that ȝe be not anoied
Thouȝ I so frendli ȝou my councel schewe
Bi god I nolde haue toold it but a fewe
Now sire quod she but a word or I goo
Michild is ded with ynne þese wokis two
Sone aftir þat ȝe wente out of þis town̄
His deþ say I bi Reuelacioıı̄un
Seide this frere / at hom in our̉e dortour̉e
I dar wel seien or þat half an houre
Aftir his deth I say him born̄e to blis
In myn visioıı̄un so god me wis
So dide oure sektem̄e and our̉e fermerer
That han ben trewe freris fifti ȝere
Thei mowen now god be þankid of his lone
Maken hir iubile and walken alone
And vp I Roos and all oure couent eke
Wiþ many atere trillynge on my cheke
Wiþ outen noyse and clateringe of bellis
Te deum was oure song and noþing ellis
Saue aftir to crist I bad an orisoıı̄un
Thankyng him þan of my reuelacioıı̄un
For sire and dame tristith me riȝt weel
Oure orisoıı̄uns ben more effectuel
And more we sēen of cristis secrete þingꝭes
Than borel folk al þouȝ that thei ben kingis
We lyuen in pouert and \in/ abstinenceabstinencein abstinence
And borel folk in richesse and dispense
Of mete and drinke and hir foul delite
We haue þeise worldis lustis al in dispite
Laser and dyues lyueden diuersly
And diuerce goủernaunce hadden þer bi
Who so wole pray he muste faste and be clene
And fatte his soule and make his bodi lene
We fare as seiþ þe apostil cloth and fode
Suffisiþ vs þouȝ þei be not ful gode
Þe clennes and þe fastinge of vs freris
Makith þat crist acceptiþ oure praiers
Lo moyses xl daies and fourti nyȝt
Fastid or þat god ful or miȝt
Spak with him in þe mount of synay
Wiþ empti wombe of fastinge many aday
There resceyuede he þe lawe þat was writen
Wiþ goddis fynger and ely wel ȝe witen
In mount oreb or he had ony speche
With hiȝe god þat is our̉e lyues leche
He fastid longe and was in contemplaıı̄unce
Aaron that hadde þe temple in gouernaunce
And eke þe oþer prestis eủerychon
In to þe temple whane þei shulde goon̄
To prayen for þe peple and do seruice
Thei nolde drinken in no maner wise
Ne drinke swich þat miȝte him dronke make
But þer in abstinence pʳreie and wake
Lest þat thei diden take hide what I seie
But thei be sobre that for þe peple preie
Ware þat I sei nomore for it suffisiþ
Oure lord ihūihesu as holi writt deuysiþ
Ȝaf vs ensamnple of fastīnge and preiers
Therfore we mendināntis we seli freris
Ben weddid to pouerti and to continence
To charite homblesse and to concience
To persecusioıı̄un for riȝtwissnes
To wepinge to misericorde and clen̄nes
And þerfore mowe ȝe se þat oure pʳreiers
I speke of vs we mendenaıı̄untis we freris
Ben to þe hiȝ god more acceptable
Þan ȝours wiþ ȝoure festis at þe table
Fro paradys first if I shal not lie
Was man out of chasid for his glotenye
And chaast was man in paradis certeine
But herkene now thomᵃas what I shal seien
I haue no tixt of it as I suppose
But I shal fynde in amaner glose
That speciali our̉e swete lord iħcihesu
Spak this bi freris whan̄ne he seide þus
Blessed be þei that pore in spirit ben
And so forþ al þe gospel may ȝe seen
Wheþ̉er it be lyk oure proffessioıı̄un
Or hern þat swommēn in possessioıı̄un
Fy on hir pompe and on hir glotenye
And of hir lewdenesse I hem diffie
Me þenkith þei ben lyk to tanynþan
Fat as awhal and walken as a swan
Al viuolent as abotel in þe spence
In her preier is ful gret reuerence
Whan þei for soulis seien þe psalme of dauid
Lo buf þei seien . Cor . meūm eructauit
Who folwiþ cristis gospel ⁊and herfore
But we þat humble beth chast and pore

div.l: (base) Werkers of goddes word nat Auditours
