As for ȝoure trouþe ⁊and ȝoure obeisaunce
Nauȝt for ȝour lynage ne for ȝour richesse
But now knowe I in very soþfastnesse
That in gret lordschip Ief I me wel auyse
Ther is gret seruitute in sundri wise
I may not don as eủery plow man may
¶My peple constreyneþ me to take
Anoþ̉er wyf and crien day bi day
And eeke þe pope rancour for to slake
Consentith it þat dar I vndertake
And treuly þus myche wol I ȝow sey
My new wif is comynge bi þe wey
¶Be strong of herte and voide anon hir place
And þilke dower þat ȝe brouȝte me
Take it agein I gᵃunte of my grace
Returneþ to ȝour fadirȝ hous quod he
No man may alwey haue prosꝑperite
Wiþ euene herte I rede ȝou to endure
The strook of fortune or of auentur
¶And sche ageyn answerde in pacience
My lord quod sche I woot and wiste alwey
How þat betwene ȝour magnificence
And my poủert no wiȝt ne can ne may
Maken conꝑperison it is no nay
I helde me neuer digne in nomaner
To ben ȝour wyf ne ȝoure chāmberere
¶And in þis hous þer ȝe me ladi made
Þe hiȝe god I take for my witnesse
And also he willi my soule glade
I neue helde me ladi ne maisteresse
But humble ʆseruaunt to ȝoᵘure worþinesse
And eue shall while þat my lyf may dur
Aboue eủery worldly creatur
¶That ȝe so longe of ȝoure benignite
Han holden me in honour and nobeley
Where as I was not worþi for to be
Þat þanke I god and ȝou for whom I pᵃy
To ȝilde it ȝow þer is nomor to sey
Vn to my fadir gladly wol I wende
And with him dwelle vn to my lyues ende
¶Þer I was fostrid of a child ful smal
Til I be ded my lif þer wole I lede
A widowe clene in body herte and all
Forsoþe I ȝaf to yow my meydenhede
And am ȝour trewe wif it is no drede
God schilde siche a lordis wyf to take
Anoþ̉er man to husbond or to make
And of ȝour ⁊andabsent:newenewewyf god of his gᵃce
So gᵃunte ȝow welþe and prosꝑperite
For I wole gladly ȝilden hir my place
In whiche þat I was blisful for to be
For siþen it likiþ ȝou my lord quod sche
Þat sumtyme weren al myn hertis rest
Þat I shal gon I wole gon whan ȝow list
¶But þer as ȝe me profre siche dowaire
As I first brouȝt it is wel in my mynde
It were my wreched cloþis noþing faire
Þe whiche to me wer hard for to fynde
A goode god how gentil and how kynde
Ȝe semed bi ȝour speche ⁊and ȝoure visage The Clerk
The day þat makid was our mariage
¶But soþ it is seid algate I fynde it trewe
For in affect it preued so is bi me
Loue is not hoot as whan þat it is newe
But certis lord for non aduersite
To die in þis caas it shal not be
þat eue in word or werk I shal repent
Þat I ȝou ȝaf myn herte in hole entent
¶My lord ȝe wote þat in my fadirs place
Ȝedede me strippe out of my pore wede
And richely ȝe clodid me of ȝour gᵃce
To ȝou brouȝte I not ell out of drede
But filthe and nakednesse and maidenhede
And here ageyn my cloþinge I restore
And eke my weddinge ryng foreneumor
¶Þe remenant of ȝour iewell redi be
Wiþ Inne ȝour chaumbre I dar ȝou it safly sayn
Nakid out of my fadirs hous quod she
I cam and naked I mote turne ageyn
All ȝour plesaunce wolde I folwe feyn
But ȝit I hope it be not ȝour entent
Þat I smokles out of ȝour paleis went
¶Ȝe coude not do so dishonest aþing
That þilke Wombe whiche ȝour childeren lay
Shulde before þe peple in my walkyng
Be seyn albare wherfore I ȝow pᵃy
Lete me not like aworme go by þe wey
Remembre ȝow myn owne lord so dere
I was ȝour wyf þouȝ I vnworþy were
¶Wherfore in honour of my meidenhede
Whiche þat I brouȝte a nouȝt aȝen bere
As vouchesaaf to ȝeue me to my mede
But suche asmok as I was wont to were
Þat I derwiþ may wrie þe wombe of heer
That was ȝour wiff and her I take my leue
Of ȝou myn owne lord lest I ȝow greue
¶The smok quod he þat þou hast on þi bak
Lete it be stille and ber it forth with þe
But wel vnneþis þilke word he spak
But wente his wey for reuþe and pite
Beforn þe folk hir siluen strippiþ she
And in hir smok wiþ fote and hed all bare
Toward hir fadir hous is she fare
¶The folk hir folewen wepynge in hir wey
And fortune ay þei cursen as þey gon
But she fro wepynge kepith hir eȝen drie
In þis tyme word ne spak she non
Hir fadir þis tidynge herde anon
Curside þe day and þe tyme þat natur
Schope him to be alyues creatur
¶For wiþouten doute þis olde pore man
Was eue in suspect of hir mariage
For eue he demede siþ þat it bigan
That Whan̄n þe lord fulfillid had his corage
Him wolde þenke it were a disꝑperage
So lowe for his astate to lyȝt
And voiden hir as sone as he eue myȝt
¶Aȝens his douȝtir hastly gooþ he
For he bi voice of folk knewe hir comynge
And wiþ hir oolde cote as it myȝt be
He keuede hir ful sorfully wepynge
But on hir body myȝte he it not brynge
For rude was þe cloþ and she more of age
By daies fele þan att hir mariage
¶Thus wiþ hir fadir for a certeine space
Dwellyth þis flour of wilfly pacience
Þat neiþer bi hir wordys ne hir face
Beforn þe folk ne eke in hir absence
Ne shewid sche þat hir was doon offence
Ne of hir astate no rememburance
Ne hadde she as bi hir contenanc̄etce
¶No wondir is for in hir grete astate
Hir goost was eue in pleyn humilite
No tendir mouþ non hertte delicate
No pompe no sembulaunt of rialte
But ful of pacient benygnyte The Clerk
Discrete and prideles ay honourable
And to hir husbond ay meke and stable
¶Men speke of iob and most for hir humblesse
As clerkis whan him liste coude wel endite
Namely of men but as in soþfastnesse
Þouȝ clerkis pise women but alite
Þer can noman in humilnes him aquite
As women can ne can be half so trewe
As women ben but ⁊andabsentitit bifalle of newe
¶Fro boloigne is þis eerl of pauyk come
Of whiche þe fame vp sprong and les
And in þe peplis eeris al and sume
Was eeke þat a newe markesse
He wiþ him brouȝte in siche pompe and richesse
That neue was þer seyn wiþ mans iȝe
So noble aray in al west lumberdie
¶That markis whiche þat shope and knew al þis
Or þat þis eerl was come sent his message
For þilke seli pore grisildis
And sche wiþ humble herte ⁊and glad visage
Wiþ no swollen þouȝ in hir corage
Cam att his heste and on hir knees hir sette
And reuently and wisly sche him grette
¶Grisilde quod he my wil is entelry
Þis maiden þat shalt wedded be to me
Resceyued be to morwe as rially
As it possible is in myn hous to be
And eke þat eủery wiȝt in his degre
Haue his astate in sittynge and in seruyce
And in hiȝ plesaunce as I can best deuise
¶I haue no woman sufficient certeyn
Þe chaubris to araye in ordinance
Aftir my lust and þerfor wolde yfeyn
That þin were al siche mane gouernaunce
Thow knowest eke of oold all my plesaunce
Þouȝ þin aray be bad ⁊and euel be seye
Do þou þy deuer at þe leste wey.
¶Not oonly lord þat I am glad quod she
To do ȝour lust but I desir also
Ȝou for to ʆserue and plese in my degre
Wiþ outen feynynge and shull eủermo
Ne neue for no wele ne no wo
Ne shal þe gost wiþ Inne myn herte stent
To loue ȝou best wiþ all my trewe entent
¶And wiþ þat word she gan þe hous to diȝte
And tablis for to sette and beddis make
And peyned hir to don all þat she myȝt
Preiynge þe chaıı̄unberers for goddis sake
To hasten hem and faste swepe and schake
And sche þe moste seruiceable of alle
Hath eủery chaumbre araied and his halle
¶Aboute þe vnderne gan þe eerl aliȝt
Þat wiþ him brouȝte þis noble childeren tweye
For whiche þe peple ran to se þat siȝt
Of hir araie so richeli biseie
And þan at arst amongis hem þei seid
Þat Walter was no fole þouȝ þat hīm lest
To chaunge his wyf it was for þe best
¶For sche is fairer as þei demēn alle
Þan is grisilde and more tendre of age
And fairer fruȝt betwene hēm shuld falle
And more plesaıı̄unt for hir hiȝ lynage
Hir broþer eek so faire was of visage
þat hym to seen þe peple hath cauȝt plesaunce
Comendynge now þe markis gouenaunce
¶Oȝe sturdi peple vnsad and eủer vntrewe
Ay vndescreet and chaungīnge as a fane
Delyange eue in rumble þat is newe
For like þe mone ay wexen ȝe ⁊and wane
Ay ful of clappynge dere I nowȝ a vrane
Ȝour doom is fals ȝoure constience euel pueþ
A ful gret fool is he þat on ȝow leueþ
¶Þus seide sad folk in þat Cite
Whane þat þe peple gaside vp and doıı̄unn
For þey wer glad for þe nouelte The Clerk
To haue a new ladi of hir toun
Nomore of þis make I now mencion
But to grisilde ageyn I wol me dresse
And telle hir constaunce and hir besinesse
¶Ful besy was grisilde in eủery þyng
That to þe feste was ꝑpartinent
Riȝt nouȝt was she abaischid of hir cloþing
þouȝ it were rude and sumdel rent
But wiþ glad cher to þe ȝate is she went
Wiþ oþer folk to grete þe markeisse
And aftir þat dooþ forþ hir besinesse
¶Wiþ so glad cher hise gestis she resceyued
And so kunyngly eủerych in his degree
Þat no de faute noman ꝑperceyued
But ay þey wondren what she be
Þat in so pore aray was for to se
And coude siche honoᵘur and reuerence
And wondirli þey preisen hir pʳdence
¶In all þis mene while she ne stint
Þis maide ⁊andabsent:andand hir broþ̉er to comende
Wiþ al hir herte wiþ ful benygne entent
So wel þat noman coude hir price amende
But att þe laste whane þese lordis wende
To sitte doun to mete he gan to calle
Grisilde as sche was bisy in þe halle
¶Grisilde quod he as it were in his play
How likiþ þe my Wif and hir beute
Riȝt weel my lord quod she for in good fay
A fairer siȝ I neuer noon þan sche
I pᵃy to god ȝeue hir prosꝑperite
And so hope I that he woll to ȝou sende
Plesaunce I nouȝ vn to ȝoure lyues ende
¶ Oþing I beseke ȝou and warne also
That ȝe ne pue wiþ no turmentynge
This tendre maide as ȝe haue do mo
For she is fostrid in hir norishynge
More tenderly and to my suposinge
Sche coude not aduersite endure
As coude apore fostrid creatur
¶And whane þis walter say hir pacience
Hir glad chere and nomalice at all
And he so offte hadde doon to hir offence
And sche ay sad and constant as awal
Contemynge euer hir ynocence oủer all
Þis sturdi markis gan his herte redresse
To rewe vp on hir wifly stidfastnesse
¶Þis is ynouȝ grisilde myn quod he
Be now nomore agast ne euel apayed
I haue þy feith and þi benyngite
As wel as eue woman was asaied
In gret astate and porely araied
Now knowe I dere wyf þi stidfastnes
And hir in armes took and gan hir kis
¶And she for wonder of it took no kepe
She herde not what þing to hir ⁊andabsent:hehe seide
She ferde as she had stert out of aslepe
Til she out of hir maisdnesse obreide
Grisilde quod he bigod þat for vs deide
Þou art my wyf non oþer I haue
Ne neue I hadde as god my soule saue
¶Þis is þi douȝtir whiche þou hast supposid
To be my wyf þat oþer feiþfully
Shal ben myn aier as I haue ay disposid
Þou bare him in þi bodi treuly
Att boloigne haue I kept hem pduely
Take hem ageyn for now maist þᵘ not seie
That þou hast lorn non of þi childeren tweye
And folk þat oþir wise han seid of me
¶I warne hem wel þat I haue don þis dede
For no malice ne for no cruelte
But for to asaye in þe þe Womanhed
And not to sle my childeren god forbed
But for to kepe hem pduyli and stille
Til I þi purpos knew and all þi wille
¶Whan she þis herde oıı̄un swon doon she falliþ
For piteuos ioie and aftir hir swownynge The Clerk
She boþe hir childeren ȝoug vn to hir calliþ
And in hir armes piteuously wepinge
Embrassinge hem and tendirly kyssyngge
Ful lyk a moder wiþ hir salt teris
She baþid boþe hir visage ⁊and hir heeris
¶O whiche a petuous þing it was to se
Hir swounynge and her humble voice to here
Graunt mercy lord god þanke it ȝow quod she
Now recke I neuer to be ded riȝt her
¶Siþen I stonde in ȝour loue and gᵃce
No force of deeþ ne whane my spirit pace
¶O tendre o dere o ȝong childeren myn
Ȝour woful moder wende stidfastly
Þat cruel houndis or oủer foul venym
Had eten ȝow but god of his mercy
And ȝour benigne fadir tenderly
Hath don ȝow kepe and in þat same stounde
Al sodeynly she fil adon to grounde
¶And in hir swoȝ so sadly holdiþ she
Hir childeren two whan she gan hem enbrace
Þat wiþ gret sleȝte and gret difficulte
Þe childeren from hir arme þei gonne race
O many ateere many a piteuous pace
Doun ran of hem þat stoden hir biside
Vnneþ a boute hir myȝte þei abide
¶Waltir hir gladiþ and hir sorwe slakiþ
She risiþ vp abaischid from hir traunce
And eủery wiȝt hir ioie and feste makiþ
Til sche hath cauȝt ageyn hir countenaunce
Walter hir dooþ so feiþfully plesaunce
That it was deynte for to se hir chere
Betwene hem two siþen þey ben met in fer
¶These ladies whan þat þei hir tyme say
Han taken hir and in to chaumbre goon
And strepen out hir of hir rude aray
And in a cloþ of gold þat briȝt shon
Wiþ a corowne of many a riche ston
Vp on her hed and þey in þe halle hir brouȝte
And there she was honourid as hir ouȝte
¶Thus haþ þis piteuous day a blisfull ende
For eủery man and woman dooþ his myȝt
Þis day in merthe and reuel to spende
Til on þe welkene schon þe sterrs liȝt
For more solempne in eủery mans siȝt
This feste was and gretter of costage
Þan was þe reuel of hir mariage
Ful many aȝere in hiȝ prosꝑperite
Leuen þese iI in concord and in reste
And richely his douȝtir maried he
Vn to a lord on of þe worþieste
Of all ytale and þan in pees and reste
His wyues fadir in his court he kepiþ
Til þat þe soule out of his body crepeþ
¶His sone succedit in his eritage
In reste and pees aftir his fadir day
And fortunat was eke in mariage
Al put he not his wyf in gret asay
This world is not so stronge it is no nay
As it hath ben in olde tymes ȝore
And herkiþ what þis autour seiþ þ̉erfore
¶Þis storie is seid not for þat wyues shulde
Folwe grisilde as in humilite
For it wer in portable þouȝ þei wolde
But for þat eủery whyȝt in his degre
Shulde be constānt in aduersite
As was grisilde þerfor petrak writith
Þis storie whiche wiþ hiȝ still he enditith
¶For siþen a woman was so pacient
Vn to amortal man wel more ouȝte
Resceyuen al in gree þat god vs sent
For gret skill is he pue þat he wrouȝte
But he ne temptiþ no man þat he bouȝte
As seith seynt iame if he his pistill rede
He preuyd folk al day it is no drede
¶And suffriþ vs as for oure excercise
Wiþ scharpe scorgis and aduersite The Clerk of Oxenford
Ful ofte to be bete in sundri wise
Not for to knowe our͗e wille for certis he
Or we weren born̄ knew aƚƚ oure freelte
And for our͗e beste is al our͗e gouernaunce
Lete vs þane leue in v̉ertuous sufficiaıı̄unce
¶ O word lordingis herkene or I go
It were ful hard to fynde now adaies
In al atown̄ grisildis iij or two
For if þat þey wer͗e put to suche asaies
Þe gold of hem haþ now so bad laies
Wiþ bras þat þouȝ þe coyne be faire at iȝe
It wol raþer breke atwo þan plie
¶ For whiche here / for þe wyues loue of baþe
Whos lijf and aƚƚ hir sett god mayntene
In maistrie and eƚƚlles wer͗e it scaþe
I wol wiþ lusty herte fressħ and grene
Seie ȝou a songe to glade ȝou I wene
And lete vs stinte of ernestful mater͗e
Herkenyþ my song þat seiþ in þis manere
div.note: Songe

div.l: GRisilde is ded and eke hir pacience
And boþe att onys beried in ytaile
For whiche I crie in open audience
No wedded man so hard to be assaile
His wyues paciens in trust to fynde
Grisildis two two For certein he shall faile
O noble wyues ful of hiȝ pʳudence
Lete non̄ humilite ȝour͗e tongis naile
Ne lete no clerk haue cause no diligence
To write a storie of ȝou of suche mervaile
As of grisilde pacient and kynde
Lest chechiuache ȝou swolwe / in hir entᵃrayle
Folwiþ ekko þat holdiþ no silence
But euere answeriþ att þe contretaile
Beþ not bidaffid for ȝoure ynocence
But scharpely take on ȝow þe gouernaile
Enp̉rentiþ wel þis lesson̄ in ȝour͗e mynde
For comyn profit siþēn it may auaile
Ȝe archewyues ston͒diþ att diffence
Sithen ȝe ben strong as is a gret camaile
Ne suffriþ not þat men ȝou do offence
And sklendre wyues feble as in bateile
Beth egre as ategre is biȝonde in ynde
Euer clappiþ as a mille I ȝou conceile
Ne drede him not doþ him no reủerence
For þouȝ þin husbond armed in maile
Þe arowis of þi crabbid eloquence
Shal persche persche perse his brest ⁊and eek his ventaile
In ielosie I rede eke þou him binde
And þou shalt make him couche as a qwayle
If þou ben faire þer folk ben̄ in presence
Shew þou þi visage and þin apparaile
Ief þou be foul be fre of þi dispence
To gete þe frendis ay do þi tᵃrauaile
Be ay of chere as lyȝt as leef on lynde
And lete him care wepe wrynge and weile
Now is endid þe clerkis tale of oxenford

And now
Biginneth þe prolog of the frankelens tale
THis worþi clerk whan̄e endid was his tale
div.note: heer sholde þe marchanz tale
div.l: Oure ost seide and swore bi goddis bonys
Me were leủere þan a bareƚƚ of ale
My wif at hom̄ had herd þis legende onys
div.note:
And þis ꝓprolog is fals for it is
for þe skquiers tale
div.l: This is agentil tale for þe nonys
As to my purpos wiste ȝe my wille
But þing þat wol not be lete it be stille
div.note: Sir frankƚleyn
Þis longeth

l.seg: Sir͗e frankleyn skquier frankleyn skquier com n̉er if yoᵘur wille bee
And sey vs atale for c̉ertes yee .
Konnen þ̉eron as mocħ as eny man .
Nay sir qduod he but I wol sey as I kan
Wᵗith h̄erty wolle for I wol nat rebelle .
Ageyns yoᵘur wiƚƚ / a tale wol I telle
Haue me excused yif þᵗat I speke amys
My wil is good ⁊and lo my tale is thys

div.l: THise olde gentil briton̄s in hir daies
Off dyuers auenturs maden layes
Remeued in hir firste breton̄ ton̄ge
Whiche layes with hir ynstrumentis þey sıı̄un
div.note: The final word, presumably sıı̄ung, is cut off by the margin.
div.l: Or ells reden hem for hir plesaunce
And oon of hem haue I in Remembraıı̄unce
Whiche I shal seien wiþ good wille as I can
But seris because I am a burel man
At my begynnȳnge first I ȝou beseche
div.note: At Sarray on þe londe of Tartrie
div.l: I haue me excusid of my rude speche
I lerned neuer Rotorik certein
Þing þat I speke mote be bare and pleyn̄
I lened lened neuer on the moıı̄unt of parnaso
Ne lerned neủere markus tullius sithero
Colours ne knewe I non̄ with outen doute or drede
But suche colouris as growen in þe mede
Or eƚƚ suche as men die or peynte
Colouris of Retorik ben to me qweynte
My spirit feliþ not of suche matere
But if ȝe lust my tale shul ȝe here
IN armorik þat callyd is breteyne
Þer was a knyȝt þat louede and dede his peyne
To serue a ladi in his best wise
And many a labour many greet empⁱrise
He for his ladi wroghte wrouȝte or sche wer͗e wonne
For sche was on þe fairist vnder sōnne
And þerto come of so hiȝ kynrede
Þat well vneþis durste þis knyȝt for drede
Telle hir his woo his peyne and his distresse
But at laste sche for his worþinesse
And namely for his meke obeischaun̄ce
Haþ siche a pite cauȝt of his pennaun̄ce
Þat pⁱriuely sche fel at his acord
To take him for hir husbond and hir lord
Of siche lordschip as men han of hir wyues
And for to lede þe more in in blis her lyues
Of his fre wil he swor hir as a knyȝt
That neủere in al his lijf he day ne nyȝt
Ne schulde vp on̄ him take no no maisterie
Aȝen hir will ne kithe hir Ielosie
But hir obeye and folwe hir wil in al
As ony louer to his ladi schaƚƚ
Saue þat þe name of suereⁱnte
That wolde he haue for shame of his degre
She þankid hīm and wiþ ful gret hūmblenes
She seide sire siþen of ȝoure gentilnes
Ȝe profre me to haue so large a Reyne
Ne wolde neủere god betwix vs tweyne
As in my gilt were oiþ̉er werre or strijf
Sere I woƚƚ be ȝoure humble trewe wijf
Haue here my trouþe til þat my herte brest
Þus be þei boþe in quiete and in Rest
For oþing seris seris ser daar I sauffly seie
Þat frendis ecche oþer most obeie
If þei wol longe holde cūmpanys
Loue woll not be streyned bi maistⁱrie
Whan̄e maistⁱrie comeþ god of loue anoon̄
Betith his wynge and fare weƚƚ he is goon̄
Loue is aþing as ony spirit fre
Women of kynde desiren liberte
And not to be constreyned as a þraƚƚ
And so don men ȝif I soþe seien schaƚƚ
Loke who þat most is pacient in loue
He is att his auantāge al aboue
Pacience is an hiȝ vertu certeyn
For it vencusiþ all as þese clerkis seyn̄
Þingis þat regour schuld neủere atteyne
For att eủery word men may not chide and pleyne
Lerneþ to suffre or eƚƚ so mote I gon̄
Ȝe schulle ȝit lerne ȝif ȝe wolle or non̄
For in þis world certeyn þer no whiȝt is
That he ne dooþ ner seiþ somtyme amys
Ire siknes or constillacioıı̄un
Wyn woo or chaungēnge of complexcioıı̄un
Causiþ full ofte to don amys or spekēn
On eủery wrong aman not be wreken
Afftir þe tyme mote ben temꝑperaunce
To eủery wiȝt þat can ony gouernaunce
And þerfore hath þis wise worþy knyȝt
To lyue in ese sufferaun̄ce hir behiȝt
And sche to him fuƚƚ wisly gan to swere
Þat in hir defaute shulde neủere schulde schulde noon̄ be þer͗e
Here mon̄ men seen̄ an humble wise acord
Thus hath sche take hir ʆseruaunt and hir lord
Seruaunt in loue / and lord in mariage
Than was he boþe in lordschipp and seruage
Seruage nay / but in lordschipp aboue
Siþen he hath boþe his ladi ⁊and his loue
His ladi certis and his wijf also
To whiche / þat lawe of loue acordiþ so
And whan he was in siche ꝓprosꝑperite
Hom with his wijf he goþ in his cūntre
Not fer from̄ pedmark þer his dwellynge was
Where as he leuede in blis and in solas
Who coude telle but þat he hadde wedded be
Þe ioye þe eese and þe prosꝑperite
Þat is betwix an husbond and his wiff
A ȝere and more lastiþ þis blisfull lijf
Til þat þe knyȝt of whiche I spak of þus
Þat of cayrud was cleped arueguᵃarus
Shopp heim to gon̄ and dwelle aȝere or tweyne
In yngelond þat cleped was britayne
To seke in armis worschip and honour
For all his lust he sette in suche labour
And dwelliþ þer ij ȝere þe boke seiþ þus
Now woll I stinte of þis arueragꝰus
And speken I woll of dorigen his wijf
Þat loueden loueden louede hir husbond as hir owne lijf
For his absence wepeþ sche and sikiþ
As don̄ þese noble wyues whan him likitħ
She morneþ weyliþ fastiþ playneþ
Desir͗e of his presens hir so distrᵃned
Þat all þese wide world sche sett att nauȝt
Hir frendis whiche þat knewe hir heuy þouȝt
Conforten hir in all þat eủere þey may
Þei prechen hur þei tellen hur nyȝt and day
That causeles sche sleeith hir silf allas
And eủery comforte possible in þis caas
They don̄ to hur͗e with aƚƚ hur͗e bessinesse
And forto make hur͗e lette hur͗e heuynes
By proces as Ie knowen wel eủerychon
Men may so longe gᵃrauen in a ston̄
Til sum figure þer Inne aprentid be
So longe han þey confortid hir þat sche
Receyued hath bi hope and by resoun̄
Þe Emprentynge of hir constillacoıı̄un
Þoruȝ whiche hir gret sorwe gan aswage
She may nouȝt alwey endur͗e in suche arage
And eke ảruegarus in al this care
Hath sent hir hom letteris of his wilfar͗e
And þat he wol come hastely ayen
Or eƚƚlles hadde this sorwe hir herte slayn
Hir frendis saw hir herte gan to slake
And preyed hir on knees for goddis sake
To come and Rome hir in companye
Awey to dryue hir dirke fantasie
And fynaly sche gᵃraunted þat request
For well sche saw it was for þe best
Now stood hir casteƚƚ faste bi þe see
And ofte tymes wiþ hir frendis walkiþ she
Hur͗e to disporte on þe banke on hiȝe
Whar͗e as sche many a schip and barge syȝe
Seylyng hur cours where hem lust to go
But ȝit was þat aꝑparcel of hir woo
For to hur silf ful ofte alas seide sche
Is þer no ship as of many as I see
Wolde brynge hom̄ my lord þen wolde my͒n herte
Al warisshit be of my peynes smerte
Anoþer tyme þan wolde she sitte and þenke
And kaste hir iȝen dounward fro þe brynke
But whan she saw þe gresily rokkis blake
For verry feer hir herte be gan to quake
Þat on̄ hir fete sche myȝt not hur sustene
Þan wolde sche sitte adoun̄ on þe grene
And piteuosly in to þe see beholde
Seiynge riȝt þus wiþ sorweful siky nge s sikynge sikys colde
Eterne god þat þoruȝ þi puruyaunce
Ledist þe world bi certeyn gouernaunce
In ydil as men say ȝe noþing make
But lord þis grisly feendly Rokkis blake
That semen raþer a foul confusioıı̄un
Of werk þan ony fair͗e creacioıı̄un
Of whiche aꝑparfit god and astable
Whi han ȝe wrouȝt þis werk vnresonable
Bi þis werk south west north and est
Þer nys Ifostrid man brid ne best
It doth no good to my wit but anoyeth
Se ȝe not lord how mankynde it distroyeth
An hundrid þousend ȝit of mankynde
Han Rokkis slayn al be þey nouȝt in mynde
Whiche mankynde is so fair͗e ꝑpart of þi werk
Þat þou it madist Ilik to þyn owne werk
Þan semyþ it ȝe han don̄ gret chierte
Toward mankynde but how þen may it be
Þat ȝe suche menes make hit to distryen
Whiche menes don̄ no good but euere anoyen
Bi argumentis þat al þing is for þe best
I wote wel clerkis wolen seyn̄ as hem lust
Þouȝ I ne ne can nouȝt þe causes sooþ to knowe
But þilke god þat made wynd to blowe
As kepe my lord þis my conclusioıı̄un
To clerkis lete I al disputisoıı̄un
But wolde god þat I I al þis rokkis blake
Were sonken in to helle for his sake
Þese rokkis slen myn herte for fer͗e
Þus wolde sche sayn wiþ many a pitous ter͗e
Hir frendis sawe þat it was no disport
To Romen bi þe see but litil comfort
And shopen for to pleyen som wher eƚƚlles
Þey leden hur bi reuers and by welles
And eken in oþer places delitables
Þei daunce and pley att chesse and at tables
So on a day Ryȝt in þe morwe tyde
Vn to a gardeyn̄ þat was þer͗e be side
In suche þat þei had mad hir ordinaıı̄unce
Of vitaile and of oþer puruyaıı̄unce
Þey gon and pley hem aƚƚ þe longe day
And þis was on þe sexte morwe of may
Whiche may hath peyntid with his softe showres
This gardeyn̄ ful of leues and of an and of flouris
And craft of manes͗ hand so coriously
Arayed hath þis gardeyn͒ triayly triayly riayly
Þat neuer was þer gardeyn of suche pris
But if it wer͗e þe verray paradis
Þe ordur͗e ordur͗e odur͗e of flouris and þe fressh siȝt
Wolde han maked an herte to be to be lyȝt
That euer was born̄ but If so gret siknes
Or to to gret sorwe shulde hit in distres
So ful it was of beaute wiþ plesaunce
And after dyner go þei for for to daunce
And sīnge also saue dorygen allone
She made alwey hir compleynt and hir mone
For sche ne saw him on þe daunce gon̄
That sche loued best and oþer non̄
That was hir husbond ⁊and hur lord also
For whiche she was in þouȝt ⁊and wo
But neþeles sche moste a tyme a bide
And with good hope let hir sorwe glide
Vp on̄ þis daunce amonges oþer men
Daunced a squyer͗e beforn̄ doregen
Þat fressher was and Iolyerer͗ of aray
As to my dom̄ þen is þe monyþ of may
He syngiþ daunciþ passynge ony man
Þat is or was siþes þe world began
Þer wiþ he was ȝif men shuld him discryue
On of þe beste faryng man of lyue
Ȝong strong riȝt vertues and wise
And welbeloued and halden in gret pris
And shortely ȝf I þe soþe telle schaƚƚ
Vnwetynge of þis doryngen at al
This lusti squier seruaunt to venus
Whiche þat cleped was aurellius
Hath loued hir best of ony Creatur͗e
Two ȝere and more as was his auentur͗e
But neuer durste he telle hir his greuaunce
With outen cuppe he drank all his penaance
He was dispeiryd no þing durst he seie
Saue in his song sumwhat wolde he wreie
His woo and his gen̉eral compleynynge
He seide he louede and I was loued no þing
Of suche mater he made many layes
Songes compleyntes roundelette vyrelayes
How þat he durste noȝt his sorwe telle
Þat langwisschid as a fere doth in helle
And dyee he seide I moste as dede ecco
For marcyus þat durste nouȝt telle hir wo
In other maner þen ȝe here me saye
Ne durste he nouȝt to hur͗e his wo bywrye
Saue ꝑparauentur͗e sum̄ tyme at daunces
Þe ȝong folk kepen to her͗e of obʆseruaunces
Hit may wel be he lokyd on hir face
In suche awyse as men þat axen gᵃrace
But noþing wiste sche of his entent
Neþeles it hapede or þey thens went
Because þat he was hur͗e neyȝebour͗e
And was a man of worshipp and honour͗e
And hadde knowen hem ofte tyme ȝore
Þey felle in speche este tyme more and mor͗e
Vn to his purpos drouȝ Aurelyus
And whan he say his tyme he seide þus
Madame quod he be god þat þis world made
So þat I wiste I myȝt ȝoure herte glade
I wolde þat day þat ȝoure Aruegarus
Wente to þe see þat I auerlyus
Had went þat I shulde neuer han come ageyn̄
For wel I wote my ʆseruyce is in veyn̄
My guerdon͒ nys but brekynge of myn herte
Madame reuetħ on my peynes smerte
For with a word ȝe may me shle or saue
Her͗e at ȝour͗e fote god wolde I were I gᵃraue
I naue as now nomor͗e leiser͗e for to seye
Haue merci on me swete or ȝe wol ȝe wol do me deye
She gan to loke on Auerelyus
Is þis ȝoure wille ꝙquod sche ⁊and say ȝe þus
Neuer erst quod sche ne wiste I what ȝe ment
But now aurely I knowe ȝoure entent
Bi thilke god þat ȝaf me soule and lyff
Ne schall I neuer ben vntrew a wyf
In word ne in werk as fer as I haue witt
I wol ben his to whom þᵗat þᵗat I am knytt
But aftir þat in playn̄ þus seide sche
Take þis for fynaƚƚ answer͗e as for me
Aurely quod sche by god þat is aboue
Ȝit wol I gᵃraunte ȝou to be ȝour͗e loue
Siþes I se ȝou so pitously compleyne
Loke þat ȝe betwix engelond and brytayne
To remewe alle þe rokkis ston̄ by ston̄
That þey ne lete schip ne bote to gon̄
I say whan̄e ȝe haue maad þe see costis so clene
Of Rokkis þat þer nys no ston̄ asene
Then woll I loue ȝou best of ony man
Haue her͗e my trouthe in all that eủere I can
Is þer non̄ oþer gᵃrace in ȝow quod he
No by þe lord quod she þat maad me
For well y woot þat it shaƚƚ neuer betide
Lete suche foly out of ioure ioure herte glyde
What deynte schulde aman haue by his lyff
For to loue an oþer mans wyf
That hath hir body whan so him lykyth
Aurely ful ofte sore syketh
So woo was aurely when þat he þis herde
And with asorweful herte þus answerde
Madame quod he þis wer͗e an Inpossible
Then mote I die on sodeyn̄ deth orible
And with þat word he turned him anon̄
Tho cam hir oþer frendis many on̄
And in þe aleyes romed vp and doun̄
And noþing wiste of þis conclusioun̄
But sodeynly began reuel newe
Til þat þe bryȝt sonne loste his hewe
For þe orison̄te hath raft þe sonnes lyȝt
This is ameche to seye it was nyȝt
And hom þei gon In ioye and in solas
Saue only wrecche aurely alas
He to his hus is gon wiþ sorwefulherte
He sayde he may not from̄ his deth asterte
Him semeþ he felith his herte cold
Vp to heuene he his herte gan hold
And on his knees bare he sette him doun̄
And in þe gronynge sayd he þis orisoun̄
For very woo out of his witte breyde
He nyst nouȝt what he spak but þus he seide
Wiþ pitous herte haþ he his compleynt begonne
Vn to þe goddesse and first vn to þe sonne
He sayde appollo god and gouernour͗e
Of eủery plaunt erbe tre and flour͗e
Þat ȝeuest aftir þi diclinacioıı̄un
To ilke of him his tyme ⁊and his sesoıı̄un
And þin herborwe chaungiþ lowe ⁊and hiȝe
Lord phebꝰus cast þy merciabil eyȝe
On wreche Aurely whiche I nam but lorn̄
Lo lord my lady hath my deth sworn̄
With outyn gilt but þin benygnyte
Vp on̄ my dedly herte haue sūm pite
But wel I wot lord phebꝰus ȝef ȝou leste
Ȝe may me helpe saue my lady beste
Now fouchesauff þat I may ȝou deuyse
How þat I may be holpe and in what wyse
Your͗e blisful sistir lucyna þe shene
Þat of þe se is chif goddesse and quene
Þouȝ neptynus haue deyte in þe se
Ȝit Emꝑperesse Abouen him is she
Ȝe knowith wel lord riȝt as hur͗e desyr͗e
Is to be quked ⁊and lyȝted of ȝour͗e fyr͗e
For whiche sche folwith ȝou ful bysily
Ryȝt so þe se desirith naturelly
To folwen hur͗e as he þat is goddesse
Boþe in see ⁊and in Reủeres mor͗e and lesse
Wher͗for͗e lord phebus þis is my request
Do þis myracle or I I do myn herte brest
That thou next after þis apposecioıı̄un
Do away þilke rokke and leye it doun̄
The hieste rokke in armorik bretayne
And lete þis flode endur͗e ȝeris tweyne
Than certis to my lady may I say
Holdith ȝour͗e hestis þe rokkis ben away
Lord phebꝰus doth þis meracle for me
Pray hur sche go no fastir cours þan ȝe
I say þus pray ȝour͗e sustir þat sche go
No fastir cours þan ȝe þis ȝeris two
Þen schal sche be eủere att fulle alwey
And sprynge flood laste boþe nyȝt ⁊and day
And but sche fuchesauf in suche man̉ere
To gᵃraunte me my lady souereyn dere
Prey hur to synkyn eủery rokke adoun̄
In to hir owne derke regioıı̄un
Vnder þe ground þer pluto dwellyþ in
Or neuer mor͗e schall I my lady wyn
Thyn temple in delphos wol I barefote seke
Lord phebus se þe teris on my cheke
And of my peyne haue sūm cūmpassioıı̄un
And with þat word in swoun̄ he fel adoun̄
And longe tyme he lay in atraunce
His broþer whiche þat knew of his pennaunce
Vp cauȝte him and to þe bedde hīm brouȝte
Dispeirid in þis turment and in þis þoute
Lete I þis woful cratur͗e lye
Chese he for me whethir he woƚƚ lyue or dye
Aruegarus with hele and gret honour
As he þat was of chyualry þe flour͗
I comen hom̄ and oþer worþy men
O blisful art þou doregen
That hast þy lusti husbond in þyn armes
The fressche knyȝt þe worþy man of armes
That louetħ þe as is owne hertis lyff
Nothing lust him to ben ymagynatijf
Ȝif ony wiȝt hath spoken whiles he was oute
To hur of loue he mad þer of no doute
He nouȝt entendith of suche mater͗e
But daunceþ Iustiþ and makiþ good cher͗e
And þus in Ioie and blisse I lete him dwelle
And of þe seke aurely woll I telle
In langour and in furious turmentis
Two ȝer͗e and mor͗e þis wreche Aurelyus
Or ony foot on erthe myȝt he gon̄
No comford in this tyme had he non̄
Saue of his broþer whiche þat was a clerk
He knew of all this woo and of all this werk
For to non̄ other creatur͗e certeyn
Off þis mater ne durste he no word seyn̄
Vndir his brest he bare it mor͗e secr͗e
Than eủere dede pamphilyus for galatr͗e
His brest was hole with outen for to sene
But in his herte was ay þe arwe kene
And wel ȝe knowe þat a sursanur͗e
In surgery ful ꝑperilous is þe cur͗e
But man myȝte touche þe arwe or come þer by
His brothir wepith and weylith pⁱriuyly
Til at þe laste hym fel in remembraunce
That whiles þat he was at orlyaunce in fraunce
As ȝonge clerkis þat ben lycorous
To reden artes that ben curious
Seken in eủery halke and eủery hurne
ꝐParticuler͗e sciens for to conne
He hym remembrid þat vp on̄ aday
Att orlyaunce in study abook he say
Of mᵃgyke naturel whiche his felowe
That was þat tyme abacheler͗e of lawe
Al wer͗e he therto lerne another craft
And preuyly vp on̄ his deske he laft
Whiche book spekiþ mechel of oꝑperacioıı̄uns
Touchynge þat viij an twynti mancioıı̄uns
That longen to þe mone and suche folye
As in our͗e dayes hit nys nouȝt worth a flie
For holychirch hath in our͗e bileue
Ne suffrith noon Ilusions vs for to greue

div.l: (base) And whan this book was in his remembraunce
(base) Anon for ioye his herte gan to daunce
(base) And to hymself he seyde pryuely
(base) My brother shal be warisshed hastily
(base) For I am siker that ther be sciences
(base) By whiche men make diuerse apparences
(base) Swiche as thise subtile Tregettours pleye
(base) For ofte at festes haue I wel herd seye
(base) That Tregettours with Inne an halle large
(base) Haue maad come In a water and a barge
(base) And in the halle rowen vp and doun
(base) Som tyme hath semed come a grym leoun
(base) And som tyme floures sprynge as in a mede
(base) Som tyme a vyne and grapes white and rede
(base) Som tyme a Castel al of lym and stoon
(base) And whan hem lyked voyded it anoon
(base) Thus semed it to euery mannes sighte
(base) Now thanne conclude I thus that if I myghte
(base) At Orliens som old felawe yfynde
(base) That hadde this Moones mansions in mynde
(base) Or oother Magyk naturel aboue
(base) He sholde wel make my brother han his loue
(base) For with an apparence a clerk may make
(base) To mannes sighte that alle the Rokkes blake
(base) Of Britaigne were yvoyded euerichon
(base) And Shippes by the brynke comen and gon
(base) And in swich forme enduren a day or two
(base) Thanne were my brother warisshed of his wo
(base) Thanne moste she nedes holden hir biheste
(base) Or ellis he shal shame hire at the leeste
(base) What sholde I make a lenger tale of this
(base) Vnto his brotheres bed he comen is
(base) And swich confort he yaf hym for to gon
(base) To Orliens that he vp stirte anon
(base) And on his wey forthward thanne he is fare
(base) In hope for to been lissed of his care
(base) Whan they were come almoost to that Citee
(base) But if it were a two furlong or thre
A ȝong clerk Romynge by him selff þey mette
Whiche þat in latyn thrifftyly hem grette
And after þat he sayd a wonder thing
I know ꝙquod he þe cause of ȝour͗e comynge
And er þey forther eny foot went
He told hem al that was in her͗e entent
This bryton̄ clerk him enquered of felawes
Þe whiche þat he hadde knowe in olde dawes
And he answerde him þat þey ded were
For which he wepte ful ofte many atere
Doun̄ of his hors he lyȝt anon̄
And with þis magiscien forth is he gon̄
Hom̄ to his hous and made hēm wel at ese
Hem lakked no vitaiƚƚ þat him myȝt him him plese
So wel araied hous as þer was on̄
Aurelyus in his lyff ne saw he neuer non̄
He schewid him or he wente to soꝑper
Forestes parkes ful of wilde der͗
Þo saw he hertis with hornes hyȝe
Þe grettest þat eủere wer͗e I seye with iȝe
He sawe of hem slayn an hundrid wᵗith houndes
And sum with arwes blede with bitter woundes
Þese faukoners vp on̄ a fair͗e ruyer͗e
He sawe whan voided wer͗e þis wilde der͗e
That with her͗e fawkonnys han̄ þe heron̄ slayn̄
Þan saw he knyȝtis Iusten in a playn͒
And aftir þis he dede hum suche plesaunce
That he him shewyd his lady in a daunce
On whiche him silf daunced as him þouȝte
And when þis maistir þat þis magyke wrouȝte
Saw hit was tyme he clappyd his hondes to
And far͗e wel al þe reuel is ago
And ȝit remeued neuer out of his hous
Whiles þey sawe al þis siȝt meruylous
But in his studye þer as his bokes be
They saten stille ⁊and no wiȝt but þey iij
To him þis maistir callyd his squier͗e
And seyde him þus is redy our͗e soper͗e
Almost an hour͗e hit is I vndirtake
Sithes I ȝow bad our͗e soꝑper to make
When þat þese worthy men wenten wᵗith me
Vn to my study þer as my bokes be
Sire quod þis squier͗e when it likith ȝou
Hit is al redy þouȝ ȝe wolden it now
Go we þen soupe quod he and for þe beste
Þis amerous folk sumtyme wold haue reste
And aftir soper fil þey in trete
What sūmme shulde þis maisteres gwerdon̄ be
To remewe alle þe rokkis of breteyne
And eke fro geroıı̄und to þe mouthe of sayne
He made him strange ⁊and swor so god him saue
Lesse þan athousend poıı̄und he wolde not haue
Ne gladly for þat som̄e he nolde noȝt gon̄
Aurelius with blisful herte anoon̄
Answerde þus fy on athousend poıı̄und
This wyde world whiche þat men say is round
I wolde it ȝeue If I wer͗e lord of hit
Þis bargeyn̄ is ful dreuen for we ben knyt
Ȝe schullen ben I I payd treuly by my trouthe
But lokith now þat for no necligence ne for slouthe
Ȝe tarie vs no lenger þen to morwe
Nay quod þis clerk her͗e my trouthe to borwe
To bedde is gon̄ aurelyus when him luste
And wel nyȝ all þis nyȝt hadde his reste
What for his labour͗e and for his hope of blysse
His wofuƚƚ herte of pennaıı̄unce gan to lysse
Vp on̄ þe morwe when þat it was day
To brytayne took þey þe riȝte way
Aurelyus and this magicien bisyde
And ben descendet þer þey woleth abyde
And this was as þe book me remembr͗
The colde frosti seson̄ of decembr
Phebus wax old and hewed like latoıı̄un
That in his hote declinacioıı̄un
Shon̄ as þe Bornysshed gold with st̉remys bryȝt
But now in caprycorne doun̄ he lyȝt
Where as he schon̄ ful pale I dar wel sayn̄
The bitter frostes with þe snow and rayn̄
Distroyed hath þe grene in in eủery ȝerd
Ianus sitt bi þe fire with double berd
And drynkith of his bugle horn þe wyn̄
Beforn̄ him stand þe braune of þe touxid swyn̄
And nowel crieth eủery lusty man
Aurelyus in al þat eủere þat he can
Doth to this maistir cher͗e and reuerence
And pᵃrayeth him to don̄ his diligence
To bryngen him out of his peynes smerte
Or with a swerd þat he wolde shlitte his herte
This subtiƚƚ clerk whiche routhe hath of þis man
That nyȝt and day he sped hem þat he can
To wayte atyme of his conclusioıı̄un
This is to seyen to make illusyoıı̄un
The wheche an apparens in iogellerie
I can no termes of astorolygie
That she and eủery wiȝt shulde wene and saye
That of breteyne þe rokkys wer͗e aweye
Or eƚƚlles þey wer͗e sonke vnder grounde
So att þe laste haþ his tyme y founde
To make his iapes and his wrecchidnes
Off whiche a substicions cursudnes
His tablys collettauns forth he brouȝte
Ful wel corretted ne þer lakked nouȝt
Ne his colectes ne his expans ȝers
Ne his ratis ne his oþer geris
As ben his centres and his Argumentis
And his proporcioıı̄uns cōnuenyentis
For his equacioıı̄uns in eủery þing
And by his viij spere in his worching
He knewe how fer alnache was shoue
Fro þe hed of þilke fyx aries aboue
Þat in þe ix spere concederit is
Ful subtilly he callyd aƚƚ þis
And whan̄e he hadde founden̄ his firste mancioıı̄un
He knew þe remenaunt by proꝑporcioıı̄un
And knew weƚƚ þe monys mancioıı̄un
And cordaunt to his oꝑperacioıı̄un
And knewe also his othir obseruaunces
For suche illusiouns ⁊and suche meschauncez
As hethen folk vsed in þilke dayes
For whiche no lenger mad he delayes
But þoruȝ his magike for awoke or twey
It semed as aƚƚ þe rokkes had ben̄ away
Aurelius whiche þat dispeyrid is
whether he schal haue his loue or fare amys
Awaitith nyȝt and day of þis myracle
And when he knew þer was non̄ oþer obstacle
That voyded wer͗e þe Rokkes eủerychon̄
Doun̄ to his maistirs feet he fel anon̄
And sayde I wofful wreche Aurelyus
Thanke I ȝow lord and my lady Venus
That me haue holpe of my caris colde
And to þe temple forþ þe wey hath holde
Wher͗e he knew he schulde his lady se
And whan he saw his tyme anon̄ riȝt he
With dredful herte and humble cher͗e
Salued haþ his souereyn lady der͗e
My Ryȝtful lady quod þis woful man
Whom I moste drede and loue as I best can
And lothest am am of all þis world displese
Ner͗e it þat I haue for yow suche disese
That I most die her͗e for ȝour͗e fote anon̄
Bot nouȝt woll I telle yow how me is woo bygon̄
But certeynly owþer most I dye or pleyne
Ȝe slo me gilteles for verry peyne
But of my deth ȝe haue no routhe
A vyse ȝou well or ȝe lesen ȝour͗e trouthe
Repentith ȝow for þilke god aboue
Or ye me sle by cause þat I ȝou loue
For madame well ȝe woot þat ȝe haue hiȝt
Nouȝt that I chalenge ony þing of ryȝt
Of ȝou my soủerayng lady but ȝoure grace
But in a gardeyn ⁊and in suche a place
Ȝe wot riȝt wel þat ȝe behiȝt me
And in myn hand ȝoure trouþe plyȝt me
To loue me best god wote ȝe seyde so
Al be þat I vnworthy be þer to
Madame I speke it for þe honour͗e of ȝou
More þan to haue myn hertis lyff thorgh ȝow
I haue so do riȝt as ȝe comaundid me
And ief ȝe vouchesaf ȝe may goo ⁊and se
As ȝou luste and haueth ȝoure heste in mynde
FOr Or FOr quyk or ded riȝt þer ȝe schull me fynde
In ȝou lith all to do me lyue or dye
But well I wot þe rokkis wer͗e awey
He took his leue and sche astonyed stood
In al hir face nas no drope of blod
Alas quod sche þat þis eủere schuld happe
She wente neuer to haue come in suche atrappe
For wende y neủer bi possibilite
That suche a maistir or siche ameruayle schuld be
Hit is aȝen þe processe of natur͗e
And hoom sche goth a sorweful creatur͗e
For very feer vnneþes may sche go
She wepith and wailyþ aday or two
And swoneþ þat it rouþe was to se
But whi it was to no wiȝt tolde it sche
For out of toune was goon̄ aruegarus
But to hur͗e silf sche seide and spak þus
In hir͗e compleynt as ȝe schall aftir here
With face pale and with sorweful chere
Allas quod sche on þe fortune I pleyne
That vnware hast wrapped me in þy cheyne
Off whiche þe eschape wot I non̄ socour͗e
Saue only deth or dishonoure
On of þis two behouyþ me to chese
But neþeles ȝit had I leuer to lese
My lif þan of my body to haue shame
Or knowen mysilf fals or lesen myn name
And with my deth I may be quyt Iwys
Hath þer nouȝt many awiff or þis
And many amayden slayn hir silf allas
Rathir þan witħ hir bodies do trespas
And certis lo þis stories beriþ witnes
When terauntes ful of cursidnesse
Hath slayn Phidon̄ in Attenes att þe leste
He comaundid his douȝtirs to areste
And bryngen hem be for him in dispite
All naked to fulfillen here dilite
And in her͗e faders blod þei made hem daunce
Vp on þe pauement god ȝef hem mishaunce
For whiche this woful maydenes ful of drede
Rather þan þey wolde lesen hir maydenhede
They preuyli ben start in to awelle
And dreynt hem silf þer is nomor͗e to telle
They of mesne let enquere and seke
Off lacedomye Fifti maydenes eke
On whiche þey wolden don̄ here lecherie
But was þer non̄ of all that companye
That sche was slayn and with a glad entent
Ȝe rather for to dien þan for to assent
To ben oppressed of hir maydenhed
Why schulde I þan to dye be in dred
Lo eek þe tirraunt Austoclides
That loued amayden þat hiȝt symphalides
Whan þat hir fadir was slayn on anyȝt
Vn to dyanes temple goþ sche anon̄ Ryȝt
And hente þe ymage wiþ hir harmes two
Fro whiche ymage wolde sche neuer go
No wiȝt myȝt of hit hir handis race
Til sche was slayn riȝt in þe same place
Now siþens þat maydens had suche dispite
To ben defoulid with mans foul delite
Wel auȝte awiff rathir hir silf to slee
Þen ben defouled as þenkyd me
What schall I sayn̄ of hardrubalys wif
That at cartage byraffte hir silf hir lijf
For whan sche sawe þat romaynes won̄e þe toun̄
She toke hir͗e childeren alle and swepte adoun̄
In to þe fier and ches rather to dye
div.note: Frankleyn̄
div.l: Þan ony romaynes dede hur͗e vilanye
div.note: vilanye wye
div.l: Hath nouȝt lucresse Islayn̄ hir silf allas
Att rome there sche oppressed was
Off tarquyne for hir þoute it was ashame
div.note: the same
div.l: To lyue whan sche hadde lost hir name
The eyȝte maydenes of melefye also
Han slayn hem for very drede and wo
Rather þan folk of gaule schuld hem oppresse
Mo þan a þousend stories as I gesse
Couthe I now tellen as touchynge þis mater͗e
Whan abradace was slayn his wijf so der͗e
Her silf slouȝe / and lete hir blod do glide
In habradace woundes brod and wyde
And sayde my body att þe leeste way
Þer schall no wiȝt defoule it ȝif I may
What schulde more ensaumplis þer of sayn̄
Sithes that so many han hem silf slayn̄
Well rather þan þey wolde defouled be
I wol conclude what is best for me
Other raþer sle my silf in sūm maner͗e
As dede demonycioıı̄uns douȝter dere
Be cause þat sche nold nouȝt defouled be
O cedasus hit is ful gret pyte
To reden how þy douȝteren deyde allas
That slouȝ hem self for suche aman̉ere caas
As grett appetit was it or more
Þe theban mayden þat for nychasore
Her͗e selue slouȝ ryȝt for suche maner woo
Anoþer theban mayden dede riȝt so
For on̄ off massodoygne had her͗e opp̉ressed
She wᵗith heer deetħ hir maydenhed hath redressed
What schal I sayn̄ of mysaratives mysaratives mysarative mysarative wiffes
That for suche caas by raffte her͗e self her͗e lyffes
How trewe was eke to Alcebrades
His loue þat for to dyen ches
Then for to suffren his bodye vnberied be
Loo whiche a wyf was alcesten quod sche
What Emore off good penolope
Al grece knowith of hir castite
Parde off ledomay is writen thus
That whan̄e att troye was slayn protheselayus
No lenger woll sche lyue aftir his day
The same of noble porcia telle y may
With outen brutus couthe she noȝt lyuen
To whom sche hadde all hool hir herte ȝeuen
The ꝑparfit wifhod of arthemesy
Honoured is þoruȝ alle þe barbary
O teuta quene þȳn wiffly chastite
To alle wyues may amyrrour͗e be
Thus playnes Dorigen a day or tweye
Purposed eủere þat sche woll dye
But natheles vp on̄ þridde nyȝt
Hom com Aruegarus þe worthy knyȝt
And asked hir why þat sche wepte so sore
And sche gan wepen euer þe lenge þe more
Allas quod sche þat eủere I was born̄
Þus haue I said quod she she þus haue I sworn̄
And told him alle as ȝe haue herd before
It nedith nouȝt to reherce hit no more
Þis husbond in glad cher͗e in sundery wyse
Answerde and saide as I schall ȝou deuyse
Is þer ouȝt eƚƚlles dorigen but þis
Nay nay quod she god helpe me so Iwys
This is to meche and it were goddes wille
Ȝe wyff quod he lett slepe þat is stille
Hit may be well ȝit wel ꝑparauenture
Ȝe schulle ȝour͗e trouthe holden I ȝou ensure
For god so wyssly haue mercy vp on̄ me
I hadde well leuer I stiked for to be
For verry loue whiche þat I to ȝou haue
But ȝif ȝe schulle ȝoure trouthe kepe kepe and saue
Trouthe is þe heyest þing þat man may kepe
But with þat word he breste anon̄ to wepe
And sayde I ȝou for bede vp peyne of detħ
That neủere whiles ȝe lasten liff and bretħ
To no wiȝt telle þou how þat þis mater͗e
As I may kepe I woll my woo endur͗e
Ne make no contynaunce of heuynesse
That folk of ȝou may deme harme as I gesse
And forth he cleped a squier͗ee and ameyde
Goth forth anon̄ with dorigen he sayde
And bryngeth hur͗e to suche aplace anon͒
They take hur͗e leue ⁊and on hir way þey gon̄
But þey ne wiste whi sche thider went
She nolde nowyȝt tellen hir entent
This squyer͗e whiche þat hiȝte Aurelyus
On dorigen þat was so amerous
Of auentur͗e happid hur to mete
A myd þe toun̄ riȝt in þe quickeste strete
As sche was boun̄ to go þe wey forth riȝt
Toward þe gardeyn̄ þer as sche had hiȝt
And he was to þe gardyn ward also
For well he spyed when sche wolde go
Out of hir hous to ony maner place
But þus þey mette of auentur͗e or gᵃrace
And he saluyþ hir͗e with good entent
And askith hir whethir þat sche went
And sche answerde half as sche were mad
Vn to þe gardyn as myn husbond bad
My trouthe for to holden allas allas
Aurelyus gan woundre of þis caas
And in his herte hadde gret compassioıı̄un
Off hur͗e and of hur͗e lementacioıı̄un
And of aruegarus þe worþy knyȝt
Þat bad hur holde all þat sche had hiȝt
So loth him was his wyf shuld breken hur͗e trouthe
And in his hertte he cauȝte of þis gret routhe
Consederynge þe beste on euery side
Þat fro his lust were him betir abyde
Þan don̄ so hiȝe a cheorles wrecchidnes
Aȝen fraunchise and all gentilnes
For whiche in fewe wordis sayde he thus
Madame saith to your͗e lord aruegarus
That sithes I se þis gret gentilnes
Off ȝou and eke I se ȝoure distres
For me þenketh that it it is gret routhe
That ȝe to me þus shuld breke ȝour͗e trouþᵉ
I haue wel leủere euer to leue in woo
Than I deꝑparte þe loue betwix ȝou two
I ȝou relese madame in to ȝour͗e hond
Quyt eủery surement and eueri bond
Þat ȝe haue maad to me as here beforn̄
Sith thilke tyme þat ȝe were born̄
My treuthe I plyȝt I schall ȝou neuer repreue
Off no bihest and here I take my leue
As off þe trewest and of þe beste wiff
That eủere ȝet I knewe in all my lijff
But eủery wijf bewar͗e off hir beheste
On dorigen remembreth atte leste
Thus can a squier͗e doon̄ agentil dede
As well as can aknyȝt with outen drede
She þanked him vpon vpon hir͗e knees all bar͗e
And hoom̄ vn to hur husbond is sche far͗e
And told him̄ all as ȝe han herd me sayd
And be ȝe seker he was so weƚƚ apayd
And þat it wer͗e inpossible me to write
What schulde I lenger off þis caas endite
Aruegay and Dorigen his wijff
In souereyngne blisse ledde forth hir lijff
Neuer eft ne was þer anger hym by twene
He cherisschid hir as þouȝ sche wer͗e aquene
And sche was to him trewe For eủeremore
Off these two folk ȝe gete off me no more
Aurely that þis cost hath all forlorne
Cursed þe tyme þat euer he was born͗e
Allas ꝙquod he allas þat I behiȝt
Off pured gold a Mˡthousend pound of wyȝt
Vn to this philosopher how schall I do
I se nomore but þat I am vndo
Myn eritage mote I nedes selle
And ben a begger͗e her͗e may I noȝt dwelle
And schame all my kynrede in þis place
But I of hit may geten beter gᵃrace
But naþeles I woll of him assay
Þe gentilnes of hīm if þat I may
And þonke hīm off his gret curtesie
My trouthe woƚƚ I kepe I woll not lye
With herte sor͗e he goth vn to his cofre
And brouȝte gold vn to þis philosophr͗e
Þe valu of v C lībpound I gesse
And him beseched of his gentilnes
To gᵃraunte him dayes of þe remenaunt
And maister I dar weƚƚ make auaunt
I failid neuer my trouth as ȝit
For sikerly my dettes shal be quyt
Toward ȝow how þat eủere I fare
To gon an begge in my kirtel bar͗e
But wolde ȝe fuchesauf vp on̄ suerte
Two ȝere or þre to respite me
Þan wer͗e I weƚƚ or eƚƚlles most I selle
Myn eritage þer nys nomor͗e to telle
Þis philosopher͗e soberly answerde
And seide þus whan he þis wordis herde
Haue I noȝt holden couenaunt vn to þe
Ȝis certes wel and trewly vn to me
Hast þou nouȝt had þi lady as þe lykith
No no quod he and sorwefully he sikith
What was þe cause telle me ȝif þou can
Aurelius anon̄ his tale bigan
And told him aƚƚ as ȝe han herd byfore
Hit nedeth not to ȝou reherce it nomore
And seyde Aruegarus of gentilnes
Had leuer dyen in sorwe and in distresse
Þan þat his wyff wer͗e of hir trouthe fals
Þe sorwe of dorigen̄ he told him als
How loth hir wer͗e to ben a wicked wiff
And þat sche had leuer þat day han lost hir lyff
And þat hir trouþe sche swore þoruȝ Innocence
She neủer erst herde spekēn of apparence
That made me han of hir so gret pyte
And riȝt as freoly as he sente hir me
As freoly I sente hur͗e to him aȝyan̄
Þis is al and sum þer nys nomorer͗e to sayn̄
Þis philosopher͗e answerde leue broþer
Eủerich of iou dede gentelich to oþer
Thou art a squier͗e and he is a knyȝt
But god for bede for his meche myȝt
But if aclerk couthe don̄ a gentil adede
As wel as ony of yow it is no drede
Sir͗e I relesse þe þy þousaund pound
As þouȝ þou now riȝt wer͗e crepen out of þe groıı̄und
Ne neủere or now haddist knowen me
For sir͗e I woƚƚ nouȝt taken apeny of þe
For all my craft ne noȝt for my tᵃrauaille
Þou hast payed well for my vitaile
It is ynow and fare weeƚƚ ⁊and haue good day
And took his hors and forth he goth his way
Lordyngꝭes þen wolde I þis questioıı̄un axe ȝow
Whiche was þe moste fre as þenkith ȝow
Now tellyth me or þat I forth wende
I can nomor͗e my tale is at an ende
Here endith the Frankleyns tale
And begynnyth the ꝓprolog of the Nonne
The mynystre and þe norice vnto vices
Wheche þat men clepe on englis Idelnes
That porter of þe gate is off delices
To escheuwe and by hure contarie hur͗e opp
div.note: The last letters, presumably "res" are cut off in the margin.
div.l: That is to seien leoffuƚƚ besines
Well ouȝte we to don̄ our͗e entent
Lest þat þe feend þoruȝ idelnes vs hent
¶ For he that with his thousand cordes sleyghe
Contynuelly vs waitith to be clappe
When he may man in ydilnes asspye
He can so lyȝtly cache him in his trappe
Til that aman be hent riȝt by þe lappe
He nys noȝt war þe feond haþ him in hond
Well ouȝte vs worche and Idilnes wiþstond
¶ And þouȝ men dradde neủer for to die
Ȝit sum men woll be reson̄ douteles
Þat ydilnes is roten slogardie
Off whiche þer cometh no good ne encres
And sithen þat slouthe hure haldeþ in ales
Only to slepe and for to ete ⁊and drynke
And / to deuour͗e al that oþer swynke
¶ And for to put vs fro suche Idilnes
That cause is of gret confusioıı̄un
I haue her͗e don̄ my feyfuƚƚ besynes
After þe legend in tᵃranslacioun̄
Riȝt as þe glorious lijf and passioıı̄un
div.note: amstrodam
div.l: Þou with þy garland wrouȝte of Rose and lylye
I mene ȝou mayde and martir seint cecilye
¶ And þou þat flour͗e of verginis art aƚƚ
Of whom þat barnard lust so weƚƚ endite
To þe att my bygynḡe frst I caƚƚ
Þou comfort of vs wrecchis do me write
The maydenes deth that was þoruȝ hir merite
The eterne lyf of þe feendes victorie
As men may reden aftir in hur͗e storie
¶ Thou maiden and moder douȝtir of þi sone
Thow welle of mercy synfull mannes cur͗e
In whom that god for bounte ches to wonne
Þou humble ad hiȝe of eủery creature
Þou nobledest so fer͗e our͗e nature
Þat no disdeyn þe maker had of kynde
His sone in blood and flessch to clothe and wynde
¶ With Inne þi cloistir blisfuƚƚ of þi sides
Took man̄s schapp þe eterne loue ⁊and pees
That of þe tryne compas lord and gide es
Whom erthe and see and heuene out of Reles
Ay heren and þou virgyne We͒mmeles
Bare of þy body and dwellest mayden pur͗e
The creatoᵘr of eủery creatur͗e
¶ Assemblid in þe is magnificence
With mercy goodnesse and wᵗith suche pitee
That þou þat art þe sonne of excellence
Ful freoly or that men þin helpe beseche
Thou gost biforn̄ and art hur͗e lyues leche
Now help þou meke and blisful fayre mayde
Me flemed wreche in this desert of galle
Thenk on þe Woman of canane þat sayde
That whelpes eten som̄ of þe cromes alle
That from̄ his lordes table ben Ifalle
And þouȝ þat I vnworthey sone of eue
Be synful ȝit accept my byleue
¶ And for that with with feith is ded with outen werkis
So forto worchen ȝif me witt ⁊and space
That I be quyt fro þen̄s that most derk is
O thou þat art so fair͗e and so ful of gᵃrace
Be myn avoket in so hiȝe a place
Ther þat with outen ende is songen osanne
Thou cristes moder douȝtir of seynt anne
¶ And of þy liȝt my soule in presoun lyȝt
That troublyd is by þe contagioıı̄un
Off my body and also by þe wiȝt
Off erthely lust and fals affeccioıı̄un
O hauene of refute O saluacioun̄
Off hem þat ben in sorwe and in distresse
Now help for to my werk I woƚƚ me dresse
¶ Ȝit pray I ȝow that reden þat I wryte
For ȝeue me þat I do no diligence
Þis ilke storye subtilly to endite
For boþe haue I þe wordis ⁊and þe sentence
Off him that at þe seintis reủerence
Þe storie wrot and folwede hur͗e legende
And prayen ȝou that ȝe wolen my weik amende
¶ First wol I ȝou þe name of seynt Celelye
Expoune as men may in hur͗e stories se
It is to saye in Englys heuenes lylye
For pure chastnes of virginite
Or for sche whittnesse hadde of honeste
And grene of conciens and of good fame
The sote sauour͗e lylye was hur͗e name
¶ Or cecylye is to say þe way to blynde
For sche ensample was by good techynge
Or eƚƚlles Cecile as I writen Fynde
Is ioyned by amaner͗e connynge
Off heuene and lay and hier in figurynge
The heuene is sett for þouȝt of holynes
And lya for hir lastynge besynesse
¶ Cely may eke be sayd in this man̉ere
Wantynge of blyndenes for hur gret lyȝt
Off sapiens and for hur͗e thewes cler͗e
Or eƚƚlles lo this maydenes name briȝt
Off heuene and leos cometh of whiche by ryȝt
Men myȝt hur͗e the heuene of peple calle
Ensaumple of gode and wyse werkis alle
¶ For leos peple in Englissch is to sey
And riȝt as men may in to heuene se
Þe sonne and mone and sterres eủery wey
Ryȝt so men goostly in this mayden fre
Seyen of feith þe magnanymyte
And eke þe clernes hool of sapience
And sundry werk briȝt of excellence
¶ And riȝt as þese philosophres write
That heuene is swift and round and eke brennynge
Ryȝt so was fayr͗e Cicilye þe white
Ful swyft and besy eủere in good werkynge
And rond and hool in good ꝑperseủereynge
And brennynge eủere in charite ful bryȝt
Now haue I declared what þe maiden hygħt
This maiden bryȝt cicilye as hur͗e lijf saitħ
