div.l: Was comen of Romayns and of noble kynde
And fro hem vp fostered in þe feitħ
Off crist and bare his gospel in hur͗e mynde
She neủere sesid as I euer fynde
Off hur͗e prayer͗e and god to loue and drede
By sykynge him to kepen hure maydenhede
¶ And when this mayden shulde vn to man
Iweddet be that was ful ȝonge of age
Whiche that I cleped was Valerian
And day was comen of hur mariage
She ful deuout and humble in hur͗e corage
Vnder hur͗e Robe of gold þat sat ful fair͗e
Had nexte hur Flessch I clad hur with an haier͗e
¶ And whiles þe organes maden melodye
To god allone in herte þus sayde sche
O lord my soule and eke my body gye
Vnwēmmed lest þat I confoundet be
And for his loue þat dide vp on̄ atr͗e
Eủery secun̄de day and þe þridde sche faste
Ay byddynge in hur͗e orisouns ful faste
¶ Þe nyȝt cam and to bedde sche must gon̄
With hur͗e husbonde as is þe maner͗e
And preuyli to hym she seide anon̄
Swete and welbeloued spouse dere
Þer is a counseyƚƚ and ȝe wolde it her͗e
Whiche þat riȝt fayn̄ I woƚƚ to ȝou saye
So that ȝe swer͗e ȝe schul it nouȝt bewrye
¶ Valeryan gan faste to hur͗e swer͗e
Þat for no cas ne thing þat myȝt be
He schuld neuer mor͗e bewrye hur͗e
And þan att erst to him þus sayd sche
I haue an aungeƚƚ whiche þat louetħ me
That with gret loue wheþer þat I ride or go or slepe
Is redy ay my body for to kepe
¶ And if he may felen out of drede
Þat ȝe me touche or loue in vilanye
He riȝt anon̄ woƚƚ sle ȝou with þe dede
And in ȝour͗e ȝouthe thus ȝe schullen dye
And if þat ȝe in clene loue me gye
He woll ȝou loue as me for clennesse
And schewen ȝou his ioye and his bryȝtnesse
¶ Valerian corrected as god wolde
Answerde aȝen if I schall truste þe
Lete me þat aungel se and him beholde
And if þat it a very aungel be
Þan wolle I do as þou hast preyed me
And if þou loue an oþer man forsoþe
Ryȝt with this swerd thenne wol I sle ȝou botħhe
¶ Cecilye answerde anon̄ riȝt in this wyse
Ȝef that ȝou lust the aungel shull ȝe se
So that ȝe trowe on crist and ȝou Baptize
Goth forth to via apia ꝙquod sche
That fro this toun̄ ne stant but myles þre
And to þe pore folkes þat þer dwelle
Sey hym riȝt thus riȝt as I schal telle
¶ Telle hem þat I cecilye ȝou to hem sent
To schewe ȝou the gode vrban þe olde
For secre nedes and for good entent
And whan that ȝe seint Vrban han byholde
Telle hym þe wordes whiche þat I ȝou tolde
And when that he hath purged ȝou fro synne
Þen schulle ȝe se that aungel er͗e ȝe twynne
¶ Valerayn̄ is to þat place I gon̄
And riȝt as him was tauȝt by his lernynge
He fond this holy old vrban anon̄
Among þe seintes buriels lotyng
And he anon̄ with outen tariynge
Dede his message and when þat he it told
Vrban for Ioye his handes gan vp hold
¶ The teres from̄ his eyen lett he falle
Almyȝti god o iħuihesu cⁱrist ꝙquod he
Sower͗e of chastite counseƚƚ herde of vs alle
Þe frut of þilke seed of chastite
Þat þou hast sowen in Cicily take to þe
Lo lyke a besy be with outen gile
Þe serued ay þyn owne thraƚƚ Cecile
¶ For þilke spouse that sche toke but now
Ful lyke a fiers lyon̄ she sendiþ her͗e
As meke as eủer was ony lombe to ȝou
And with þat word anon̄ þer gan aper͗e
An old man clad in whites cloþis cler͗e
Þat had a book with letteres of gold in honde
And gan by forēn valerian to stonde
¶ Valeryan as ded fel doun̄ for fer and drede
When he him say and vp he hente him þo
And on his book riȝt þus he gan to rede
O lord . o . feith with outen eny mo
O cristendom̄ and fader of alle also
Abouen alle and oủere al eủery wher͗e
Þis wordes alle with gold Iwriten wer͗e
¶ Whan þis was red þen seyde þis olde man
Leuyst þou þis þing or no sey ȝe or nay
I leue all this þing quod Valarian
For soþer þing þan this I dar well say
Vnder þe heuene no wiȝt þenke may
Þo Vanysshit þis olde man he nyste wher͗e
And pope Vrban him cristened þer͗e
¶ Valerian goth hom̄ and fond Cecilye
With Inne his chaumbre with an aungel stonde
Þis aungel had of roses and of lylye
Corounes two þe wheche he bar͗e in honde
And first to Cecily as I vnderstonde
He ȝaf þat on̄ and after gan he take
Þat other to Valeryan hur͗e make
¶ With body clene and with vnwemed þouȝt
Kepeth ay weƚƚ þis corouns ꝙquod he
From̄ paradis to ȝou haue I hem brouȝt
Ne neủere mor͗e shuƚƚ þey roten be
Ne lesen hur͗e sote sauour͗e trustiþ me
Ne neủer wiȝt schaƚƚ sen hem wᵗith his eiȝe
But he be be chaste and hate Vilanye
¶ And for thou Valeryan for þou so sone
Assentedist to good counseiƚƚ also
Say what þe lust and þou shalt haue þy bone
I haue abrother ꝙquod valeryan̄ þo
Þat in þis world I loue noman so
I pᵃray ȝou that my brother may haue gᵃrace
To knowe þe trouthe as I do in þis place
¶ Þe aungeƚƚ seide god lykeþ ȝour͗e request
And boþe with þe palme of matirdam̄
Ȝe shullen comen in to his blysful fest
And with þat word tyburce his broþer cam
And whan that he þe þe sauour͗e vnder nam
Whiche that þe roses and þe lylys caste
Wiþ inne his herte he gan to woundere faste
¶ And seide I woundere this tyme off þe ȝer͗e
Whens þat sowte sauour͗e cometh so
Off Rose and lylie that I smelle her͗e
For þouȝ I hadde hem in myn hondes two
Þe sauour͗e myȝte in me no depper go
Þᵉ swete smeƚƚ þat in myn herte y fynde
Hath Chaunged me al in an other kynde
¶ Valaryan seyde two corouns haue we
Snow whithe and rose red þat shyneth cler͗e
Whiche that þin eiȝen haue no myȝt to se
And as þou smellest hem þoruȝ my pᵃrayer͗e
So schalt þou sen̄ hem my leue broþer der͗e
Ief it so be þou wilt with outen slouthe
Byleue ariȝt and knowen verry trouthe
¶ Tyburce Answerde sast þou thus to me
In soþenes or in drem̄ herkene þis
In dremes quod valarian haue we be
Vn to þis tyme brother myn Iwys
But now at erst in trouthe our͗e dwellynge is
How wost þou þis quod Tyburs in what wyse
Quod valeryan that I schaƚƚ þe deuyse
¶ The aungel of god hath me to trouthe Itauȝt
Whiche þou schalt se if that þou wolt reneye
Þyn Idoles and be clene and eƚƚlles nouȝt
And of þe miracle of þis corouns tweye
Seint ambrose in his p̉reface lust to seye
Solemply þis noble doctour͗e dere
Comendith hit and saiþ in this maner͗e
¶ The palme of martirdom̄ forto receyue
Seint Cecily Fulfillyd of goddes ȝifft
Þe world and eke hur͗e chaumbre gan sche weyue
Witnes Tyburce and Seint Cecilyes schrifft
To whiche god of his goodnes gan shifft
Corouns two of flouris well smellyngge
And made þe aungel hem þe corouns brynge
¶ The maiden hath brouȝt þe men to blysse a boue
The world hath wist what it is worth certeyn̄
Deuocioıı̄un off chastite to loue
Þo schewed him cecily open and playn̄
That all Idoles nys but þing in veyn̄
For þey ben dom̄ and þerto þey ben deue
And charged him his Idoles to leue
¶ Who noȝt þis trowith abeste he is
Quod þe Tyburce Ief þat I schall noȝt lye
She gan þan kysse his brest that herde this
And was fuƚƚ glad he couthe trouthe aspye
This day I take þe for myn alye
Saide this blisfull fair͗e maden der͗e
And aftir þat sche seide as ȝe may her͗e
¶ Lo riȝt so as þe loue of cⁱrist quod sche
Made me þy brothers wiff riȝt in þat wyse
Anon for myn̄ alye her͗e I take þe
Sithens þat þou wolt þyn Idoles dispice
Go with thi brother and þe Baptize
And make þe clene so þat þou mowe byholde
Þe aungeƚ face of whiche þy broþer tolde
¶ Tyburce answerde and seide brother dere
First telle me wheþer I schaƚƚ and to what mān
To whom ꝙquod he come forth with riȝt good cher͗e
I wol þe lede vn to þe pope vrban
To Vrban broþer myn Valerian
Quod þo tiburce wolt þou me thider lede
Me þenkith þat it were awounder dede
¶ Ne menest þou not Vrban ꝙquod he þo
That is so oftēn dampned to be ded
And woneth in halkes to and fro
And dar noȝt onys putte forth his hed
Men schuld him brenne in a fer͗e so Red
Ief he wer͗e foun̄de or that men men myȝt him spie
And we also to beren him compaignye
¶ And whiles we seken þilke deuynyte
That is Ihid in heuene preuely
Algate I brent in this world schulde we be
To whom Cecilye answerde boldely
Men myȝte drede weƚƚ and skillfully
Þis lijf to lese myn owne der͗e brother
Ief this were lyuynge and non̄ other
¶ But þer is better lyf in othur place
Þat neuer schall be lost ne drede þe nouȝt
Whiche goddes sone vs told þoruȝ his gᵃrace
That faders sone haþ aƚƚ thynges wrouȝt
And al that wrouȝt is with askilful þouȝt
Þe goost þat fram þe fader gan procede
Hath souled hem wiþ outen ony drede
¶ By word and by miracle hiȝ goddes sone
When he was in this world declared her͗e
That þer was othir lijf man may wone
To whom answerde tiburce oo suster dere
Seydest þou noȝt riȝt now in this maner͗e
That þer nys but oo god oo lord in sothfastnes
And now of þre how maist þou bere wittnes
¶ That schall I telle quod sche or that I go
Ryȝt as aman hath sapiences þre
Memorie engyne and intellecte also
So in oo beynge of diuinyte
Þre ꝑpersonys riȝt well þer mowe be
So gan sche him bysyly to preche
Off cristes sone and of his peynes teche
¶ And many poyntis of his passioıı̄un
How goddes in this world was with holde
To don̄ mankynde pleyn Remyssioıı̄un
That was bounden in synne and cares colde
Aƚƚ this þing sche vn to Tyburce tolde
And aftir þis tyburce in good entent
To pope Vrban he with valerian̄ went
¶ Whiche þankith god and with glad herte and lyȝt
He cristened him and made him in þat place
Parfijt in his lernynge goddes knyȝt
And aftir þis tiburce gate suche grace
That eủery day he saugh in tyme and space
The aıı̄ungel of god and eủery man̉er bone
That he god asked hit was I gᵃranted sone
¶ Hit were full hard by ordr͗e for to seyn̄
How many wounders iħuihesu for him wrouȝt
But att þe laste to tellen short and pleyn̄
The sergeauntes of þe toun̄ of Rome hem souȝt
And by forn̄ almacħ þe propheete hem brouȝt
Whiche hem apposed and knew all hir entent
And to þe ymage of Iubyter hem sent
¶ And seide who so wolnoȝt sacrifice
Swappe of his hed this is my sentence her͗e
Anon̄ þese martirs þat I ȝou deuyse
On maximus þat was an officer͗e
Off þe profectus and of þe cronyculer͗e
Hem hente and when he forth þe seintes ladde
Hym silf he wepte for pite þat he hadde
¶ Whan̄e maximus hadde herd þe seintis lore
He gate him of þe turmentoᵘurs leue
And ladde hem to his hous with outen mor͗e
And wiþ her͗e prechinge or þat it wer͗e eue
They gonne fro þe turmentour͗e to reue
And fro maxime and fro his folke ilkone
Þe fals feith / trowen in god allone
¶ Cecilye come when it was woxen nyȝt
With prestes that cristened him al in fer͗e
And aftirward whan day was woxen lyȝt
Cecily hem seide with a sobre cher͗e
Now cristes owne knyȝtis leeff and der͗e
Castith awey þe werkis of derkenes
And armetħ ȝou in armᵘur of lyȝtnes
¶ Ȝe haue forsothe don̄ agret bataiƚƚlle
Ȝour͗e cours is don̄ ȝour͗e feith haue ȝe conserued
Goth to þe coroune of lyff þat may not faylle
Þe Ryȝtful Iuge whiche that ȝe haue serued
Schal ȝeue it ȝow as ȝe haue it discerued
And when this thing was said as I deuyse
Men ladde him forth to do þe sacrifice
¶ But when þey wer͗e to þe place I brouȝt
To tellen schortely þe conclusioıı̄un
They nolde encense ne sacrifice riȝt nouȝt
But on̄ hir knees saten hem adoon̄
With humble herte and sad deuocioıı̄un
And losten bothe her hedes in that place
Her͗e soules wente to þe kyng of gᵃrace
¶ This maximus that saw this þing bytyde
With piteous teres he told it anon̄ ryȝt
That her soules saw he he to heuene glyde
With aungeles ful of clernes and of lyȝt
And wiþ his wordes couerted many awyȝt
For which Almacheus dede him so to bete
With whippys of led til he his lyf gan lete
¶ Cecily him toke and buried him anon̄
By Tiburce and valeryan softely
With inne hur͗e buryn̄g place vnder a ston̄
And after this Almachius hastely
Bad his mynystres fecchen openly
Cecily so sche riȝt in his p̉resens
Do sacrifice and Iubiter encence
¶ But they conuerted þoruȝ hir͗e wyse lor͗e
Wepten ful sore and ȝaff credence
Vn to hur͗e word and criden more and mor͗e
Crist goddes sone with outen difference
Is verry god þis is al our͗e sentence
That hath so good aʆseruaunt him to ʆserue
Thus with oo voys I trow þouȝ we sterue
¶ Almacheus þat herde of this þing
Bad fechen cecily þat he myȝt hur͗e se
And altherfirst lo this was his askyng
What man̉ere woman art þou ꝙquod he
I am agentil woman born̄ ꝙquod sche
I aske þe quod he þouȝ it þe greue
Off thy religioun̄ and of þy beleue
¶ Why þan be gan thy questioıı̄un folily
Quod sche þat woldest two answeres conclude
In on demaunde ȝe asken lewdely
Almache answerde to þat semylitude
Off when̄s cometh þyn answer so rude
Of conciens and of good feith vnfeined
Of whenns quod sche when þᵗat sche was afreyned
¶ Almacheus seyde takest þou non̄ hede
Off my power͗e and she answerde him this
Ȝour͗e myȝt quod sche ful litil is to drede
For eủery mortel man̄s power nys
But lyk abladder ful of wynd I wys
For with an nedeles poynt when it is blowe
May alle þe boste of hit be leid ful lowe
¶ Ful wrongfully began þou ꝙquod he
And ȝit in wrong is þy ꝑperceueraunce
Wost þou nouȝt nat how our͗e princes fre
Ben thus comaundid and mad ordinaunce
Þat eủery cristen wiȝt schaƚƚ haue penaunce
But þat he his cristendom̄ with seye
And gon al quyt ief he it wol Reneye
¶ Ȝour͗e princes erreth as ȝour͗e nobley dotħ
Quod tho cecily and with sentence
Ȝe make vs giltisse and it is nouȝt sotħ
For ȝe that knowen wel our͗e Innocence
For as meche as we don̄ areuerence
To crist and for we bern̄ a cristen name
Ȝe putt on vs a crym̄ and a blame
¶ But we that knowe þilke name also
For vertues we may it nouȝt wᵗithseye
Almache answerde chees of these two
Do sacrifice or cristendon̄ reneye
Þat mowe now askapen by þat weye
Att whiche this holy blisfuƚƚ maide
Gan for to laughe and to þe Iuge saide
¶ Iuge confus in thi nycite
Wolt thou that I reneye Innocence
To maken me a wicked wiȝt ꝙquod sche
Lo he dissimyletħ hern̄ in audience
He stareth and wodeth in his adủertence
To whom almachius oo vnsely wrecche
Ne wost þou noȝt how fer my myȝt may strecche
¶ Haue not our͗e myȝty princes to me ȝeuen
Ȝe bothen pour͗e and auctorite
To maken folk to dyen or to lyuen
Why spekest þou þan so proudely to me
I ne speke it noȝt but stidfastly ꝙquod sche
Nouȝt proudly for I say as for my side
I hate dedly þilke vice of pride
¶ And ȝif þou drede nouȝt asoth to her͗e
Then wƚƚ I schewen all openly by riȝt
Þat þou hast mad aful gret lesynge her͗e
Þou saist þi princes haue þe ȝeuen myȝt
Bothe to sle and for to queke awiȝt
Thou that maist noȝt but only lyff bereue
Thou hast non̄ oþer power ne no leue
¶ But þᵘou þᵘou maist se þy princes han þe maked
Mynystre of deth for ȝef þou speke of mo
Thou lyest for þy pouer͗e is ful naked
Do wey þy boldenes seide almacheus þo
And sacrifice oo god or two
I ne reche noȝt what wrong þou me profre
For I can suffere it as a philosophr͗e
¶ But þilke wronges may I nouȝt endur͗e
Þat þou spekest her͗e of our͗e goddes ꝙquod he
Cecily answerde oo nyce creatur͗e
Þou seidest no word sithes þou spekest to me
Þat I ne knew þer with þi nycite
And þat þu wer͗e in eủery maner wyse
A lewed offycer and a lewed Iustice
¶ Þer lakkyth nothing to þy nyce eyen̄
Þat þou nart blynd for þing þat we seyn̄ alle
That is aston̄ þat men mowe weƚƚ aspien̄
Þat þilke ston̄ a god þou wolt it calle
I Rede þe lete þyn hond vp on̄ hit falle
And tast it wel a ston̄ þou schalt it fynde
Syn that þou seest noȝt with þyn eien blynde
¶ Hit is a schame þat þe peple schaƚƚlle
So skorne þe and lauȝwe att þy folye
For comenly women wot it wel oủeral
That myȝti god in his heuens hye
And these ymages well thou maist aspye
To þe ne to thi silf may prophite
For in effecte þei be noȝt worth amyte
¶ This and suche other wordes sayde sche
And he wax wroth and bad men shulde hir lede
Hoom til hur͗e owne hous and in hir͗e hous ꝙquod he
Brenne hur͗e riȝt in abathe with flaumes rede
And as he bad riȝt so was don̄ þe dede
For in a bathe þey gonne hur͗e faste shitton̄
And nyȝt and day grett fuyr͗e ther͗e vnder they betton̄
¶ For all the fuyr͗e and eke the bathes hete
The longe nyȝt and eke þat day also
She sat al cold and felte of hit no wo
div.note: b
div.l: Hit made hur͗e nouȝt adrope for to swete
div.note: a
The scribe has reversed the order of lines 519 and 520, which has evidently led a corrector to reverse the next two lines as well.
div.l: But in that bathe hur͗e lyff sche muste lete
For he Almache with fuƚƚ wicked entent
To slen̄ hur͗e in þe bathes his sondes sent
¶ Þre strokes in þe necke he smot hur͗e þo
Þe turmentour͗e but for no maner͗e chaunce
He myȝt noȝt all hur͗e necke atwo
And for ther was that tyme an ordynaunce
Þat no man schulde do no man suche pen̄aunce
Þe forthe stroke for to smyte softe or sore
Þis tᵘurmentour͗e ne durste smyte smyte nomor͗e
¶ But half ded with hur͗e neccke he corue þer͗e
He lete hur͗e lye and on his wey he went
Þe cⁱristen folk whiche abouten hur͗e wer͗e
With scherdes han þe blood ful fayr͗e I hent
Thre dayes leued sche in this tᵘurment
And neủere cesed hem þe feith to preche
Þat sche had fostrid him sche gan to teche
¶ And hem sche ȝaf her͗e mebles and hur͗e thing
And to þe pope vrban betoke hur͗e þo
And seide I aske this of heuene kyng
To haue respite þre dayes and no mo
To recomende to ȝow or that I go
Þese soules loo and that I myȝte do wyrche
Her͗e of myn hous ꝑperpetuelly a chirche

fw.hi: The ꝓprolog of þᵉ Chanon̄s yoman

div.l: ¶ Seint Vrban with his dekenes pryuyly
The body fette and beried hit by nyȝte
Among his other seintes honestly
Hur͗e hous þe chirche of seint cecyly hight
Seint vrban halwyd hit as he wel myȝt
In whiche in to this day in noble wyse
Men don̄ to crist and to his seintis ʆseruyce
The ꝓprolog of þe Chanonez ȝoman here begynnetħ
WHan̄e that told was þe lyff of seint Cecyle
Or we hadde fully reden v myle
Att bouȝten vnder þe ble vs gan a take
Aman that clothid was in clothis blake
And vnder that he had awhit sinplice
His hakeney was of pomel grice
So swette he that woundir it was to se
Hit semed he hadde pⁱriked myles þre
Þe hors eek that a his a his ȝeman sat vp on̄
So swette eke þat vnneþis myȝt he gon̄
Aboute þe peitrelle stode þe fom̄ ful hiȝe
He was of fom̄ flecked as a pye
A male twy fold on his croupe lay
Hit semede þat he cariede litil aray
Al lyȝt for somᵘur rode this worthy man
And in myn herte to woundre y began
What that he was til þat I vnderstood
How that his cloke sowed was to his hode
For whiche whan I longe had avised me
I demed him sūm chanon̄ for to be
His hat hyng att his back doun̄ by alace
For he had reden more þan trot or pace
He hadde ay ay y pricked as he wer͗e wood
A cloote leef hadde he vndir his hood
For swote and for to kepen his hed from̄ hete
But it was ioye to sen̄ him swete
His forhed dropped as astillitorie
Wer͗e ful of planteyne ⁊and of peritorie
And whan that he cam he gan to crie
God saue quod he this ioly companye
Faste haue I pricked quod he for ȝour͗e sake
Be cause that I wolde ȝou atake
To riden in this meri cumpanye
This ȝeman was ful of curtesye
And seide siris now in the morwetyde
Out of ȝour͗e hostelerie I saw ȝow ride
And I warned anon̄ her͗e my souereyn̄
Whiche that with ȝou to riden is seyn̄
For his disport he loueþ daliaunce
Frend for thy warnynge god ȝeue þᵉ good chaıı̄unce
Þan seide our͗e ost For certeyn it wolde seme
Thi lord were wijs so may I well deme
He is ful iocounde also dar I say
Can he not telle amery tale or tway
Wiþ þe whiche glade he may this companye
Who sire my lord ȝhe ȝhe with outen lye
He can of merthe and iolyte
Nouȝt but Inowȝ so mote I þe
And ȝe him knew as wel as do I
Ȝe wolde woundre how weƚƚ and craftely
He wolde werchen and that in in in sondry wyse
He hath taken vp on̄ him many agret empryse
Wheche wer͗e ful hard for ony þat is here
To brynge about but þey of him it ler͗e
As homly as he rit amongis ȝou
Ief ȝe him knewe it wolde be for your͗e prow
Ȝe wol not for gon̄ his aqueyntaunce
For meche good I dar well leye in balaunce
Aƚƚ that I haue in posessioıı̄un
He is aman of hiȝ discressioıı̄un
I warne ȝow weƚƚ he is a passynge man
Wel quod our͗e hoost I pᵃraye þe telle me þan̄
Is he a clerk or non̄ I pᵃray þe telle me this
Nay he Is gretter þan a clerk Iwys
Seide this ȝeman and in these wordis fewe
Oost of his craft sumwhat wolle I schewe
I say my lord can siche sitillyte sitillyte sutillite
But all this craft ȝe may nouȝt wete of me
And sumwhat helpe I ȝit to his werkyngge
That al this ground on whiche we be rydynge
Til þat we come to canturbury toun̄
He coude al clene turne vp so doun̄
And paūe it al of siluer and of gold
And whan̄e this ȝeman hadde this tale told
Vn to our͗e hoost he seide benedicite
Þis thing is wounder meruelous to me
Sithen that thi lord is of so hiȝe prudence
Be cause of whiche men shuld him reuerence
Þat of his worschippe men Ricke so lyte
His ouer sloppe is not worth amyte
As in affect to him so mote I goo
Hit is aƚƚ baudy and to tore also
Whi is thy lord so slotisch I þe pᵃray
And is of power better clothis to bay
If that his dede acorde with this this thi speche
Telle me that and that I þe beseche
Why quod þe ȝeman wherto aske ȝe me
God helpe me so as he schall neủere þee
But I woll not avowe that I say
And therfor͗e kepe it secreet I ȝou pᵃray
He is to wys in feith as to my beleue
Þat þat is ouerdon̄ it woƚƚ not preue
And riȝt as clerkis seyn it is a vise
Wherfor͗e I holde him lewyd and nyce
For whan̄e aman hath ouer awitt
Full often mysschapen hym to mys vsen it
So dooþ my lord and þat me greued sore
God it amende I can seye nomor͗e
Þer of no force good ȝeman quod our͗e hoost
Sithens of þe kunnynge of þy lord þou wost
Telle how he doth I pᵃray þe hertely
Siþens he is so crafti and so sliȝe
Wher͗e dwelle ȝe if it to telle be
In þe subarbis of a toun̄ ꝙquod he
Lorkynge in hernes and in lanes blynde
Wher͗e as these robbers and þese theues by kynde
Holde her͗e preue feyr feyr and her͗e ful residence
As tho that dar not schewen her͗e presence
So fare we Ief I schall seie þe sothe
Now quod our͗e hoost lete me telle to the
Why art þou so discolorid of thy face
Petir quod he god ȝeue him hard gᵃrace
I am so vsed in þe fier to blowe
Þat it hath chaunged my colours I trowe
I am not wont in a mirrour͗e to pⁱrie
But swynke sore and lerne to multiplie
We blondren euer and pouer͗e in þe fier͗e
And for aƚƚ that we faylen of oure disir͗e
For eủere we lacke oure conclusioıı̄un
To meche folk we don̄ illusioıı̄un
And Borwe gold be it apound or two
Or ten or xij or many a sūmme mo
And make hem wene at þe leste wey
Þat of a pound he coude make twey
Ȝit it is fals and ay we han good good hope
Hit for to don̄ / and aftir it for to grope
But that science is so fer vs beforn̄
We may not al they we hadde it sworn̄
It oủeretake / it sclit awey so faste
It woƚƚ vs make beggers att þᵉ laste
Whilis this ȝeman was thus in this talkynge
This chanon̄ drowȝ him neer and herde al þing
Off whiche this ȝeman spak for suspecioıı̄un
Off mens speche eủere hadde thys chanoıı̄un
For caton̄ seith he that gilti is
Demeþ al thing be spoke of him Iwys
That was þe cause he gan so nyȝ him drawe
This ȝeman to harkene all his sawe
And thus he seide to his ȝemān þo
Holde thow thy pees and seie no wordis mo
For if thou do / þou schalt it riȝt weel abie
Thou sklaundrist me her͗e in this cūmpanye
And eek discouerist þat þou schuldist hide

fw.hi: The tale of þᵉ Chanon͒s yoman

div.l: Ȝhe quod our͗e hoost teƚƚ on what so bitide
Off all this þretinge I sett it noȝt att a myte
In feith quod he nomor͗e do I but a lite
And whan̄e þe chanon̄ siȝ it wol not be
But that his ȝeman wolde telle his pⁱriuyte
He fledde awey for v̉ery wo and schame
Aha quod þe ȝeman her͗e schaƚƚ risen a game
All that I can anon̄ riȝt wol I telle
Sithen he is goȝ þe foule fend him qwelle
For neuer her aftir woll I wᵗith him mete
For peny ne for pound I ȝou behete
He that me first brouȝte in to that game
Or that he die sorwe he haue and schame
For it ernest to me is by my feith
That fele I wele what ony man seiþ
And ȝit for all my smert ⁊and for al my greef
For all my labour͗e sorwe and myschyff
I coude it neủere leue in no wyse
Now wolde god my wittis wolde suffyce
To tellen alle þat longeþ to þat art
And neþeles ȝou wolle I tellen a part
Sithens my lord is gon̄ I woll not spare
Siche thing as I knowe I wol declare
WIth this chanon̄ dwelled haue I vij ȝer͗
Iit of his science am I neủer þe neer
Al that I hadde I haue lost þer by
And god wote so han mo þan I
Ther I was wont to be riȝt Fresch and gay
Of clothinge and of oþ̉er good aray
Now I may wer͗e an hose vpon̄ myn hed
And where my coloᵘur was fressch and red
Now it is wan and of ledin hewe
Who so it vsith sore schaƚƚ him rewe
And of my swynk blerid is myn iȝe
Lo siche a vauntage is to multiplie
That sclidinge science hath mᵃd me so bar͗e
That I haue no good wher͗e þat eủere I far͗e
And ȝit I am endetit so þer by
Off gold that I haue borwed þer by
That whiles I leue I schal it quite neủere
Lete eủery man be ware of of by me for euere
What maner man that castith him ther to
Ief he contenue I holde his thrift I do
For so helpe me god þer by schal he not wyn̄ne
But empte his purs and make his wittis þinne
And whan̄e he þoruȝ his madnes and folye
Hath lost his owne good by gipardie
Þan he exitiþ oþer folk þer to
To lese hir͗e good as he him silf hath do
For vn to schrewes Ioye it is an ese
div.note:
Consolac̄io miseroꝝrum est ħhabere
consortes in pena
div.l: To han hir felowys in peyne and in disese
Þus was I onis lerned of a clerk
Off that no charge I woƚƚ speke of oᵘure werk
Whan̄e we ben̄ ther as we schullen exercise
Our͗e eluysch craft than we semen wyse
Oure termes ben so clergial and so qweynte
I blowe þe fier til that myn herte feynte
What schulde I telle yche porcion̄
Off thingis whiche we worchin vp on̄
And on v or vjj vjj vj vncis may wel be
Off syluer or of sum other quantite
And bisie me to telle all þe names
Off orpyment brent salt iren squames
That in to pouder ben̄ grounden ful smal
And in an erthen pott how putt is aƚƚ
And salt I put in and also paper
To fore þese powdris that I spak of eer
And weel I couerid with alambike of glas
And of meche thing whiche ther was
As of þe pott and glasis latinge
Þat out þe er myȝt passe nothinge
And of þe esy Fyre and smert also
Whiche that was maad ⁊and ⁊and of þe þe care and wo
That we hadde in our͗e matres sublemynge
And in almagan̄ynge and calcenynge
Off quik siluer I cleped merkerie crude
For all our͗e sleȝte we conne not conclude
Oure orpyment and sublymed mercurie
Oure ground litarge eke on þe purferie
And eche of these of vncis acertein
Nouȝt helpiþ vs our͗e labour͗e is in veyn̄
Ne eke our͗e spiritis ascensioıı̄un
Ne our͗e meterials liggynge al fix adoun̄
May in our͗e workynge nothing vs auayle
For lost is all oure labour͗e and our͗e trauayle
And all thing and cast atwynti deuel wey
Is lost also / whiche we on it ley
Þer is also full many an oþer thing
Þat is vn to our͗e craft aꝑperteynynge
Þouȝ I be ordre nouȝt him reherce can
Be cause that I am alewed man
Ȝit wol I telle hēm as þey come to mynde
Þouȝ I can not sette hem in hir͗e kynde
As bool armonyak and veerdegrees
And son̄dry vesseƚƚlles maad of erthe and glas
Oure vrinaƚƚlles and our͗e discentories
Violettis cruselitis and sublimytories
Concurbitis and alembikis eek
And other siche dere Inow aleke
As arsnyk sal armonyak and brymston̄
Off eerbis coude I telle eke many on̄
As egremoyne valerian and lunarie
And other siche if that me luste to tarie
Oure laumpis brennynge boþe be nyȝt and day
To brynge about our͗e craft If þat we may
Oure furneys eke and our͗e calcinacioıı̄un
And of watris Albificacioıı̄un
Vnslecked lyme chalk ⁊and gleire of an ey
Pouders dyuers dung asschen and cley
Serid poketis sal petir and vitriol
Off dyuers wodes mad of fier͗e and cole
Sal tartari alkeili ⁊and sal p̉reparate
Clay mad with hors heer or man̄nes and oyle
Off tartarie alum glas berm wort ⁊and argoyle
Reisalgar and othir maters enbibinge
And eek oure maters encorporynge
And of oure siluer citrinacioıı̄un
Oure sementynge and oure fermentacioıı̄un
I woll ȝow telle as me was tauȝt also euene
Þe foure spiritis and þe bodies seuene
By ordre as I herde my lord neuene
Wheche were compowned wᵗith maistris seuene
The firste spirit quyk siluer callyd is
Þe seconde orpyment þe þridde I wis
Sal armonyak þe fourthe brymston̄
Þe bodies seuene lo hēm eke her͗e anon̄
Sol gold is ⁊and luna siluer we trepe
Mars iren mercurie quyksiluer we clepe
Saturnes leed Iupetir tyn
And venus copur bi my fader kyn
This cursed crᵃft whos wole exc̉erecise
He schal no good haue that may him suffice
For al the good he spendeth þer aboute
He lese schall þer of haue I no doute
Who that lustiþ to outen his folye
Lete him come forth and lerne to multiplye
And eủery man that auȝt hath hath in his cofre
Lete him apeyr͗e an wexe a philosophr͗e
Askance þat craft is so liȝt to lere
Nay nay god woot al be he monk or frere
Prest or chanon or ony oþer wiȝt
Þouȝ he sitte att his book day and nyȝt
In lernynge of this eluysch nyce lore
Al is in veyn̄ ⁊and ꝑparde meche more
To lere alewed man this subtilite
Fiȝe speke noȝt þer of it wol not be
And kun̄e he letterure or kun̄e he non̄
As in affect he schall fynde it al on
Boþe two by my sauacioıı̄un
Concluden in multiplicacioıı̄un
Iliche wel wehen þey haue al I do
This is to seyn̄ þey fayle boþe two
Ȝit forȝate I to my rehersaile
Of watir corosyues and of lymaile
And of bodies mollificacioıı̄un
And also of her͗e induracioıı̄un
Oilis oblucioıı̄un and metals fusible
Te tellen al wolde passen abible
Þat ouȝwher͗e is wherfor͗e as for þe beste
Of alle these names now woll I reste
For as I trowe I haue ȝou told Inowȝ
To areisey afend be he neủere so rouȝ
Anay abide ȝit þer is a philosopher ston̄
Alexer cleped is seche we faste suche on̄
For hadde we him þan wer͗e we seker ynowȝ
But vn to god of heuene we make avow
For all our͗e craft whan we haue al I do
And al oure sleiȝte he wol not come vs to
He haþ mᵃd vs spende meche good
For sorwe of whiche we wexen almost wood
But that good hope crepeth in our͗e herte
Supposynge eủere þouȝ we sore smertte
To be releued by him aftir ward
Siche supposynge of hope ben hard and scharp
I warne ȝow wel it is to seken eủere
Þat future temps haþ mᵃd men to seủere
In trust þer of from all that eủere þey hadde
Ȝit of that art they kun̄e noȝt wexe sadde
For to hēm it is a bitter swete
So semeþ it for hadde they but a shete
In whiche he myȝte wrappe his body anyȝt
And abak for to walwen in bi day liȝt
They wolde hem sille and spende on that crᵃft
They can not stinte til noþing be laft
And eủeremore wher͗e eủere that þey gon̄
Men may hem knowe by smyƚƚ of þe brymston̄
For alle þe wᵒrld þey stynke as a goot
Þe sauour͗e is so rāmmysch and so hoot
That þouȝ from aman amyle be
The sauour͗e wolle enfecte him trustiþ me
Lo thus by smellynge and by þredbar͗e aray
If men list / these folk knowe may
And If aman wolle aske him pⁱriuyly
Whi they be cloþid so vnthriftely
They riȝt anon̄ woll rowne in his eere
And seye if that þei aspied were
Men wolde him sle be cause of hir science
Lo thus þese folk betᵃraen ynnocence
Passe ouer this I go my tale vnto
Or that þe pott be on þᵉ feer I do
Of metals wᵗith acerteyn qwantite
My lord him tempriþ and non̄ but he
Now he is gon̄ I dar wel seye boldely
For as men say he can well craftely
Algate I wote wel he haþ suche a name
And ȝit full ofte he ryn̄nyth in blame
And woot ȝe houȝ full often it fallith so
The pott to brekith and fare well al is go
These metals ben of so gret violence
Our͗e walles ne may not make her resistence
They ꝑpersen so and þoruȝ þe walles þey gon̄
Þouȝ þey wer͗e mad of lyme and ston
And sum of hem synken in to þe ground
Thus haue we lost by tymes many apound
And sum ben flaterid all þe floore aboute
Sum lepen in to þe roof with outen doute
Þouȝ that þe fend noȝt in our͗e siȝt him schewe
I trowe he be with vs þilke schrewe
In helle þer that he is lord and sire
Nis þer more woo of rankour͗e ne of ire
Whanne that our͗e pott is broken as ȝe haue herd said
Euery man chit and holdeþ hīm euel payed
Sum seyden it was longe on þe fer͗e makynge
Sum seye nay but on þe fire blowynge
Than was I ferd for þat was myn offyce
Straw quod þe þridde ȝe ben lewid and nyce
It was noȝt temꝑperit as it ouȝte to be
Nay quod þe fourthe stinte and herkene me
Be cause that our͗e feir͗e is noȝt mᵃd of bech
That is þe cause and other non̄ so thech
I can not telle where on it was a long
But well I woot gret strijf is þer among
What quod my lord þer nys nomor͗e to done
Off this ꝑperill I wol be ware eftsone
I am riȝt siker that this pot was cᵃrasid
Be as be may be ȝe no þing amasid
As vsage is lete swepe þe flore as swethe
Pluk vp ȝoure herte and be ech glad and bleþe
The mullok on an hepe swopen was
And on þe floore cast a canvas
And al the mullok a sidis þrowe
And sifftid and pickid many a þrowe
ꝐParde quod on̄ sumwhat of our͗e metal
Ȝit is þer here þouȝ we haue not al
And þouȝ this þing myˢhappe as now
An oþer tyme it may be well I nouȝ
Vs must putte our͗e good in auentur͗e
Amarchaunt ꝑparde may not alwey endur͗e
Trustiþ me weel in his prosꝑperite
Sumtyme his good is dreynt in þe see
And sumtime it comeþ saaf vn to þe lond
Pees quod my lord þe nexte tyme I wol fond
To brynge our͗e craft / all in an other plite
And but I do sire lete me haue þe wite
Þer was defaute sumwhat well I woot
An oþ̉ere side þe fier was ouer hoot
But be it hoot or cold I dar seye this
That we concluden eủeremor͗e amys
We faylen of that werk we woƚƚ haue
And in our͗e madnes eủeremor͗e we raue
And whan we ben to geders ecchon̄
Eủery man semeþ as salomon̄
But all thing that semeþ gold
div.note:
Ne teneas aurūm tom̄tum quod
spēldet vt aurum
div.l: Nis not gold as I haue herd told
But eủery appil that is fayr͗e att iȝe
Nis not good what so men clappe or crie
Ryȝt so farit it amongis us
He that semeþ wisest bi IħcIhesus
Is most fool whan it comyþ to þe preef
And he that semeþ trewest is a þeef
That schullen ȝe knowe so that I fro ȝou wende
By that I of my tale haue mᵃd an ende
Ther is achanon of religioıı̄un
Amongis vs wolde enfecte al atoun̄
Þouȝ it as gret wer͗e as neneue
Rome alisaıı̄undre troie and suche iij
Ther couþe noman write as I gesse
His sleȝtis and his infynyte falsnes
Þeiȝ that he myȝte lyue a þousend ȝer͗e
In alle this world of falsnes is his pere
For in his termes he wol him so wynde
And speken his wordis in so hiȝ akynde
Whanne he comune schal with ony wiȝt
What he ne wolle make him dote ariȝt
But it afeend be as him silf is
Ful many aman haþ he begild or this
And wole if that he lyue ony while
And ȝit mēn riden and gon̄ ful many a myle
Him for to seke and for to haue his aqueyntaıı̄unce
Noȝt knowynge of his fals gouernaunce
And ȝif that ȝe liste to ȝe me audience
I woll it tellen her͗e in ȝour͗e presence
But worschipful chanon̄s relegious
Ne demeþ not that I schlaundre ȝour͗e hous
Al þouȝ my tale of a chanon̄ be
Off eủery ordre sum schrewe is ꝑparde
And god forbede that aƚƚ a companye
Shuld rewe asinguler man̄nys folye
To sklaundre ȝou it is noþing myn entent
But to corecten þat is mys I ment
This tale is not oonly told for ȝou
But eek for othir mo ȝe weten wel how
That among cristis apƚostolis twelue
Ther was no creature cursid / saue iudas hīm silue
Than̄e why schulde the remenānt haue blame
That gilteles weren to ȝou I seye the same
Saue only this if ȝe wol herkene to me
Ief ony Iudas in ȝour͗e couent be
Remembriþ him betymes I ȝow rede
Ief schame or loos be cause of ony dede
And beth nothing displesed I ȝou pᵃray
But in this cas harkene what I schall say
In london̄ was a preest an an̄wiler
That þer Inne hadde dwellid many aȝer͗
Which was so plesaunt and so ʆseruysable
Vn to þe wijf ther he was att þe table
That sche nolde noþing suffre him to paye
For boord ne for clothinge wente he neủer so gay
And spendinge siluer hadde he riȝt Inouȝ
Ther of no force I woll procede as now
And telle forth my tale of þe chanoıı̄un
That brouȝte this preest to confusioıı̄un
This fals chanon̄ cam vp on̄ a day
Vn to this preestis chaūmbre þer he lay
Besechinge him to lene hi͒m acerteyn
Off gold and he wolde quyte him ageyn̄
Lene me amark but dayes þre
And at my day I woll quyte it þe
And if so be þou fynde me fals
Anoþ̉er day hange me by þe hals
This preest him toke amark and that a a swithe
And this chanon̄ him þankid fele siþe
And toke his leue and wente forth his way
And the þridde day brouȝte his monay
And to the preest he took his gold ageyn̄
Wherof this p̉rest was woundir glad and feyn̄
Certis quod he nothing anoyeþ me
To lene aman a noble or two or thre
Or what thing wer͗e in myn possessioıı̄un
Whane he so trewe is of condicioıı̄un
That in no wyse breken he woƚƚ his day
To suche a man I can not seye nay
What quod this chanon̄ schuld I be so vntrewe
Nay þat were thing fallen on þe newe
Trouthe is a thing that I wol euer kepe
Vn to þat day I schaƚƚ in erþe crepe
Bileeueþ þis as siker as is ȝour͗e crede
Þat in suche fantesie may sorwe brede
God þanke I ⁊and in good tyme be it seid
Þat þer was neủer man ȝit yuel paied
For gold no siluer þat he me lente
Ne neủer falshed in myn herte mente
And sire quod he of my pⁱriuyte
Sithens ȝe so goodly han̄ ben to me
And kithid to me so gret gentilnes
Sumwhat to quyten wiþ ȝour͗e kyndenes
I wol ȝou schewe and if ie list to lere
I wol ȝou telle playn̄li playn̄ playn̄li þe mater
How I can worche in philosophie
Takith good heede ȝe schullen well sen̄ at iȝe
That I woll don̄ amaistrie or that I go
Ȝhe quod þe preest leue sir͗e and wol ȝe so
Mary þerof I pᵃray yow hertely
At ȝour͗e comaundement sire truly
Quod the chanon̄ and eƚƚlles god forbede
Lo how þe þeef coude his seruyce hede
Forsothe it is þat suche prouerid ʆseruyce
Stynkith that witnesseþ þe colde wyse
And that ful sone I wol it ferefie
In this chanon rote of all trecherie
That eủeremor͗e delite hath and gladnes
Suche fendly þouȝtis in his herte exp͗res
How cristis peple he may to myschif bryngge
God kepe vs from̄ his fals disseymylynge
Now wist not this preest wᵗith hom̄ he melte
Ne non̄ of his harm̄ comynge he felte
O cely prest oo cely Innocent
With coueityse anon̄ þou schalt be blent
O graceles ful blynd is thi concente
Nothing art þou war of þi disceyte
Whiche that this fox haþ schapen to þe
His wile wrenchis þou maist not fle
Wherfore to goon̄ to conclusioıı̄un
That referreþ to þy confusioıı̄un
Vnhappy man anon I woll me hiȝe
To tellen þin vnwit and þi folye
And eek thi falsnes of þᵗat oþer wrecche
As ferforþ as my kūnnynge wolde strecche
This chanon was my lord ȝe wol wene
Sire oost in feith and by heuene qwene
Hit was an oþ̉er chanon̄ and not he
That can an hundrid fold more of subtilite
He hath betᵃraied folkis many atyme
Off his falsnes it dulliþ me to ryme
Euer whan that I speke of his falshede
For schame of him my chekes wexen rede
Algatis þey beginne to glowe
For rednesse haue Inoū wel I knowe
In my visage for fumes dyuers
Of metals whiche ȝe han herd me reherse
Consumed and wastid haþ my reednes
Now takith hede of þis chanon̄s cursidnes
Sers quod this chanon̄ late my ȝeman goon
For quik siluer and þat I it hadde anoon̄
And lete him brynge vncis two or thre
And whan̄e he comyþ as faste schul ȝe se
A woundir thing whiche ȝe say neủer or this
Sire quod the preest it schall be don I wys
He bad his ʆseruaıı̄unt fecchin him this his this thing
And he all redy was at his biddyng
And wente him forth and come anon̄ aȝen̄
With this quik siluer schortly for to seien̄
And toke þese vnces þan to þe chanoıı̄un
And he him leide ful fayr͗e adoıı̄un
And bad þe seruaunt colys for to brynge
That he anon̄ myȝte knowe his worchinge
Þe colys ryȝt anon̄ weren I fet
And this chanon̄ took out a cruselet
Off his bosme and schewede it þe prest
This instrument quod he whiche þou seest
Take it in þyn hond and put þi silf þer ynne
Off this quiksiluer an vnce and þer bygȳnne
In the name of crist to wexen a filoosofre
Ther ben but fewe to whom I wolde it profre
To schewen hem thus meche of my science
For ȝe schullen her͗e seen bi exꝑperience
That this quik siluer I woll here mortefie
Riȝt in ȝour͗e siȝt her͗e anon̄ wᵗithouten lye
And make it as good siluer and as fyn̄
As þer is ony in ȝour͗e purs or in myn
Or eƚƚlles where and make it malliable
And eƚƚlles holdeth me fals and vnable
Amonges folk for eủere to aper͗e
I haue a pouder her͗e that cost me der͗e
Shall make al good for it is cause of aƚƚ
My kunnynge whiche I ȝou schewe schall
Voydiþ ȝoure man and lete him be þer oute
And schittiþ þe dore whiles we ben þer aboute
Oure pⁱriuyte / that no man vs aspie
Whiche that we worchyn in this filosophie
Ay as he bad was fulfild in dede
This ilke seruant anon̄ riȝt out ȝede
And his maistir schitte þe dore anon̄
And to their labour͗e spedely þey gon̄
This prest att this cursed chanon̄s biddinge
Vp on þe fer anon̄ he sette þis thing
And blew þe fer and besiede him riȝt faste
And þis chanon̄ in þis cruselite caste
A pouder wher of I not it was
I mad it was of chalk or of glas
Or sumwhat eƚƚlles was not worth a flie
To blynde with þis p̉rest and bad him hiȝe
The colys for to couche al aboue
Þe cruselte for in tokenynge I þe loue
Quod this chanon̄ wᵗith þin hondis two
Schullen worche all þing ȝour͗e silf or I go
Graunt merci quod the preest and was ful glad
And couched þe colis eủere as he bad
And while he bisi was þis fendly wreche
This fals chanon̄ þe foule fend him fecche
Out of his bosum toke abechin cole
In whiche fuƚƚ sutilly was mad an hole
And þer Inne was putt of syluer lymaile
An vnce and stopped was wiþ outen faile
This hole wᵗith wex to kepe þis lymaile In
And understonditħ that this fals gy m n gym gyn
div.note: The scribe has simply erased the final minim.
div.l: Was not mᵃd þere but it was mᵃd afore
And other thinges as I schaƚƚ telle more
Here aftirward whiche that he wᵗith him brouȝte
Or he cam þer͗e / to bigile hīm he þouȝte
And so he dede or that he wente atwyn̄ne
Til he hadde turned him coude he noȝt blynne
It dullith me whan I of him speke
On̄ his falshede fayn wolde I me Wreke
And I wiste wher͗e / but he is þer͗e and her͗e
He is so variaun̄t he abidith no wher͗e
But takith hede now for cristis loue
He toke his cole of whiche I spak aboue
And in his hondis he bare it pⁱriuely
And whiles þe preest couched bisily
The colis as I ȝow or this
This chanon̄ seide frend ȝe dōn amys
This is not couchid as it ouȝte to be
But sone I schall amenden it quod he
Now lete me medle þer with alitil while
For of ȝou haue I pite by seint gile
Ȝe ben riȝt hote I se well how ȝe swete
Haue here a cloþ and wipe away þe swete
And whiles that þe preest wipede his face
This chanon̄ took his cole god ȝeue him sori gᵃrace
And leide it aboue an onward
Off þe cruselite and blewe wel aftirward
Til that þe cole gan faste bren̄e
Now ȝeue vs drinke quod þe chanon̄ þan̄e
As swiþe al schal be wel I vndirtake
Sitte vs doun̄ and lete vs meri make
And whan this chanon̄s bechen cole
Was brent and al þe lymaile out of the hole
In to þe cruselt it fel anon doun
And so it muste nedes bi resoun̄
Sithens it aboue so euene was
But þerof wist þe prest noȝt allas
He demeþ alle þe colis I like good
For of that sleȝte he no thing vnderstod
And whanne þᵗat þᵗat this alkamystre siȝ his tyme
Ryse vp sire preest and stond bi me
And for I wote wel Ingote haue I non̄
Goth walkith forth and brynge me achalk ston̄
For I make it wole of þe same schapp
Þat is an yngote if I may haue happ
Doeþ brynge with ȝou eke a bolle and a panne
Ful of water and ȝe schul se þanne
How that our͗e besynes schall þryue and preue
And ȝit for ȝe schulle not haue no mysbileue
Ne wrong conceite in me in ȝour͗e abscence
I wol not ben out of your͗e presence
But go wiþ ȝow and come wiþ ȝow aȝeyn
Þe chaūmbre dore schortely for to seien
Þey openden and schitten and wente hir͗e way
And forth wiþ hēm þei caried þe key
And comen aȝen wᵗithouten ony dilay
What schulde I tarien all þe longe day
He toke þe chalk and schop it in þis wyse
Off an yngote as I schal yow dyuese
I say he took out of his owne sleue
Ateyne of siluer euel mote he þryue
Whiche that was but an vnce of weiȝte
And takiþ hede of this cursed sleiȝte
He schop this yngote in lengþe and brede
Off this teyne wᵗithouten ony drede
So sliȝly that þe preest it noȝt aspieþ
And in his sleue anon̄ aȝen̄ it hiȝeþ
And fro þe fier͗e he took vp his matere
And in the yngote putte it wiþ meri chere
And ıı̄ n̄ īn the water vessel he it caste
Whanē þat him liste and bad þe p̉rest as faste
Loke what þer͗e is putt in þin hond an grope
Þou fynde schall siluer I hope
What deuel of helle schuld it ellis be
Shauynge of siluer / siluer is it ꝑparde
He putt in his hond and toke vp ateyne
Off siluer fyn / and glad in euyry veyn
Was this preest whan he saw it was so
Goddis blessynge and his moders also
And al halwis haue ȝe sir͗e chanoıı̄un
Seide this preest and I hir͗e malisoıı̄un
But ȝe vouchesauf to teche me
Þis noble craft and this noble sutilite
I wol be ȝoure in all that eủery may
Quod this chanon̄ ȝit wole I make asay
The secunde tyme that ȝe mowe take hede
And ben̄ expert in this and in ȝour͗e nede
Anoþ̉er day asay in myn absence
This discipleyne and þis crafti science
Lete take an oþer ounce quod he þo
Of quyk siluer with outen wordis mo
And dooþ þerwiþ as ȝe han don̄ or þis
With þat oþer / whiche now siluer is
This prest him besieþ in all that eủere he can
To don aftir þis chanon̄ þis cursid man
Comaıı̄undiþ him and faste to blowe þe fer͗e
For to come to þe effect of his desir͗e
And this chanon̄ in þe mene while
Al redy was þe prest to bigile
And for a contenaunce in his hond bare
An holwe sticke take keep̄ and be war͗e
In þe ende of whiche an vn̄ce and more
Of siluer lymaile put was as bifore
In his sticke and stoppid wiþ wex weel
For to kepe in his lymayle eủery dele
And whilis þis preest was in his besines
This chanon̄ with his sticke gan him dresse
To hiȝen anon̄ and his pouder caste in
As dede eer͗e þe deuel brynge him out of his skyn
Him to sterne I pᵃray god for his falshede
For he was euer fals in þouȝt and dede
And wᵗith this abouen þe Cruselet
Þat was ordeyned with þe false get
He st̉eride þe colis til it relente by gan
Þe wex ayen þe fer woot eủery man
But it be afole knowith it mote nede
And þat in þe sticke was out it ȝede
And in þe cruselet hastely it fel
Now gode siris what wolle ȝe þānne bet þān wel
Whan̄ne þat þis prest was thus bigilid ayen
Supposynge noȝt but trouþᵉ soþe to seyn̄
He was so glad I can not expresse
In no man̉ere his merthe and his gladnesse
And to þe chanon̄ he profrid eftsone
Body and good ȝhe quod this chanon̄ sone
Þouȝ pore I be crafti þou schalt me fynde
I warne þe þe ȝit þer is more by hynde
Is þer coꝑper her͗e ȝeue hit seide he
Ȝhe quod þe prest I trowe þer be
Eƚƚlles I schaƚƚ lete bie sum and þᵗat as sweþe
Now good sir͗e go þy wey and hiȝe þe
He wente his way and with this coꝑper cam
And þis chanon it in his hond nam
And of that coper weied vp an vnce
Al to symple is my witt to pronounce
His misteri in my wit þe doubelnes
Off this chanon̄ rote of all his his cursidnes
He semede frendly to hem that knewe hīm not
But he was fendly boþᵉ in werk and þouȝt
Hit werieþ me to tellen of his falsnes
And neþeles ȝit woƚƚ I it expresse
He putte this vn̄ce of of coꝑper in þe cruselet
And on þe feir͗e also swithe he hath it set
He putte this vn̄ce of coꝑper in þe cruselet
And on þe fier also swithe he haþ it sett
And cast in pouder and maad þe preest to blowe
And in his worchinge for to stoupen lowe
As he dede eer and all was but a Iape
Ryȝt as him lust þe p̉rest he maad an ape
Aftirward in þe yngote he it caste
And in þe pānne putte it at þe laste
Of watir / and he putte his owne hond
And in his sleue as he be fore fond
Ȝe herde me telle he hadde a siluer teyne
He sliȝly took it out þis cursid hine
Vnwittynge þis preest of þis fals craft
And in this pannys botme he hath it laft
And in þe watir rumblyd to and fro
And woundir pⁱriuely took it vp also
Þe coꝑper tyne not knowynge þe prest
And hid it and hente him bi þe brest
And to him spak and thus seide on his game
Stoupiþ a doun̄ bi god ȝe ben to blame
Helpiþ me now as ȝe dede while eer͗e
Puttiþ in ȝour͗e hond and loke what is þer͗e
The prest toke vp þe siluer teyne anon̄
And þan̄e seide þe chanon̄ lete vs gon̄
Wiþ þese þre tynes whiche we han wrouȝt
To sum gold smyth and wete wher͗e þei ben ouȝt
For by my feith I nolde for myn hood
But if they wer͗e siluer fyn and good
And that as swithe proued schall it be
Vn to þe goldsmyth wᵗith þese teynys þre
Þey wente and putte þese teynys in asay
To fier͗e and hamber þer myȝt noman seye nay
But þat þei wer͗e as þei ouȝte to be
This lewed prest who was gladder þan he
Þer was neuer brid gladdir aȝen̄ day
Ne þe nyȝthyngale in þe meri mornynge of may
Ther nas neủere non̄ that liste better to synge
Ne ladi lustier in Carolynge
Or for to speke of loue or womanhede
Ne knyȝt in armes to don̄ an hardy dede
To stonden in gᵃrace of his ladi dere
Than̄e hadde this prest this craft to lere
And to the chanon̄ þus spak and seide
For þe loue of god that for vs alle deide
And as I may deseruen vn to ȝou
What schaƚƚ this resette coste me now
Now bi our͗e ladi quod this Chanon̄ it is der͗e
I warne ȝou saue I and a frere
In yngelond þer can noman it make
No fors quod he now sire for goddis sake
What schal I paye telle me y pᵃray
I wis quod he it is ful der͗e y say
Ser͗e att o word if the liste it haue
Ȝe schul paye fourti pond so god me saue
And ner þe frenschippe þat ȝe dede to me or þis
To me ȝe schul paye mor͗e I wis
Þis preest þe sum̄e of fourti poıı̄und anon̄
Of noblis to fette vn to hīm gan he gon̄
The chanon̄ to haue for þis ilke resceite
Aƚƚ his worchinge nas but fraude as disceite
Sir͗e prest he seide I kepte ȝe hadde no loos
Of my craft y wolde it were kept in cloos
And kepeþ it secrete as ȝe loue me
For and men knowen all my subtillite
Bi god þey wolde haue so gret enuye
To me bi cause of philosofie
I schuld be ded þ̉er n̉er non othir wey
God it forbede quod þe prest what ȝe sey
Ȝit hadde I leuer spenden aƚƚ þe good
With þat I haue and eƚƚlles lepe I wood
Þan þat ȝe schullen fallen in suche myschif
For ȝour͗e good wille sir͗e haue ȝe good preef
Quod þe chanon̄ and feireweƚƚ gᵃrant mercy
He wente his wey and neủere eft þe preest sey
Aftir þat day and whan̄e þe preest schulde
Maken asay att siche atyme he wolde
Off this receite fare wel it wol not be
Lo thus beiapped and bigilid was he
Þus makiþ he his introduccioıı̄un
To bringe folk to hur͗e distruccioıı̄un
Co͒nsederiþ siris how that in suche astate
Betwix men and gold þer is gret debate
So ferforth þat vnneþis is þer non̄
This multepliynge blent so many on̄
That in good feith I trowe þat þer be
Þe cause grettest of whiche is skarcite
Fylosofris speken so myȝtily
In this craft þat men can not come þer by
For ony witt þat men now haue adayes
Þey may wel chiteryn and don̄ þese iayes
And in hur͗e termes setten hir lust and peyne
But to othir purpoos schul þey neủere ateyne
Aman may liȝtly lerne if he haue ouȝt
To multiplie and to brynge his good to nouȝt
So suche a lucre is in þis lusti game
Amans merthe it wol turne in to gᵃme
And emptyn also greet and heuy pursis
And maken folk for to purchasen cursis
Of hem þᵗat han hir good þer to lent
O fiȝ for schame þey þᵗat haue be brent
Alas kun̄e þei not fle þe fery hete
Ȝee þat vse it I rede he it lete
Lest ȝe lese al for bet þan̄ neủer is late
Neuer to þryue it wer͗e to longe a date
Þouȝ ȝe frolle eủere ȝe schul it neủere fynde
Ȝe ben as bold as is baiard þe blynde
That blundriþ forþ and ꝑperil castiþ non̄
He is as bold to renne ayen̄s aston̄
As for to gon̄ besides in þe wey
So far͗e ȝe that multiplie y sey
Ief ȝour͗e iȝen conn̄e not seen ariȝt
Loke that ȝour͗e mynde lacke not his siȝt
For thouȝ ȝe loke neuer so brod and stare
Ȝe schullen noþing wynnyn in this chaffar͗e
But waste all that ȝe may rappe an renne
Wiþdrawith þe fier͗e lest it so faste brenne
Medlyth nomore wiþ þat art I mene
And ȝif ȝe don̄ your͗e þrift is gon clene
And riȝt as swiþe I woll yow tellen her͗e
And What þe philosophre seyen̄ in þis mater͗e
Lo þus seiþ arnold of þe new toun̄
As his rosarie makith mencioıı̄un
He seith riȝt þus wᵗithouten lye
Ther may noman mercurie mortifie
But it be wᵗith his broþ̉ers knowlecchinge
How that he / whiche first asaied þis þing
Of philosofris fadir was hermes
He seiþ how þᵗat þe dragon̄ douteles
Ne died not but he be slayn̄
By his brothir and that is for to seyen̄
By þe dragon mercuri and non̄ oþer
He vndirstondiþ and brymston̄ his brothir
That þer on sol ⁊and luna weren Idrawe
And þerfor͗e he took hede to my sawe
Lete noman besie him þis art for to seche
But if þe entencioıı̄un and þe speche
Off filosofris vndirstonde can
And if he do he is alewid man
For this science and þis kunyn̄ge quod he
Is of þe secrete and of þe secretis ꝑparde
Also þer was a disciple of plato
That on a tyme seide his maistir to
As his book senyor wolde bere witnes
And this was his demaunde in soþfastnes
Tel on þe name of preuy ston̄
And plato answerde to him anon̄
Take þe ston̄ þat tritanus men name
Whiche is that quod he magnanyzia is þe same
Seide plato and sire is it þus
This is ygnytum ꝑperynotyus
div.note: This is ignotu͒m ꝑper ignocius
div.l: What is magnanya good sire I yow pray
Iit is awatir that is maad I say
Off four͗e elementis quod plato
Telle me þe rote good sire quod he þo
Off that watir / ȝif it be ȝour͗e wille
Nay nay quod / plato / certis that I nylle
These filosofris sworn̄ eủerychon
That þey ne schulde discoure it to non͒
Ne in no book it is Write in nomaner͗e
For vn to crist it is so lijf and der͗e
That he woll nouȝt þat it discourid be
But wher͗e it lykith vn to his deynte
Men for to enspire and / for to defende
Whom þat him likith and þis is þe ende
Than conclude I thus / siþens god of heuene
Ne wol not that þese filosofris neuene
How that aman schuld come to þis ston̄
I rede as for þe beste to lete it gon̄
Who that makyþ god his aduersarie
As for to Worche ony þing in contᵃrarie
Of his wil / certis he schall neuer þryue
They þat he multiplye terme of aƚƚ his lyue
And þer͗e apoynt for endith is my tale
God sende eủery man bote of his bale AmeN
div.note:
þᵉ ꝓprolog failleth
Whan þᵗat þᵉ ȝeman had thus his tale

fw.hi: The tale of the Doctoᵘur of Phisik

div.l: Ther was as tellith tytus liuyus
div.note: titꝰus liuius
div.l: A knyȝt that cleped was virginyus
Fulfillit of honour and of worthinesse
And strong of frendis ⁊and of Richesse
A douȝtir he hadde bi his wijf
And neủere he hadde mo in all his lijf
Fair͗e was this maide in exullent bewte
Abouen eủery wiȝt that men may se
For natur͗e hath his soủereyn diligence
I formed hir in so gret excellence
As þouȝ sche wolde seien̄ lo I natur͗e
Þus can I forme and peynte a Cratur͗e
Whan that me lust who can me contirfete
Pigmalion̄ nouȝt nouȝ nouȝt þouȝ he forge and bete
Or graue or peynte / for I dare wel seien̄
Appollis aȝen̄s þes schuld worche al in veyn̄
Or to gᵃraue or peynte or forge and bete
If they p̉resumed me to con̄tirfete
For he that is þe former pⁱrincipal
Hath makid me his vicari gen̉eral
To forme and peynte erthely creaturis
Riȝt as me lust / and eche þing in my cur͗e is
Vndir þe moone that may wane and wexe
And for my werk no þing wole I axe
My lord and I ben fully att a cord
I maad hir to þe Worschippe of my lord
So do I alle myn̄ oþer creaturis
What colour͗e that þey han or what fyguris
This semeþ me What nature wolde seien
This maide of age xij ȝer͗e was and tweyn̄
In whiche that natur͗e had siche a dilite
For as sche gan peynte a lilye White
And rede a a rose riȝt with sucħ peyntur͗e
Siche Siche Sche peintid hath this noble Creature
Or sche were born vp on hir lemes free
Where as bi riȝt suche colours schuld be
And phebus diede and haþ her tresses grete
Ilike to þe stremes of his bourned hete
And if þat excellent was hir beute
A þousend fold more v̉ertuous was sche
On hir lackid no Condicioıı̄un
That is to preyse as by discrecioıı̄un
As wel in goost ⁊and bodi chast was sche
For whiche sche flourid in virginite
With al humylite and abstinence
With al temꝑperaunce and pacience
With mesure eke and wᵗith beringe of aray
Discrete sche was in answeringe alway
Þouȝ sche were wijs pallas dar͗e I sayn
Hir faucoun̄ eek full godly and playn̄
No countirfetid termes hadde sche
To seme wijs but aftir hur͗e degre
She spak and alle in hir wordis more and lesse
Swownynge Swownynge Sownynge in vertu and in gentilnes
Schamfast sche was in maydenes schamfastnes
Constant in herte and euer in besynes
To dryuen hir out of ydiƚƚ slogardie
Bacus hadde out out of hir mouþ no maistrie
For wyn̄ and ȝouþe dooþ doon̄ venus to encrese
As men in fier caste oile and grese
And of hir owne vertu vnconstreyned
She haþ ful ofte tyme sijk hir feyned
For that sche wolde schonye þe cumpanye
Wher͗e likly was to treten of folye
As is att festes reueles and att dauncis
Shall ben occasioıı̄un of daliauncis
Suche thingꝭes maken Childeren for to be
To sone Rype and bold as man may see
For all to sone may men lerne loore
To schewe hem boldenes before
Off boldenes Whan sche is awijf
And ȝe maisteres in your͗e old lijf
That lordis douȝtris haue in gouernaunce
Ne takith of my word no displesaunce
Þenkith þat ȝe ben sett in gouernyngis
Of lordis douȝtrin only for two þingꝭis
Ouþ̉er for ȝe han kept your͗e honeste
Or eƚƚlles ye han fallen in frelte
And knowen well y now þe olde daunce
And han fully forsake all suche myschaunce
For euermor͗e þerfore for cⁱristis sake
Kepeth wel þo þat ȝe Vndirtake
A theef of venson̄ þat hath left
His lykerousnes and aƚƚ his craft
Can kepe a forest best of ony man
Now kepeþ weel for if ȝe wollen ȝe can
Loke vnto no vise ȝe sente
Lest ȝe be dampned for your͗e wicked entent
For who so dooþ atraitoure is certeyn
And takith kepe of þat I schall seyn̄
Off all treson̄ souereyn̄ pestilence
Is whanne awyȝt betᵃraed ynnocence
Ȝe fadris and ȝe modris eek also
Þeȝi ye han childeren be it on or two
Your͗e is þe charge of all hur͗e surviaunce
Whiles that they ben vnder youre gouernaunce
Be war that bi ensaumple of your͗e lyuynge
Outher by your͗e necligence in chastesynge
That they ꝑperschen for I dar well seyn̄
If that they don ȝe schullen it sore abeyen̄
Vnder a schypard softe and necligent
The wolf hath many aschepe and lombe to rent
Sufficiþ oon ensaumple as her͗e
For I mote turne ayen vn vn to my mater͗e
This maide of Whiche I woƚƚ this tale expresse
She kepte hir silf sche neded no maisteresse
For in hur͗e lyuynge maydens mow rede
As in a book eủery good Word and dede
That longith to amayde v̉ertuous
She was so prudent and so boıı̄unteuous
For whiche hir fame out sprong on eủery side
Bothe of hir bewte and of hir boıı̄unte wyde
That þoruȝ þat lond þei preised hir vchon̄
That louede v̉ertu saue envye allon̄
That sory is of oþer menz men menz wele
And glad is of his sorwe and of his vnhele
Þe doctour makith þis discripcioıı̄un
This mayde vp on̄ aday wente in to toun̄
Toward atemple wiþ hir modir der͗e
As of a ȝong maidenes þis is þe maner͗e
Now was þer thanne a Iustice in þat toıı̄un
That gouernour͗e was of þat regioıı̄un
And so bifell þis iuge hise iȝen caste
Vp on this maide avisinge him ful faste
As sche cam forby þer͗e þis iuge stood
Anon̄ his herte chaungid and his mood
So was he cauȝt Wᵗith beute of þis maide
And to him silf full pⁱriuyly he seide
This maide schal be myn for ony man
Anon þe fend in to his hertte ran
And caste him sodeynly by sūm sleȝte
The maiden to his purpoos Wynne he myȝte
For certis bi no force / ne bi no mede
Him þouȝte he was not able to spede
For sche was stronge of frendes and eke sche
Confermed was in soủereyn boıı̄unte
That weel he wiste he myȝte hir neủere wyn̄e
As for to make hir With hur͗e body syn̄e
For whiche be grete liberacioıı̄un
He sente aftir a Clerk in þe same toun̄
Whiche that he knew for sotil and for bold
This iuge vn to þis clerk hath told
In secrete wise and mad him to asure
He schal telle it to no creatur͗e
And if he dede he schulde lese his hed
Whan̄e þat assentid was þis cursid ded
Glad was þis iuge and maad him glad cher͗e
And ȝaf him ȝiftis precious and dere
Whanne schape was all hir consꝑpiracie
For poynt to point how that his lecherie
Parformed schulde be ful sutilly
As ȝe schullen here her aftir openly
Hoom goth this clerk that hiȝte claudius
Þis fals iuge that hiȝte apius
So was his name for this is no fable
But knowen for historial þing notable
The sentence of hit sooþ is wiþ outen doute
Þis fals iuge gooþ now faste aboute
As he was wount to sitte in his consistorie
And eủere hadde þis maide in memorie
And yaf domes vp on̄ sondri caas
Þis fals clerk cam forth awell good paas
And seide lord if it be youre wille
As dooþ me riȝt vp on̄ this piteuous bille
In whiche y pleyne vp on̄ virgynyus
And if that he wol seie it is not þus
I wol it preue and fynde good witnes
Þat sooþ it is my bille I wolle expres
Þe iuge answerde of þis in his absence
I wolde awer͗e her͗e in my presence
Lete do him calle and y woll gladly her͗e
Þou schalt haue all riȝt and no wrong her͗e
Virgynyus cam to wite þe iugis wille
And riȝt anon̄ Was red þis cursid bille
The sentence of it what it was ȝe schullen her͗e
To you my lord apyus so dere
Schewith ȝour͗e pore seruaunt claudius
How that aknyȝt callid virginius
Aȝens þe lawe and ayens al equite
Holdiþ expres ayens þe wille of me
My ʆseruaunt whiche is my þral bi riȝt
Whiche that from̄ myn hous was stolen by nyȝt
Whiles that sche was ful ȝong / þis wolle y preue
Bi witnes lord so þat it noȝt ȝou greue
She nys his douȝtir what euer he seye
Wherfore to ȝou my lord iuge I pᵃraie
Ȝelde me my þrall if it be your͗e wille
Lo this was alle the sentence of his bille
Virginyus vp on̄ þe clerk biholde
But hastely or he his tale tolde
He wolde han p̉reued it as schulde a knyȝt
And eek bi wittnessynge of many awiȝt
That all was fals that seide his adủeresarie
This curssid iuge wolde no lenger tarie
Ne here aword more of virginius
But yaf his Iugement and seide him thus
I deme anon̄ this clerk his seruaunt haue
Þou schalt no lenger hir in þin hous haue
Go bringe hir forth and put hir in our͗e warde
This clerk schaƚƚ haue his þral þis I awarde
And whan this worthy knyȝt þis virginius
Þoruȝ assent of þis iustice apius
Muste bi force his der͗e douȝtir yeue
Vn to þe iuge in lecherie to lyue
He gooþ him hoom and settiþ him in his halle
And lete anon̄ his douȝtir to hym to hym calle
And with aface ded as aschen cold
Vp on hir humble face he gan bihold
With fadris pitee stickynge þoruȝ his hertte
All wolde he not from his purpoos hīm conủerte
Douȝtir quod he virginia be þin name
Ther beeth two Weies ouþ̉er deeþ or schame
That þou must suffre allas þat y was bore
For neủere þou disceruedest þerfore
To dien with aswerd or with a knyff
O der͗e douȝtir endir of my lyff
Whiche I haue fostrid vp in suche plesaunce
Þat were neủere out of my rememburaunce
O douȝtir whiche þat art my laste woo
And in my lijf my laste ioye also
O gem̄me of chastite in pacience
Take þou þy deeþ for þis is my sentence
For loue nor noȝt for hate þou must be ded
My pitouous hond mote smyte of thyn hed
Alas that eủere apyus þe say
Thus hath he flasly iuged þe to day
And tolde all þe case as ȝe before
Han herd noȝt nediþ to telle more
Merci dere fadir quod this maide
And with that word sche boþe hir armes leide
A bout hir necke as sche was wont to do
Teeris brast out of his iȝen two
And seide good fadir schaƚƚ I die
Is ther no gᵃrace is þer no remedie
No certis dere douȝtir myn ꝙquod he
Thanne yeue me leue fadir myn ꝙquod sche
My deeth for to compleyne alitil space
For ieppte ȝaf his douȝtir siche gᵃrace
For to compleyne hir or he hir slow allas
And god it woot nothing hir trespas
But that sche ran hir fadir first to se
To welcome him wiþ gret solempnyte
And wiþ that word sche fell aswon̄ anon̄
And aftir whann̄e hir swonȳne was agon̄
She Rysiþ vp and to hir fadir seide
I blessed be god that I schall dye amayde
Yeue me my deeþ or that I schall haue schame
Dooth with your͗e Child youre wille on goddis nam
div.note: The final word of of line 250 ("nam") is cut off in the gutter, presumably a final "e."
div.l: And with that word sche p̉reied him full ofte
That with his swerd he wolde smyte hir softe
And with that swownynge doun̄ sche fell
Hir fadir with ful sorweful herte and wil
Hir hed of smot and by þe topt it hente
And to þe iuge he gan it p̉resente
As he sate in dome in consistorie
And whan̄e þe iuge it sawe as seiþ þe storie
He bad to take him and honge him vp anon̄ faste
But riȝt anon̄ aþousend peple in praste
To saue þe knyȝt for routhe and pite
For knowen was þe fals inequite
The peple anon̄ hadde suspect in þis þinge
By maner of þe Clerkys Chalengīnge
That it was bi þe assent of appius
That wiste well that he was lecherous
For whiche vn to þis apius þy gon̄
And caste him in to a preson an þᵗat anon̄
Wher͗e as he slouȝe him silf and claudius
That seruaunt was vn to apius
Was demed for to honge vp on a tre
But that virginyus of his pete
So p̉reide for him that he was exiled
And eƚƚlles certis hadde he be bigilid
The remenaıı̄unt wer͗e an honged mor͗e and lesse
Þat consentynge wer͗e vn to þis curssidnes
Her͗e may men se how sy͒nne hath his merite
Be ware for noman woot whan̄e god wold smyte
In no degre ne in whiche man̉ere wise
Þe Worme of conscience may agryse
Of wickid lijf þey it so preuy be
Þat noman woot þer of but god and he
Wher͗e it he be lerid man or lewid
He not how sone he schal be aferd
Þerfor͗e I rede yow this counceƚƚ take
Forsakith synne or synne ȝow for sake
Here endith the tale of doctour͗e of Phisik

And
Now begynnytħ þe tale of þe ꝑpardoner͗e
OVre ost gan swer͗e as he wer͗e Wood
Harow quod he by nayƚƚ and bi blood
This was a flas c hler lk cherl clerk and a fals iustice
A schamfull deth as tunge may deuyse
Come to þe iustice and hir aduocasse
Algate this seli mayde is slen̄ alasse
Allas dere abouȝt sche beute
Wherfor͗e I say alday that men may see
That ȝifte ifte ȝifte of fortune and of natur͗e
Ben cause of deeþ of many a Creatur͗e
And beth ȝeftis that I speke of now
Men han full ofte more harm þan prow
But treuly myn owne maistir der͗e
This is apiteuous tale for to here
But naþeles passe oủere it is no force
I preie to god saue þe gentill cors
And þin orynals and þi iurdans
Þin ypocras and eke thin galions
And eủery box fuƚƚ of þi letewarie
God blesse hem and oure ladi seint marie
So mote I þe þou art a propre man
And like a preleet by seint runyan
Saue that I can not wel speke in terme
But well y woot þou dost myn herte to erme
That y haue cauȝt almost a cardiacle
By corpus bones but I haue triacle
Or eƚƚlles a drauȝt of moyst corny ale
Or but I here anon̄ a mery tale
Myn herte is lost for pite of þis maide
Þou belamy I oon ꝑpardonere he seide
Telle vs sum merthe or iape and þᵗat anon̄
Hit schall be do quod he bi seint Ion
But first quod he her͗e att þe next ale stake
I wol boþe drynke and eten of acake
But riȝt anon̄ þese gentiƚƚ gūnne to crie
Nay lete him telle vs no rebawdye
Telle vs sum morall þing þat we may her͗e
Sum witt and þan wolle I I gladly lere
I graunte Iwis quod he but I mote þenke
Vp sum onest þing while that I drinke
Now bygunyth þe ꝑpardeners tale
LOrdyngis ꝙquod he in in chirche whan I p̉reche
I peyne me to haue an haıı̄unt speche
I rynge it out as round as doþ abelle
For I can alle bi rote þat I telle
My teme is alwey on and euer was
Radix omīmnium omīmnium malorum est cupiditas
First I pronounce fro whens that I come
And þane my billis schewe I all and sone
Oure lige lordis seelis on my patent
Þat schewe I first my body to warant
Þat noman be so bold prest no clerk
Me to distrobble of cristis holi werk
And aftir þat telle y forth my talis
Bullis of popis and of cardinalis
Of patriarkis and of Bisschoppis I schewe
And in latyn I speke wordis a fewe
To sauēn with my predicacioıı̄un
And for to stere men to deuocioıı̄un
Þan̄ne schewe y forþ my longe cristal stones
I cramed ful of clouttis and of bones
Releckis they ben as þey wene vchon
þānne haue y in latoıı̄un a schuldir bon
Whiche that was an holy iewes scheep
Good men say I takith at my wordis keep
Ief that this bon be waschen in a welle
Ief cow or calf or ony sheep swelle
That ony worm hath y bit or ony wormelles y stıı̄unge
Take wate of þᵗat well and wesshe his tıı̄unnge
And it is hool anon and þerfore
Of pikis and of scabbe and of eủery sore
Schall eủery scheep þat of þis welle
Drynkith a drauȝt take hede what I telle
If that þe goodman þᵗat þe bestis owith
Woll eủery woke or that þe cok him crowid
Fastinge drinke of this welle a drauȝt
As þilke holy iewe our eldris tauȝt
His beestis and his store schall multiplye
And sire also it helith Ielowsye
And þouȝ aman be fallen in gelous rage
Lete make with þis watir his potage
And neue schall he his wijf my striste
Þouȝe he sothe of hir defaut s wiste
Alle hadde sche taken prestis tweyn or þre
Here is ameteyne eke þat ȝe may see
He that his hond wol putte in þis meteyne
He schal haue multiplienge of his greyn
Whane he hath sowen be it whete or otis
So that he bringe me good pens or ell grotis
And men and women oo þing warne y ȝou
Ief ony wiȝt be in þis chirche now
Þat hath don syne orible þat he
Dar not forschame of it schreuen be
Or ony woman be sche yong or old

Þe poisoıı̄un þat is so hard and so violent
Þis cursid man haþ in his hond y hent
Þis poysoıı̄un a box and siþens he ran ꝒProdoner
In to þe nexte strete vn to aman
And borwed him large bottell þre
And in þe two his poysoıı̄un purid he
Þe þridde he kepte clene for his drynke
For all þat nyȝt he schope him to swynke
In cariynge of þᵗat gold out þᵗat place
And whan þis traitour wᵗith sory gᵃce
Hadde fillyd with him his grete bottell þre
To his felowys aȝen repayrid he
What nedeþ to sermone þer of more
For riȝt as þey hadde cast his deth byfore
Ryȝt so þey han hīm slayn and þᵗat anon
And whan this was don þan spak þe toıı̄un
Now lete vs drynke and sette and make vs mery
And aftirward wole his bodie berie
And aftir þat it happeþ hēm ꝑpar caas
To take þe bottell þer yn þis poysoıı̄un was
And drank and ȝaff his felowe drynke also
Þoruȝ whiche anon þey sturuen boþe two
But certis y suppose þat auysen
Wrott neuer in no canoıı̄un ne in no fen
Mo woundir sorwe of enpoysonynge
Þus hadde þese wrecchis two hir endynge
Þus endid ben þese omysides two
And eke þis falshe enpoysener also
O cursid syne ful of all cursidnes
O traitours omycides o wickydnes
O glotonye leccherie and hasardie
Þou blasfemur of cⁱst wᵗith vilonye
And oþis grete of vsage and of pⁱride
Alas mankynde how may it bityde
Þat to þy creatoᵘur whiche þᵗat þe wrouȝte
And wᵗith his pⁱricious blood þe bouȝte
Þou art so fals and so vnkynde alas
Now gode men god foryeue ȝou ȝouʳe trespas
And war yow fro þe syne of auarice
Myn holy ꝑpardoıı̄un may ȝow alle warische
So þat ȝe offre noblys or sterlyngis
Or ellis syluer spones brochis or ryngis
Bowiþ your hed vndir þis bille
Comeþ vp ȝe wyues offriþ ȝour wille
Ȝour names I entre her in my rolle anon
In to þe blisse of heuene schul ȝe alle gon
I ȝow asoyle by myn hiȝ power
Ȝe that wolle offre as clene and eeke as cler
As ȝe wer born lo siris þus y pche
And ihıı̄un crist þat is our soulis leche
So gᵃunte yow his ꝑpardoıı̄un to resseyue
For þat is best I woll yow not disceyue
But siris o word I forgat in my tale
I haue releckys and ꝑpardoıı̄un in my male
As faire as ony man in yngelond
Whiche wer ȝeue me by þe popis hond
If ony of you wolle wᵗith deuocioıı̄un
Offren and haue myn absolucioıı̄un
Comyþ forþ anon and knelyþ her adoon
And y schal yow ȝeue of me ꝑpardoıı̄un
Or ell takith ꝑpardoıı̄un as ȝe wende
Al New and fressch at eủery townes ende
So that ȝe offre alwey new and newe
Noblis and pens whiche ben good and trewe
It is an honour to eủery man þat is here
Þat ȝe may haue asufficient ꝑpardener
To assoyle ȝou in contre as y ride
For auenturis whiche þat may bityde
For ꝑparauenture þei may fallen oon or two
Doun of his hors and breke his necke atwo
Loke whiche a suerte it is to yow alle
Þat I am in youre felowschippe I falle
That may asoyle ȝow boþe more and lasse
Whane that þe soule schall from þe bodi passe
I Rede that oure oost schall bygyne
For he is most envoluppte in syne
Come forth sire ost and offre first anon
And þou schalt kysse þe relikis echoon
Ȝhe for agrote vnbukil þou þi purs ꝒProdoner
Nay nay ꝙquod he þane haue I cristis curs
Lete be quod he it schal not be so þe ich
Þou woldest make me kysse þin olde brecch
And swere it were a relic of a seint
Þouȝ it were with þi foundement enpeynt
But by þe cros whiche seint elyne fond
I wolde y hadde þy colyons in myn hond
In stede of relekis outhyr of seintewarie
Lete cutte hem of and y woll hem carie
They schulle be schryned in an hogges tord
This ꝑpardoner answerde not a word
So wroth he was he uolde no word seie
Now quod oure oost y wol not lenger pleye
Wiþ þe ne with non vþer angry man
But ryȝt anon þe worthy knyȝt by gan
Whan that he say that alle þe peple louȝ
Nomore of þis for it is riȝt I nouȝ
Sire ꝑpardoner be glad and meri of chere
And ȝe ser oost þat ben to me so dere
I pᵃy ȝow þat ȝe kysse þe ꝑpardoner
And sire ꝑpardoner y pᵃy þe drawe þe ner
And as we dede lete vs lauȝe and pleye
Anon þey kissede and reden forth hir weye
þe ꝑpardoners
Her͗e begynnyth the Shipmannis tale
A Marchaunt Whilome dwellide at Seint Denys
That riche was for whiche mēn helde hīm wis
A wyff he hadde of excellent beaute
And componable and reuelous was sche
Whiche is a thyng that causiþ more dispēnce
Þan worþ is al þe chere and reủerence
That men hem doþ att festis and att dan̄cis
Whiche salutacion̄s an cōntenauncis
As dooþ a shadewe vp ōn a wal
But wo is him þᵗat payen mote for al
Þe sely husbond algate he mote paye
He mote vs cloþe and he mote vs araye
Al for his owne worschyppe richely
In wheche aray we dauncen Iolily
And if þat he noȝt may ꝑparauentur͗e
Or ell list not whiche spencis endur͗e
But þenkiþ it is I wastid and I lost/
Þan mote an oþ̉er paye for our͗e cost/
Or lene vs gold and þᵗat is ꝑperilous
This noble marchaunt held a worthy hous
For whiche he hadde al day so gret repayr͗e
For his largesse and his wyf was fair͗e
That woundir is // but herkneþ to my tale
Among alle þese gestis grete and smale
Þer was amonk afaire man and/ a bold
I trowe a þritty wynter he was oold
Þat eủere in on was drawynge to þᵗat place
Þat ȝonge monk that was so faire of face
Aqueyntid was so wᵗith þe good man
Sethen þat hir firste knowleche began̄
That in his hous as faumiler was he
As it is possibil ony frend to be
And for as meche as þis good man
And eeke þis monk of which þᵗat I began
Were boþe tweyne y bore mo village
Þe monk him cleymyd as for cosynage
And he aȝen he seyde not onys nay
But was as glad þer of as foule of day
For to his hertte it was a gret plesaıı̄unce
Þus be þey knyt wᵗith eterne aliaunce
And eche of hem gan oþer for to essur͗e
Off breþerhod whilis her lyues may endur͗e
Fre was daun̄ Ion and namely of dispence
As in þat hous and ful of diligence
To dōn plesaunce and also gret costage
He noȝt forȝate to yeue þe leste page
In all that hous but aftir hir degre
He yaff þe lord and sithen his meyne
Whan that he come own man̉ere honest þing
For whiche þey wer͗e all glad of his comynge
As foul is fayn whan þe day risiþ
Nomore of this as now for it suffisiþ
But so befel þis marchaunt up on̄ a day
Shope him to make him redy his aray
Toward þe toun̄ of bruggꝭes for to fare
To byen þer͗e a porcion̄ of war͗e
For whiche he haþ to parys sent anon
A messager͗e and p̉reyed haþ daun̄ Ion
Þat he shulde come to seynt/ Denys and playe
With him and wᵗith his wiff as ay or twaye
Or he to Bruggis wente on alle wyse
Þis noble monk of whiche y ȝou deuyse
Hath of his abbot/ as him liste lycence
Be cause he was aman of hiȝ prudence
And eek an officer out for to ryde
To sene hir͗e gᵃranges and hir͗e bernes wyde
And vn to seint Denys he comyþ anōn
Who was so welcome as my lord daıı̄un Ioon̄
Our͗e dere coseyn ful of curtesie
With hīm brout he a iubbe of maleuesye
And eke an oþ̉er ful of fyn̄ v̉ernage
And volatily as ay was his vsage
And þus I lete hem ete and drynke ⁊and play
Þys marchaunt/ and þis monk aday or tway
Þe þridde day þis marchaunt vp arisid
And on his nedis sadly him a visid
And vp in to his coıı̄untynge hous goth he
To rekene wiþ him silf wel may be
Of þilke ȝeer how þat wᵗith him stood
And how þat he dispendid hath his good
And ȝif þat he encresed were or non
His bokys and his baggis many on̄
He leith beforn him on his countynge bord
Ful riche was his tresour͗e and his hord
For whiche ful faste his coıı̄untur dore he shette
And eek he nolde þat noman schulde him lette
Of his a coıı̄untis for þe mene tyme
And þus he satt til it was passid pⁱrime
Daıı̄un Ion was rese in þe morwe also
And in þe gardeyn walkith to and fro
And haþ his þingis seyd ful curtisly
Þe good/ wyff come walkyng pⁱriuyly
In to þe gardeyn þer he walkith softe
And hīm salutith as sche haþ don̄ ofte
Amayde child come in hir componye
Whiche as hir liste sche may goủerne and gye
For ȝit vnder þe ȝeerd was þe mayde
O dere cosyn̄ myn daıı̄un Ion sche seide
What eylith ȝow so raþe for to aryse
Nice ꝙquod he it ouȝte y now suffice
.V. ouris for to slepe vp on anyȝt/
But it were for an old pallyd wiȝt
As ben þese wedded men þat lien ⁊and dare
As in a forme sitt/ a wery hare
Wer͗e al forstrauȝt wᵗith houndis grete and smale
But dere nece why be ȝe so pale
I trowe certis that our͗e good man
Hath yow sore laborid siþ þe nyȝt began
Þat yow were nede to reste hastely
And with þat word he louȝ ful merily
And of his owne þouȝt he waþ alred
Þis fayr͗e wyf gan to shake hir hed
And seide thus ȝhe god wot al ꝙquod sche
Nay coseyn myn it stondiþ not so wᵗith me
For by that god þat ȝaff me soule and lyff
In alle þe rewme of Fᵃrance is þer no wyff
Þat lesse lust/ hath to þat sory play
For y may synge allas and weleawey
Þat y was born but to no wyȝt ꝙquod sche
Dare y not telle how it stondith wᵗith me
Wherfore y þenke out of þis lond to wende
Or ellis of my silf to make an ende
So ful am I of drede and of care
Þis monk began vpon this wyf to star͗e
And seyde alas my nyce god for bede
Þat ȝe for ony sorwe and for ony drede
For do ȝour͗e silf but telle me your͗e greff
ꝐPar auentur͗e I may in your͗e myscheff
Coıı̄unsel or helpe ⁊and þerfor͗e tellyþ me
Al your͗e anoye for it schal be secre
For on my Portors I make an oth
Þat neủere in my lyf for leef or looth
Ne shal y of no con̄seil yow bewreye
Þe same ageyn̄ to yow ꝙquod sche I seye
Be god and by this Portors I swer͗e
Þouȝ men me wolde al in pecis tere
Ne shall y neủere for to goon to telle
Bewreye aword of thing þᵗat ȝe me telle
Noȝt for no cosynage ne alyaunce
But v̉eryley for loue and affiaunce
Thus been þey sworn̄ and here vpōn þey kyste
And eche of hem tolde oþ̉er what hē liste
Cosȳn ꝙquod sche if I hadde aspace
As I haue nōn and namely in this case
What I haue suffryd sith y was a wyff
A longe legende myȝte y telle of my lyf
With myn husbond al be he your͗e cosyn̄
Nay ꝙquod þis monk by god ⁊and by Seynt Martyn̄
He is nomore cosyn vn to me
Þan ys þe leef þat hongeth on atre
I clepe hīm so by Seint Denyce of France
To haue þe more cause of aqueyntancē
Of ȝow whiche I haue loued specially
Abouē alle oþ̉er women̄ sykyrly
Þis swer͗e I you on my professioıı̄un
Tellyth ȝour͗e greef lest he comyþ doıı̄un
And hastith yow and goth away anon̄
My dere loue ꝙquod sche o myn Daun Ion
Ful leef were me þis coıı̄unceil for to hide
But out it mote it may no lenger abyde
Myn husbond is to me þe worste man
Þat euer was sith þᵗat þe world began
But sithen y am his wyf it sit not me
To telle no wiȝt of our͗e preuyte
Neþir a bedde in nōn othir place
God shilde I shulde it telle for his gᵃrace
A wyf ne schall not seye of hir husbonde
But al honour͗e as I vnderstonde
Saue vn to yow þus meche telle schall/
As helpe me god he is noȝt worth at all/
In no degre þe valu of aflye
But ȝit me greueþ most his nygardye
And well ȝe woot þᵗat women naturelly
Desyren þyngis VI as welas I
They wolden that hir husbondes shuldē be
Hardy and wys and riche and þer to fre
And buxōm vn to his wyf and fressch abedde
But bi tha ilke lord þat for vs bledde
For his honour my silf to araye
A sonday next y mote nedis paye
An C frankys or ell am y lorn
Ȝit wer͗e me leủere þat I/ wer͗e vnborn̄ þan me were
