div.l: Þane me wer͗e don̄ sclaundir or vilonye
And if myn husbond eek myȝte it aspie
I ner but lost and þerfore I ȝou pᵃray
Lene me þis sūmme or ell mote y dey
Daun̄ Ion I seie lene ne þis hundrid fraunkis
ꝐParde I uol not faile yow my þankis
Ief that ȝe liste to don̄ that I ȝou say
For at a certeyn̄ day I woll yow pay
And do to yow what plesaunce and ʆseruyse
Þat I may don̄ riȝt as list/ deuyse
And but I do god take on me venaıı̄unce
As foul as hadde eủere Genelon̄ of Fᵃrance
This gentil monk answerde in this maner͗e
Now treuly myn owne lady dere
I haue ꝙquod he on ȝow so gret routhe
Þat y ȝou swere and pliȝt ȝou my trouthe
Þat whan̄e your͗e husbond is to Flaundris fare
I wolle delyủere iow out of þis care
For y woll brynge ȝow an C frānkis
And with þat word he cauȝt hir bi þᵉ flaunkis
And hir embraced hard and kissid hir ofte
Goth now your͗e wey ꝙquod he all stille and softe
And lete vs dyne as sone as þat ȝe may
For by my chilendre it is pⁱrime of þe day
Goþ now and beth as trew as y schall be
And forþ sche goþ as ioly as a pie
And bad þe kokis þat þey shuld him hiȝe
Now ell god forbede quod he
So that men myȝte dyne and þᵗat anon̄
Vp to hir husbond is þis wyf gon̄
And knocked at his countynge dor͗e boldely
Who is þer ꝙquod he Petir it am y
Quod sche what sire how longe wole ȝe faste
How longe tyme wol ȝe rekene and caste
Your͗e som̄es ȝour͗e bokes and ȝoure þinges
Þe deuel haue part on alle suche rekenyngꝭes
Ye haue y now ꝑparde of goddis sonde
Ye haue y now ꝑparde of goddis sonde
Come doun̄ to day and lete youre bagges stonde
Ne be ȝe not aschamed that Daun̄ ion
Schal fastinge alle this day elenge gon̄
What lete vs here amesse and go we dyne
Wyf quod this man litil can stow dyuyne
Þe curious besines that we haue
For of vs chapmen as god me saue
And by that lord that cleped is Seint yue
Scarsly among xii x shulle þryue
Continuelly lastinge vnto oure age
We mowe well make cheer and good visage
And dryue forth þe world as it may be
And kepe oure astate in pⁱriuyte
Til we be ded or ell/ þat we pleye
A pilgrimage or ell gon̄ out of oure weye
And þerfore I haue I gret necessite
Vpon̄ this queynte world to a vise me
For eủere mote we stonde in drede
Of hap and fortune in our͗e chapmanhede
To Flaundres wolle y go to morwe in þe day
And come aȝen also sone as eủere I may
For whiche dere wyf I þe biseke
As be to eủery wiȝt buxᵒn and meke
And for to kepe oure good be curious
And honestly goủerne well oure hous
Þou hast y nouȝ in eủery man̉ere wyse
Þat to a þrifti hushold may suffice
Þe lackith non aray ne no vitayle
Of siluer in þy purs shalt þou neủere fayle
And wᵗith þat word his countir dore he shette
And doun̄ he goþ nolenger wolde he lette
But hastily was þer amasse seid
And spedely þe tablys were þere y leyd
And to þe dener hastely þey hem spedde
And richely þis monk þe chapman fedde
Att aftir dyner dan̄ ion sikerly
Þis chapman took a side ful preuyly
He seyde him thus cosyn it standiþ so
That well y se to Bruggis woll ȝe go
God and Seint Austin spede ȝou and gide
I pᵃray iow cosyn wisly þat ȝe ride
Gouẻerene youȝe silf also of your͗e diet/
Al temꝑpereuly and namely in þis heet
Betwix vs two nedeþ no strange fare
Fare well cosyn god shilde yow fro care
And if that ony þing be day or nyȝte
If it lye in my power and in my myȝt
Þat ȝe woll coman̄de me in ony wyse
It shall be don̄ riȝt as ye woll deuyse
But o thing or that ȝe go if it may be
I woll praye yow for to leue me
An C fraunkis for a weke or twey
For certeyn bestis þat I mote beye
To store a place with þat is oures
God helpe me so I wolde it were ȝouris
I schal not fayle sikirly at my day
But lete this þing be secrete y iow p̉ray
For ȝit to nyȝt þese beestis mote I bay
Not for a þousent fraunkis a myleway
And fare now wel myn owne cosyn dere
Graunt mercy of your͗e coost and of your͗e chere
Þis nobil marchaunt gentil anoon
Answerde and seide o cosyn̄ myn̄ daun̄ ion
Now sikerly this is a smal request
My gold is ȝouris what þat ȝow list
And not only my gold but my chaffare
Take what ȝe liste god shilde and ȝe spare
But o þing is ȝe knowe it wel y now
Of chapmen þat hir monye is hir plow
We mowe creaunce while we haue a name
But goldleles for to be it is no game
Paieþ it aȝen when it lith in ȝoure ese
Aftir my myȝt ful fayn̄ wol y yow plese
Þese C fraunkis he fette forth anon̄
And preuyly he tooke hem to daun̄ ioon
No wiȝt in þis world wiste of þis lone
Sauynge þis marchaunt and daun̄ ioon alone
Thei drynke and speke and rome a while and pleye
Til that Daıı̄un Ioon ridith to his Abbey
The morwe cam and forth þis marchaunt ridiþ
To Flaundris ward his prentice him gideth
Til he come to Bruggis merily
Now goþ þis marchaunt faste and besily
Aboute his nedis and bieþ and craıı̄unciþ
He nouthir pleith att þe dies ne daunciþ
But as amarchaunt schortly for to telle
He lediþ his lyf and þer I lete him dwelle
The sonday next the þe marchaunt was agon̄
To Seynt Denys comyn is Daun̄ Ion
With corowne and berd al fressh and new shaue
In al þe hous þer nas so litil a knaue
Ne no wiȝt ell þat he ne was ful fayn̄
That my lord Daun̄ ioon was come ageyn
And shortly to þe poynt riȝt for to gon̄
Þis faire wyf acordid with Daun̄ ion
That for this hundrid fraunkis he shulde al nyȝt
Haue hir in his armes bolt vp riȝt
And this acord ꝑparformed was in dede
In myrthe alnyght abysy lyf þey ledde
Til that it was day þat daun̄ ion wente his way
And bad þe meyne fare well and haue good day
For noon of hem ne no wiȝt in þe toun̄
Hath of Daun̄ ion ony suspicioıı̄un
And forth he ridith hoom to his Abbey
Or where him liste nomore of him y seye
This marchaunt whanne endith was þis faire
To Seynt Denys he gan to repaire
And with his wyf he makith feeste and chere
And telliþ hir þat chaffar is so dere
And nedis muste he make a cheuysaıı̄unce
For he was bounden in a reconysaıı̄unce
To paye xx þousend shildis anoōn
For whiche this marchaunt is to paris gon̄
To borwe of certeyn frendis that he hadde
A certeyn̄ of fᵃrankis and sum̄e wᵗith him he ladde
And whanne that he was come in to þe toun̄
For gret chere and gret affeccioıı̄un
Vn to daun̄ ion he goth him first to pleye
Not for to axe no borwe of him monye
But for to wite and se of his wilfare
And for to tellen him of his chaffare
As frendis doun̄ when þey mete in fere
Daun̄ ion him makith feeste and meri chere
And he him told aȝen ful specialli
How he hadde well y bouȝt and gᵃraciously
Þankid be god all hool his marchaundise
Saue that he muste in al maner wyse
Maken acheuisaunce as for þe beste
And þānne he shulde be in ioye and reste
Daıı̄un ion answerde certis y am fayn̄
That ȝe in hele are come hom ageyn
And if that I were riche as haue I blys
Of xxᵗⁱ nꝭes schildis shulde ȝe not mys
For ȝe so kyndly this oþir day
Lente me gold and as I can or may
I þanke ȝow bi god and by Seint Iame
But naþeles y took it to our͗e dame
Ȝowr͗e wyf at hom̄ þe same gold ageyn̄
Vpon̄ ȝour͗e benche sche woot it wel certayn̄
By certeyn̄ tokens þat I can ȝow telle
Now by ȝour͗e leue y may no lenger dwelle
Our͗e abbot wol out of þis towne anon̄
And in his companye nedis muste y gon̄
Grete well oure dame myn owne nece swets
And farewell dere cosyn̄ till we mete
Þis marchaunt whiche that was ful war ⁊and wys
Creauncid hath and payed eeke in Parice
To certeyn lombardis redi in hir hond/
Þe som̄e of gold and gate of him his bond/
And hoom he goth as meri as a popingaye
For wel he know he stod in suche aray
That nedis muste he wynne in that viage
A nꝭes fraunkis aboue all his costage
His wyf ful redely mette him at þe gate
As sche was wont of oold vsage algate
And al that nyȝt in merthe þey be sett/
For he was riche and clerly out of dett
Whane it was day þis marchaunt gan ebrace
His wyff al newe and kyste hir on hir face
And vp he goth and makiþ it ful touȝ
Nomore ꝙquod sche be god ȝe han I nowȝ
And wantowly aȝen̄ wiþ him sche pleyde
Til att þe laste þe marchaunt seide
By god quod he I am a litil wroth
Wiþ iow my wyff þouȝ it be me loth
And wete ȝe why bigod as that I gesse
Þat ȝe han mad amaner strangenesse
Betwiþ me and my cosyn Daun̄ ioon
Ȝe shuld haue warned me or I had gon̄
That he ȝow hadde an C fran̄kis paied
By redi tokene and helde him euyl apayed
For that I to him spak of cheuysan̄ce
Me semed so as bi his cōntenaunce
But neþeles bi god oure heuene kyng
I thouȝte to axe of him no thing
I pᵃray þe wyff ne do nomore so
Tel me alwey or that I fro þe go
If ony detour͗e haue in myn absence
I payed þe lest þoruȝ þy necligence
I myȝte him axa a þing þat he haþ payed/
þis wyf was not afferd ne affrayed
But boldely sche seide and þat anon̄
Marie I deffie þe falsch Monk Daun̄ ioon
I kepe not of his toknes neủere a deel
He took me certeyn gold þis woot y weel
What yuyl thedom on his Monkys snowte
For god it woot y wende wᵗith outen dowte
That he hadde yeue it me because of ȝou
To don̄ þer wiþ myn honoᵘur and my prow
For cosonage and eeke for bele chere
That he hath had full ofte tymes here
But sith I se it stonde in suche disioynt/
I woll answere ȝou shortly at þis poynt
Ȝe han mo slaker dettours þan am I/
For y wol paye yow wel and redely
Fro day to day and if so be y fayle
I am ȝoure wyf score it on My taile
And y schall as sone as eủere y may
For by my trouthe I haue on myn aray
And not on wast bestowid eủery deell
And for y haue bestowid it so weell
For ȝour͗e honoᵘur for goddis sake y seye
As be not wroth and late vs lauȝe and pleye
Ȝe schulle my ioly body haue to wedde
But in seith y wol noght paye ȝow but a bedde
Forȝeue it me myn owne spouse dere
Turnyþ hidir ward and makiþ better chere
Þis marchaunt say þer was no remedye
And for to chide it were but folie
Sith þe þing may not amended be
Now wyff he seide and y forȝeue it þᵉ
But bi þi lyf be nomore so large
Kepe bet þi good this ȝeue I/ þe in charge
Thus endiþ my tale and god vs sende
Tailynge y noȝ vnto oure lyues ende
Here endith the Shipmannes tale // And
Biginnyth the prologue of þe priores
Wel seid be corpus dūs our͗e ost
Now longe mote þou saile by þe cost
Sire gentil Maister gentil mariner
God ȝeue þe Monk a M last quad ȝer
A. ha felowys beþ war of suche a iape
The monk putte in þe man̄ys hood an Ape
And in his wyues eek by Seint Austin
Drawith no monkys in to ȝoure yn
But now passe ouer and lete vs seke aboute
Who schall now telle first of all this route
An othir tale and with þat word he seide
As curtisly as it were a mayde
My lady prⁱoresse by ȝour͗e leue
So that I wiste I/ shulde ȝou not greue
I wolde demen þat ȝe tellen shulde
A tale next/ if so were that ȝe wolde
Now wol ȝe vouche it sauf my ladi dere
Gladly quod sche and seide as ȝe schullen her͗e
Domine dominus noster
Lord our͗e lord þy name how m̉eruelous
Is in this large world spred ꝙquod sche
For not only þy laude precious
ꝐParforned is by men of dignite
But bi the mouth of children þy bounte
ꝐParformed is for on þe brest soukynge
Sumtyme shewen þei þin herienge
Wherfore in loud as I best can and may
Off þe and of þe litil white flour͗e
Whiche that þe bare and is a mayde alway
To telle a storie I wol do my labour͗e
Nouȝt þat y may encrese hir honour͗e
For sche hir silf is honour and þe rote
Of bon̄te next hir sone and soulys bote
O moder mayde o mayde moder fre
O busch vnbrent brennynge in moyses syȝt
Þat rauischid don̄ from þy deite
Þoruȝ þin humilnes þe geste þat in þe liȝt
Of whos v̉ertu whan̄e he þin herte lyȝt
Conceyued was þe fadris sapience
Helpe me to telle it in thy reuerence
¶ Lady thy bounte þy magnificence
Thi vertu and thy gret humilite
Ther may no tunge exp̉reesse in no science
For sumtyme men and ladies pᵃraen to þe
Thou goost bifore of þi benygnyte
And getist vs þe liȝt of þy pᵃrayere
To gyden vs to þy sone so dere
¶ My kun̄ynge is so weyke o blisfull quene
For to declare þy grete goodnes
That I may þe weiȝt/ not/ sustene
But as a child of twelue monþe olde or lesse
Þat can vnethe ony word exp̉reesse
Ryȝt so fare y and þerfore I ȝou þy
Gidiþ my song/ þat/ I shall/ of ȝow say
Now biginnyth the preoresses tale
Ther was in asie in a gret Cite
Amongis cristen folk a iurie
Sustened by alord of þᵗat cūntre
For foul vsure and lucre of viloynye
Hatful to crist and to his con̄panye
And þoruȝ þis strete men myȝte ride or wende
For it was fre and open at eủery ende
A litel scole of cristen folk þer stood
Doıı̄un att þe ferthir ende in wheche þer wer͗e
Childeren an heep/ comen of cristen blood
That lerned in scole ȝer by ȝer͗e
Suche maner doctrine as men vsen þer͗e
Þis is to seyen to syngen and to rede
As smal childeren doıı̄un in hir childhede
Amongis þese childeren was a widowes sone
A litil clergiōn Vi ȝer͗e of age
That day by day to scole was his wone
And eek also wher͗e as he siȝ þe ymage
Of cristis modir hadde he in vsage
As \hym/ was tauȝt to knele adoıı̄un and seie
His aue marie as he gooþ bi þe weye
Thus hath þis widowe her littil sone tauȝt
Our͗e blysfull lady cristis moder dere
To worschippe ay/ and/ for gate it nouȝt/
For þe sely child wolde alwey sone lere
But ay whan I remembre of þis matere
Seint nycholas stondith eủere in my p̉resence
For he so yong to crist dide reuerens
This littil child his litel book lernynge
As he satt in his scole at his pⁱriuer͗e
Alma redemptoris herde singe
As childeren lernede hir Antiphoner
As he durste he drow him ner and ner
And herkened ay þe wordis and þe note
Til he þe firste vers coude al by rote
He wiste not what this latin was to say
For he so yong and tendir was of age
But on a day his felaw gan he pray
To expownen him þis song in his langage
Or tellen him whi this song was in vsage
This pᵃraiede he him to construe and declar͗e
Ful ofte tymes vp on̄ his knees bare
Hys felowe whiche that eldir was þan he
Answerde him þus/ þis song I haue herd seie
Was mᵃaud of oure blisfull ladi fre
Hir to salue and eek hir for to p̉raie
To ben our͗e helpe and socour͗e whan we deie
I can nomore expownde in þis mater͗e
I lerne song y can but small gᵃramerie
And is this song mᵃaud in reuerence
Of cristis moder seide this ynnocent/
Now certis y woll do my diligence
To kūnne it alle or cristemasse be went
Þouȝ that I for my prymer schal be schent
And schal be beten þries in an houre
I wol it kūnne oure lady for to honoure
His felowe tauȝte it him homward pⁱriuyly
Fro day to day til he coude it by rote
And he song it wel and boldely
Fro word to word acordinge wᵗith þe note
Twyes a day it passid þoruȝ his þrote
To scoleward and homward whan he wente
On cristis moder set was his entent
As I haue seid þoruȝ þe Iewrye
This litel child as he come to and fro
Ful merily wolde he synge and crie
O Alma redemptoris euer mo
Þe swettnesse off his herte ꝑpersid so
Of cristis moder that to hir to p̉ray
He can not stynte off syngige by þe way
Oure firste foo þe Serpent Satanas
Þat haþ in iewes hertis his waspys nest
Vp swall and seide hebraik peple allas
Is this to þow a aþing þat is honest
That suche aboy shall walken as hīm list
In your͗e dispite and synge of suche sentence
Whiche is aȝens ȝoure Awes reuerence
Fro þens forth þe iewes han conspirid
Þis ynnocent out of þis world to chase
An homicide þerto hane þey herid
Þat in an aleye hadde a preuy place
And as þe child gan for by for to pace
Þis cursid iewe him hente and helde him̄ faste
And kitte his þrote and in apitte him caste
I seye that in a wordroþe þei hīm drew
Þer as þe iewes purgen hir entraile
Off cursid folk of herodes all new
What may youre yuell entent yow avayle
Morder wol out certeyn it may not faile
And namely þer as þe honour of god schal sprede
Þe blood out crieþ on your͗e cursid dede
O martir sonded to virginite
Now maistow syngen and folwen eủere in on
Þe white lombe celestial ꝙquod sche
Of whiche þe grete euangelist Seint Ion
In Pathmos wroot whiche seith þat þei þᵗat gon̄
Before þis lombe and singe a song al newe
Þat neủere Flesshly womēn þey ne knewe
This pore widowe awaytid all þᵗat nyȝt
Afftir hir littil child bot he cam noȝt/
For whiche as sone as it was daies liȝt
With pale face for drede and besy þouȝt
Sche hath att scole and ell wher͗e him souȝt
Til finally sche gan so fere a spye
Þat he last sen̄ was in þe iurye
¶ With modris pite in her brest enclosid
Sche goth as sche were half out of hir mynde
To eủery place wher͗e sche had supposid
By liklyhede hir litil child to fynde
And eủere in cristis modirs meke ⁊and kynde
Sche cried and att þe laste þus sche wrouȝte
Among þe cursid iewes sche hīm souȝte
¶ Sche freyned and pᵃrayed piteously
To eủery iewe that dwellid in þilke place
To telle hir if hir child wente ouȝt for by
Þey seide nay but iħuihesu of his gᵃrace
Ȝaf in hir þouȝt with a mine a littil space
Þat in þat place aftir hir sone she criede
Where as he was cast in apitt biside
¶ O grete god that ꝑparfournest þy lond
By mouth of ynnocentis lo her͗e þy myȝt/
This gemme of chastite þis Em̉eraude
And eeke of martirdom̄ þe Rubi briȝt
Þere he with þrote I cutte lay vp riȝt/
He Alma redemptoris gan to sige
So loude þat all þᵉ place gan to rynge
Þe cristen folk þat þoruȝ þe strete wente
In comen for to woundre on this þing
And hastely þey for þe Prouēst sente
He come anon̄ with outen tariynge
And heriede crist þat is of heuene kyng/
And eeke his modir honour of mankȳnde
And aftir þat þe iewes lete he bynde
This child wiþ piteuous lementacioıı̄un
Vp taken was syngige his song alwey
And with þe honour of gret processioıı̄un
Þey carien him to þe nexte abbey
Hys modir swownynge by his bere lay
Vnnethe myȝte the peple þat was þere
This new rachel brynge from his bere
¶ With torment and wit shaumful deþ echon̄
Þis prouost doth þese iewes for to sterue
That of this mordur wiste and þat anon̄
He nolde no suche cursidnes obserue
Yuel schal haue þat yuel wol discerue
Therfore with wilde hors he dede hēm drawe
And aftir þat he heng hem bi þe lawe
¶ Vp on this bere lith ay þis ynnocent
Before þe hiȝ auter while that þe masse last/
And aftir þat þe abbot wᵗith his couent/
Han sped hem for to burye him ful fast
And whane þey holy water on him cast
Ȝit spak þis child whan sprent was þis holy water
And sang o alma redemptoris mater
¶ This Abbot whiche that was an holy man
As monkis ben or ell ouȝt be
Þis child to coniure he began
And seyde o dere child I halse þe
In vertu of þe holy trinite
Telle me what is þi cause for to synge
Sithen that thy throte is kit to my semynge
¶ My þrote is kut vn to my necke bon
Seide this child and as by wey of kynde
I shulde haue died ȝhe longe tyme agon̄
But iħuihesu crist as ȝe in bokis fynde
Wole that his glorie laste and be in mynde
And for þe worschippe of his modir dere
Ȝit may I synge o alma loude and clere
This welle of merci cristis modir swete
I louede alwey as aftir my kunȳnge
And whan that y my lyf schuld forlete
To me sche come and bad me for to synge
Þis antem v̉erily in my diynge
As ȝe han herd and whane þat I hadde songe
Me þouȝte sche leide agreyne vpon̄ my tūnge
Wherfor͗e y synge and synge muste certeyn̄
In honour͗e of that blisfull mayde fre
Til fro my tonge of taken ys þe greyn
And aftir þat þus seide sche to me
My litil child now wol y feche þe
Whan̄e þat þe greyne is fro þy tonge take
Be not agast/ y wolle þe not forsake
This holy monk this abbot him mene I/
His tonge out cauȝte and toke awey þe greyn̄
And he yaf vp þe goost ful softely
And whan̄e þis abbot/ hadde þis woundir seyn̄
His salt teris trillyd doun̄ as reyn̄
And gruf he fel all plat/ vp on̄ þᵉ groun̄de
And stille he lay as he hadde leye y bounde
¶ The couent eek lay on þe paument
Wepynge and herynge cristis modir der͗e
And aftir þat þey roos and forth ben went
And took awey þis martir frōm his bere
And in a toumbe of Marbilstones clere
Enclosen þey this litil body swete
Þer he is now// god leue vs for to mete
O ȝonge Hue of Lyncolne slayn also
With cursid iewes as it is notable
For it is but a litil while ago
Praye eek for vs we sinful folk vnstable
That of his mercy god so merciable
On Vs his gret mercy multiplie
For þe reuerence of his modir marie Amen
Here endeth the Pⁱrioresse tale/ And here

l.hi:
Et incipit
Bygnnyth the prolog of chaucer of Dıı̄uno Thopas

div.l: Uhan seid was al þis miracle eủery man
As sobre was that wondir was to se
Til þat our͗e oost iapen to began
And þat at erst he loked vp on me
And seide thus what man art þouꝙquod he
Þou lokist as þou woldist fynde an hare
For eủere vpon þe ground I se þe stare
Aproche ner and loke vp merily
Now ware siris and lete þis man haue place
He in þe wast is shapen as wel as I
This were apopet in armes to enbrace
For ony woman smal and faire of face
He semith eluysch by his countenaıı̄unce
For vn to wighte doþ he daliaunce
Seye now þou sumwhat/ syn oþ̉er folk han seid
Telle vs atale of merthe and þat anōn
Hoost quod I ne beþ not yuell apayd
For oþer tale certis can I non̄
But of aryme I lerned it longe agōn
Ȝhe that is good ꝙquod he now schal we here
Sum deynte thing/ me þenkith by his chere
Here byginnyth the tale of ʆsir thopas
LIistenyth lordis in good entent
And I woll ȝow telle v̉erament
Of mirthe and of solace
Of a knyght was fayr͗e and gent
In batayle and in turnement
His name was sir thopas
I born̄ he was in fere cuntr͗e
In flaıı̄undres all beȝonde þe se
At poperinge in þe place
His fadir was aman ful fre
And lord he was of that cūntre
As it was goddis gᵃrace
Sere thopas wax adouȝti mān
White was his face as apaynnemayn̄
His lippis red as a Rose
His Rode is lik scarlet in greyn̄
As y yow telle in good certeyn̄
He hadde asembly nose
His here of of his berd was liik safferoıı̄un
That to his girdill rauȝte adoun̄
His schon̄ of cordewane
Off Brugges were his hosen broun̄
His robe was of sikelatoun̄
That coste many aiane
¶ He coude hunte at wilde der͗e
And ride an hawkynge by þe reuer͗e
With grey hawkys gose on honde
Ther to he was a good archir͗e
Of wrastelynge was þer non his pere
Þer ony ram schulde stonde
¶ Ful many amayde briȝt in bour͗e
They morne for him ꝑparamor͗e
Whan hem were bet to slepe
But he was chast and no lecthour
And swete as is þe brambil floure
That berith þe red hepe
¶ And so it fill vp on a day
For soþe as y iow telle may
Sire thopas wolde out ride
He worþ up vpon his stede gᵃray
And in his hond alaıı̄unce gay
Along swerd by his side
¶ He prickid þoruȝ a fayr͗e forest
Þeryn̄e is many a wilde best
Ȝhe boþe buk and hare
And as he pricked norþ ⁊and est
I telle it yow him hadde almest
Bitid a sori care
¶ Ther spryngith erbis gret and smale
The licorice and þe setuale
And þe notemuge to putte in ale
Whethir it be moyste or stale
Or for to leye in coffre
¶ The briddis songen it is no nay
Þe sꝑparhawke and þe popyngay
Þat ioye it was to her͗e
The þristilcok mad her lay
Þe wode dowe vp on a spray
Sche song ful loude and cler͗e
¶ Sire thopas fil in loue longinge
Al whanē he herde þe þristil singe
And prickid as he were wood
His fayre stede in his prickynge
He swette þat men myȝte hir wringe
His sides wer͗e all blood
¶ Sir thopas eeke so wery was
For prickynge up on̄ þe softe gras
So fers was his corage
Þat doun̄ he leide hīm in þᵗat place
To make his stede sum solace
And ȝaf him good forage
¶ O seint marie benedicite
What eilith þis loue at me
To bynde me so sore
Me dremed al þis nyȝt ꝑparde
Þat an elf queene shall my lemein be
And slepe vndir my gore
¶ An elf qwene wole y love Iwys
For in þis world no woman is
Worþi to be my make
in toune
Alle othir women y forsake
And to an elf qwene y me take
By dale and eek by downe
¶ In to his sadil he clombe anon̄
And prickid ouer stile and ston̄
An elf qwene for to aspie
Til he so longe hath rede and gon̄
Þat he fond in a pⁱriuy won̄
Þe cuntre of fayreiȝe /
so wilde
For in þat cuntre was þer non
Þat to hīm durst ride on gon̄
Neither wyf ne childe
Til that þer come a gret geaunt
His name was sire olifaunt
A ꝑperlous man of dede
¶ He seide child by termagaunt
But if thow pricke out of mȳn haıı̄unt
Anon̄ y sle thy / stede /
wᵗith mace
Here is þe qwene of fairie
With harpe and pype ⁊and synfonye
Dwellynge in this place
¶ The child seide as so mote y þe
Whane y haue myn armour͗e
And ȝit I hope ꝑparmafay
Þat þou schalt wᵗith þis launce gay
Abien it ful sore
þy mawe
I schal ꝑperce if y may
Or it be fully pⁱrime of þe day
For her þou shalt be slawe
Sir thopas drow abak ful faste
Þis geaıı̄unt at him stones caste
Out of afel staff slynge
¶ But faire ascapid sir thopas
And al it was þoruȝ goddis grᵃrace
And þoruȝ his fayre berynge
Ȝit lisenyth lordis to my tale
Merier þan þe nyȝtyngale
I woll yow rowne
How sir thopas with sidis smalle
Prickid ouer hil and dale
Is come aȝen to towne
¶ His meri men comaundid he
To make hīm boþe game and gle
For nedis muste he fyȝte
With a geaunt wᵗith hedes þre
For ꝑparamour and iolyte
Off oon that schon̄ ful bryȝte
¶ Do come he seide my mynstrall
And gestoures for to tellen tall
Anon̄ in myn armynge
Of Romayns þat ben rialis
Of popis and of cardenalis
And eeke of loue longynge
¶ Þey fetten him first swete wyn̄
And mede eek in a mamasalyn̄
And mede eek in amasalyn
And rial spicerie
Of gingebred þat was ful fyn
And licorice and eek comȳn
With suger þat is trie
¶ He dede next his white lere
Of cloth of lake fyn and cler͗e
A breche and eke a scherte
And next his scherte an naketoıı̄un aketoıı̄un naketoıı̄un

And oủere þat a fyn hauberk

And ouer þat his cote armour
As white as a lelye flour
In wheche he wol debate
His schild was al of gold so red
And þer yn̄ne was a boris hed
A charbocle by his syde
And þer he swore on ale ⁊and bred
How that þe geaıı̄unt schuld be ded

Boþe knyȝt and lady fre

NOmor͗e of this for goddis dignyte

Now suche a ryme þe deuyl I beteche
This may be wel I yin dogerel ꝙquod he

Þat ouȝte to lyke yow as I suppose

It is a moral tale vertuous
Al be \it/ told in sundry wyse

div.ab: (base) Here bigynneth Chaucers tale of Melibeus

(base) A yong man whilom called Melibeus myghty and
riche bigat vp on his wif that called was Prudence a
doghter which that called was Sophie

(base) vp on a day bifel that
he for his desport is went in to the feeldes hym to pleye

(base) his
wif and eek his doghter hath he laft inwith his hous of which
the dores weren faste yshette
(base) thre of his olde foos han it espied and setten laddres to the walles of his hous and by wyndowes ben entred

(base) and betten his wif and wounded his doghter with
fyue mortal woundes in fyue sondry places

(base) this is to seyn
in hir feet in hir handes in hir erys in hir nose and in hir
mouth and leften hire for deed and wenten awey

(base) Whan Melibeus retourned was in to his hous and seigh al this meschief he
lyk a mad man rentynge his clothes gan to wepe and crye

(base) Prudence his wyf as ferforth as she dorste bisoughte hym of
his wepyng for to stynte

(base) but nat for thy he gan to crye and
wepen euere lenger the moore

(base) This noble wif Prudence
remembred hire vp on the sentence of Ouyde in his book that
cleped is the remedie of loue wher as he seith

(base) he is a fool
that destourbeth the moder to wepe in the deth of hir child
til she haue wept hir fille as for a certeyn tyme

(base) and thanne
shal man doon his diligence with amyable wordes hire to reconforte and preye hire of hir wepyng for to stynte

(base) for which
reson this noble wyf Prudence suffred hir housbonde for to
wepe and crye as for a certeyn space

(base) and whan she say hir
tyme she seyde hym in this wise Allas my lord quod she
why make ye your self for to be lyk a fool
(base) for sothe it aperteneth nat to a wys man to maken swich a sorwe

(base) yowre
doghter with the grace of god shal warisshe and escape

(base) And al were it so that she right now
Text on this page supplied initially from the base text. Delete this note when revised against the manuscript image.
were deed ye ne oghte nat as
for hir deth youre self to destroye

(base) Senec seith the wise man
shal nat take to greet disconfort for the deth of his children

(base) but
certes he sholde suffren it in pacience as wel as he abideth the
deth of his owene propre perrsone

(base) This Melibeus answerde anon
and seyde What man quod he sholde of his wepyng stynte
that hath so gret a cause for to wepe

(base) Ihus crist oure lord hym
self wepte for the deth of lazarus his freend

(base) Prudence
answerde Certes wel I woot attempree wepynge is no thyng
defended to hym that sorweful is amonges folk in sorwe but
it is rather graunted hym to wepe

(base) The Apostle Poul vn to
the Romayns writeth Man shal reioysse with hem that maken ioye
and wepen with swich folk as wepen
(base) but thogh attempree wepyng be graunted outrageous wepyng certes is defended

(base) Mesure
of wepyng sholde be considered after the loore that techeth vs
Senec

(base) Whan that thy freend is deed quod he lat nat thyne eyen
to moyste ben of terys ne to muche drye al thogh the teerys
come to thyne eyen lat hem nat falle

(base) And whan thou hast
forgoon thy freend do diligence to geten another freend and
this is moore wysdom than for to wepe for thy freend which
that thou hast lorn for ther Inne is no boote

(base) And therfore if ye
gouerne yow by Sapience put awey sorwe out of youre herte

(base) Remembre yow that Ihus Syrak seith A man that is ioyous and
glad in herte it hym conserueth florisshynge in his age but
soothly sorweful herte maketh his bones drye

(base) he seith eek
thus that sorwe in herte sleeth ful many a man

(base) Salomon
seith that right as Moththes in the Shepes flees anoyeth
to the clothes and the smale wormes to the tree right so anoyeth sorwe to the herte

(base) wher fore vs oghte as wel in the deth
of oure children as in the losse of oure goodes temporels haue
pacience

(base) Remembre yow vp on the pacient Iob whan he
hadde lost his children and his temporel substance and in his
Text on this page supplied initially from the base text. Delete this note when revised against the manuscript image.
body
endured and receyued ful many a greuous tribulacion yet seide
he thus
(base) Oure lord quod he hath yeue it me

(base) Oure lord hath biraft it me right so as oure lord
hath wold right so it is doon yblessed be the name of oure
lord

(base) To thise forseyde thynges answerde Melibeus vn to
his wif Prudence Alle thy wordes quod he been sothe and
ther to profitable but trewely myn herte is troubled with this
sorwe so greuously that I noot what to doon

(base) lat calle quod
Prudence thy trewe freendes alle and thy lynage whiche that
ben wise telleth youre cas and herkneth what they seye in conseylynge
and yow gouerne after hir sentence

(base) Salomon seith werk
alle thy thynges by conseil and thow shalt neuere repente

(base) Thanne by the conseil of his wyf Prudence this Melibeus leet
callen a greet congregacioun of folk

(base) as Sirurgiens Phisiciens
olde folk and yonge and somme of hise olde enemys reconsiled as
by hir semblant to his loue and in to his grace

(base) and ther with al ther
coomen somme of hise neghebores that diden hym reuerence moore
for drede than for loue as it happeth ofte

(base) Ther coomen also
ful manye subtile flaterers and wise Aduocatz lerned in the
lawe
(base) And whan this folk togydre assembled weren this Melibeus in sorweful wise shewed hem his cas

(base) and by the manere
of his speche it semed that in herte he baar a cruel Ire redy to
doon vengeance vp on his foos and sodeynly desired that the
werre sholde bigynne

(base) but nathelees yet axed he hir conseil
vp on this matere

(base) A Sirurgien by licence and assent of swiche
as were wise vp roos and vn to Melibeus seyde as ye may
heere

(base) Sire quod he as to vs Sirurgiens aperteneth that we
do to euery wight the beste that we kan where as we be withholden
and to oure pacientz that we do no damage

(base) wher fore it
happeth many tyme and ofte that whan twey men han euerich
wounded oother o same Sirurgien heeleth hem bothe

(base) wher
fore vn to oure Art it is nat perti
Text on this page supplied initially from the base text. Delete this note when revised against the manuscript image.
nent to norice werre ne parties
to supporte

(base) but certes as to the warisshynge of youre doghter
al be it so that she perilously be wounded we shullen do so ententif bisynesse fro day to nyght that with the grace of god she
shal be hool and sound as soone as is possible

(base) Almoost right
in the same wise the Phisiciens answerden saue that they
seyden a fewe wordes moore

(base) that right as maladyes
ben cured by hir contraries right so shal man warisshe
werre by vengeance

(base) hise neghebores ful of enuye hise
feyned freendes that semeden reconsiled hise flaterers

(base) maden
semblant of wepyng and empeyred and agregged muchel
of this matere in preisynge gretly Melibe of myght of
power of richesse and of freendes despisynge the power
of hise Aduersaries

(base) and seyden outrely that he anon sholde
wreke hym on hise foos and bigynne werre

(base) Vp roos thanne an Aduocat that was wys by leue and by conseil of othere
that weren wise and seyde

(base) Lordynges the nede for the which
we ben assembled in this place is ful heuy thyng and an
heigh matere

(base) by cause of the wrong and of the wikkednesse that
hath be doon and eek by reson of the grete damages that in tyme
comynge been possible to fallen for the same cause

(base) And ek
by reson of the grete richesse and power of the parties bothe

(base) for
the whiche resons it were a ful greet peril to erren in this matere

(base) Wher fore Melibeus this is oure sentence we conseile
yow abouen alle thyng that right anon thow do diligence in
kepynge of thy propre persone in swich a wise that thow ne wante noon espye ne wacche thy body for to saue

(base) And after that
we conseille that in thyn hous thow sette suffisant garnyson so that they may as wel thy body as thyn hous defende

(base) But certes for to moeue werre ne sodeynly for to doon
vengeance we may nat deme in so litel
Text on this page supplied initially from the base text. Delete this note when revised against the manuscript image.
tyme that it were
profitable
(base) wher fore we axen leyser and espace to haue deliberacioun in this cas to deme

(base) for the commune prouerbe seyth
this he that soone demeth soone shal repente

(base) And eek men
seyn that thilke Iuge is wys that soone vnderstondeth a matere and Iuggeth by leyser

(base) for al be it so that al taryyng be
anoyful algates it is nat to repreue in yeuyng of Iuggement ne in vengeance takyng whan it is suffisant and
resonable

(base) and that shewed oure lord Ihus crist by ensample for whan that the womman that was taken in auoutrye
was broght in his presence to knowen what sholde be doon
with hir persone al be it that he wiste wel hym self what
that he wolde answere yet ne wolde he nat answere sodeynly but he wolde haue deliberacioun and in the ground he
wroot twies

(base) and bythise causes we axen deliberacion
and we shul thanne by the grace of god conseille thee thyng
that shal be profitable

(base) Vp stirten thanne the yonge folk
atones and the mooste partie of that compaignye han scorned this olde wise man and bigonnen to make noyse and
seyden that

(base) right so as whil that Iren is hoot men sholde smyte right so sholde men wreken hir wronges
whil that they been fresshe and newe and with loud voys
they criden werre werre

(base) vp roos tho oon of thise olde
wise and with his hand made contenance that men sholde
holden hem stille and yeuen hym audience

(base) Lordynges quod he ther is ful many a man that crieth werre
werre that woot ful litel what werre amounteth

(base) Werre at his bigynnyng hath so greet an entree and so large
that euery wight may entre whan hym liketh and lightly fynde werre

(base) But certes what ende that ther of shal falle it
is noght light to knowe
Text on this page supplied initially from the base text. Delete this note when revised against the manuscript image.

(base) for soothly whan that werre is ones
bigonne ther is ful many a child vnborn of his moder
that shal sterue yong by cause of thilke werre or ellis lyue in
sorwe and dye in wrecchednesse

(base) and ther fore er that any werre
be bigonne men moste haue gret conseil and gret deliberacioun

(base) And whan this olde man wende to enforcen his tale by resons
wel neigh all atones bigonne they to rise for to breken his tale and beden hym ful ofte hise wordes for to abregge

(base) for sothly he that precheth to hem that listen nat heren hise wordes hys
sarmon hem anoyeth

(base) For Ihus Syrak seith That Musyk in
wepynge is a noyous thyng This is to seyn As muche auaileth to speken biforn folk to whiche his speche anoyeth as it
is to synge biforn hym that wepeth

(base) And whan this wise man
say that hym wanted audience al shamefast he sette hym doun
agayn

(base) For Salomon seith ther as thow ne mayst haue non
audience enforce thee nat to speke

(base) I se wel quod this wise
man that the come prouerbe is sooth that good conseil wanteth
whan it is moost nede

(base) yet hadde this Melibeus in his conseil many folk that priuely in his ere conseiled hym certeyn
thyng and conseiled hym the contrarie in general audience

(base) Whan Melibeus hadde herd that the gretteste party of his conseil were acorded that he sholde make werre anon he consented
to hir conseilyng and fully affermed hir sentence

(base) Thanne dame Prudence whan that she say how that hyr
housbonde shoope hym for to wreke hym on his foos and to
bigynne werre she in ful humble wise whan she say hir
tyme seyde hym thise wordes

(base) My lord quod she I you
biseche as hertely as I dar and kan ne haste yow nat to
faste and for alle gerdons as yif me audience

(base) For Piers
Alfonce seith who so that dooth to thee outher good or
harm
Text on this page supplied initially from the base text. Delete this note when revised against the manuscript image.
haste thee nat to quiten it for in this wise thy
freend wol abyde and thyn enemy shal the lenger lyue
in drede

(base) The prouerbe seith he hasteth wel that wysly kan
abide and in wikked haste is no profit

(base) This Melibe answerde vn to his wyf Prudence I purpose nat quod he
to werken by thy conseil for many causes and resons
for certes euery wight wolde holde me thanne a fool

(base) this is to seyn If I for thy conseilyng wolde chaunge
thynges that ben ordeyned and affermed by so manye wise

(base) Secoundly I seye that alle wommen ben wikke and noon good of hem alle
for of a thousand men seith Salomon I foond o good man but
certes of alle wommen good womman foond I neuere

(base) And also certes
if I gouerned me by thy conseil it sholde seme that I hadde yeue
to thee ouer me the maistrie and goddes forbode that it so were

(base) For Ihus Syrak seith that if the wyf haue maistrie she is
contrarious to hir housbonde

(base) And Salomon seith Neuere
in thy lyf to thy wyf ne to thy child ne to thy freend ne yif
no power ouer thy self For bettre it were that thy children
axen of thy persone thynges that hem nedeth than thow see
thy self in the handes of thy children

(base) And also if I wolde
werke by thy conseilyng certes my conseil moste som tyme be
secree til it were tyme that it moste be knowe and this ne
may nat be

(base) Whan Dame Prudence ful debonairly and with
gret pacience hadde herd al that hir housbonde liked for to
seye thanne axed she of hym licence for to speke and
seyde in this wise

(base) My lord quod she as to youre firste
reson certes it may lightly been answered for I seye that it is
no folie to chaunge conseil whan the thyng is chaunged
or ellis whan the thyng semeth oother weys than it was
biforn

(base) And moore ouer I seye that thogh that ye han sworn
and bihight to perfourne youre emprise and nathelees
Text on this page supplied initially from the base text. Delete this note when revised against the manuscript image.
ye weyue
to perfourne thilke same emprise by iuste cause men sholde nat seyn therfore that ye were a lyere ne forsworn

(base) for
the book seith that the wise man maketh no lesyng whan
he turneth his corage to the bettre

(base) And al be it so that youre
emprise be establissed and ordeyned by gret multitude of folk
yet thar ye nat accomplice thilke same ordinance but yow
like

(base) for the trouthe of thynges and the profit ben rather founde
in fewe folk that ben wise and ful of reson than by gret multitude of folk ther euery man crieth and clatereth what that hym
liketh soothly swich multitude is nat honeste

(base) And to the
Seconde resoun where as ye seyn that alle wommen ben wikke
Saue youre grace certes ye despise alle wommen in this wyse
and he that al despiseth al displeseth as seith the book

(base) and
Senec seith that who so wole haue Sapience shal no man
dispreise but he shal gladly teche the science that he kan with
oute presumpcion or pride

(base) and swiche thynges as he noght
ne kan he shal nat ben ashamed to lerne hem and enquere
of lasse folk than hym self

(base) And sire that ther hath be ful many
a good womman may lightly be preued

(base) for certes sire oure lord
Ihus crist wolde neuere han descended to be born of a womman
if alle wommen hadde be wikke

(base) And after that for the grete
bountee that is in wommen oure lord Ihus crist whan he was risen
fro deth to lyf appered rather to a womman than to his apostles

(base) And though that Salomon seith that he ne foond neuere
womman good it folweth nat therfore that alle wommen
ben wikke

(base) for thogh that he ne foond no good womman certes
many another man hath founde many a womman ful good
and trewe

(base) Or ellis parauenture the entente of Salomon was
this that as in souereyn bountee he foond no womman

(base) this is
to seyn that ther is no wight that hath souereyn bountee saue
god allone as he hym self recordeth in his Euan
Text on this page supplied initially from the base text. Delete this note when revised against the manuscript image.
gelie

(base) for
ther nys no creature so good that hym ne wanteth som what
of the perfeccioun of god that is his makere

(base) Youre thridde reson is this ye seyn that if ye gouerne yow by my conseil it
sholde seme that ye hadde yeue me the maistrie and the lordshipe ouer youre persone

(base) Sire sauf youre grace it is nat so
for if so were that no man sholde be conseiled but oonly of
hem that hadde lordshipe and maistrie of his persone men wolde nat ben conseiled so ofte

(base) for soothly thilke man that axeth
conseil of a purpos yet hath he free choys wheither he
wole werke by that conseil or noon

(base) And as to youre ferthe
reson ther ye seyn that the Ianglerye of wommen kan hide
thynges that they woot nat as who seith that a womman
kan nat hide that that she woot

(base) Sire thise wordes been
vnderstonde of wommen that ben Iangleresses and wikked

(base) of
whiche wommen men seyn that thre thynges dryuen a man
out of his hous that is to seyn Smoke droppyng of
reyn and wikked wyues

(base) and of swiche wommen seith Salomon that it were bettre dwellen in desert than with a womman
that is riotous
(base) and sire by youre leue that am nat I

(base) for ye han
ful ofte assayed my grete silence and my grete pacience and
eek how wel that I kan hiden and hele thynges that men oghten
secrely to hyde

(base) And soothly as to youre fifthe reson wher-
as ye seyn that in wikked conseil wommen venquysse men
god woot thilke reson stant heere in no stede
(base) For vnderstond now ye axen conseil to do wikkednesse

(base) and if ye
wol werke wikkednesse and youre wyf restreyneth thilke
wikked purpos and ouercometh yow by reson and by good conseil

(base) certes youre
wyf oghte rather be preysed than yblamed

(base) Thus sholde ye vnderstonde the Philosophre that seith In wikked conseil
Text on this page supplied initially from the base text. Delete this note when revised against the manuscript image.
wommen venquyssen hir housbondes

(base) And ther as ye blamen alle wommen
and hir resons I shal shewe by manye ensamples that many a
womman hath be ful good and yet ben and hir conseils holsom
and profitable
(base) Eke som men han seyd that the conseilyng of wommen is outher to deere or ellis to litel of prys

(base) but al be it
so that ful many a womman is badde and hir conseil vile and noght
worth yet han men founde ful many a good womman and ful
discrete and wys in conseilynge

(base) Lo Iacob by conseil of his
moder Rebekka wan the beneyson of Ysaak his fader and
the lordshipe ouer alle his bretheren

(base) Iudith by hir good conseil
deliuered the Citee of Bethulye in which she dwelled out of the
handes of Olofernus that hadde it biseged and wolde it al destroye

(base) Abigail deliuered Nabal hir housbonde fro Dauid the kyng that
wolde han slayn hym and apaised the Ire of the kyng by hir
wit and by hir good conseilyng

(base) Hester by hir good conseil enhaunced gretly the peple of god in the regne of Assuerus the
kyng

(base) and the same bountee in good conseilyng of many a good
womman may men telle

(base) And moore ouer whan that oure lord
hadde creat Adam oure forme fader he seyde in this wise

(base) It is nat good to be a man allone make we to hym an help
semblable to hym self

(base) Heere may ye se that if that wommen
were nat goode and hir conseil good and profitable

(base) oure lord god

And crieþ fals coward wreke þi wyff
By corpus bonis I wol haue þy knyff
And þou schalt haue my distaff and go spyn
Fro day to nyȝt riȝt þus sche woll bygynne
Allas sche seiþ þat euer sche was schape
To wedde a mylk soppe or a coward ape
That well ben oủerlad of eủery wyȝt
Þou darst not stonde by þi wyues riȝt
Þis is my lif but if y woƚƚ fiȝt
And out at þe dore anon̄ I mote me diȝt
Or eƚƚ be lost but if that I
Be lik a wilde lyon̄ fool hardy
I wote wel sche wol do me sle sum day
Sum neyȝebore and þan go my way
For I am perlous with a a knyff in honde
Al be it þat I dar not hir withstonde
For sche is bigge in armys by my feith
That schal he fynde þat hir mysdoþ or seith
But late vs passe awey fro this matere
My lord þe monk ꝙquod he be meri of chere
For ȝe schullen telle a tale treuly
Lo rouchester stant her faste by
Ride forþ myn owne lord breke not oure game
But by my trouthe I know not yoᵘure name
Whether schall I calle yow my lord dan̄ Ion
Or daun Thomas or eƚƚ daun albone
Of what hous be ȝe bi your fadir kyn
I vow to god thou hast a ful fayr skyn
It is agentil pasture þer þou goost
Þou art not lik apennaıı̄unt or a gost
Vpon̄ my feith þou art sum officer
Sum worthy sexteyn or sum selerer
For by my fadir soul as to my dome
Þou art a maister whanne þou art at home
No power cloisterere ne no novice
But a gouernoᵘur wily and wis
And þerwith aƚƚ of brannes and of bones
A wel faire persone for þe nones
I pᵃray to god ȝeue him confusioun̄
Þat first þe brouȝte to religioun̄
Þou woldist haue ben a tredefoul ariȝt
Hast þᵘou as grete leue as þᵘou hast myȝt
To parforme þy lust in engendrure
Þou haddist bigeten ful many a creature
Alas why werist þou so wide a cope
God yeue me sorwe but and I were pope
Not only þou but eủery myȝti man
Þou he were schore ful hiȝe vp on his pan
Shuld haue a wif for aƚƚ þis world is lost ⁊and lorn̄
Religion̄ hath taken taken taken vp al þe corn̄
Off tredynge and we boreƚƚ men ben schrympꝰus
Off febil trees comen wrecchid ympys
Þis makith þat oure eiris ben so slendre
And feble þat þey ben ⁊and mowen not wel engendre
Þis makith þat oure wyues wollen asaye
Religious folk for þei mowen better paye
Of venus payment þanne mowēn we
God wote not lusshbornes paien ȝe
But be not wroth my lord þouȝ þᵗat I pleye
Ful ofte in game a soth I haue herd seye
Þis worthy monk took aƚƚ in his pacience
And seide I wol do al my diligence
As fer as sownyþ in to oneste
To telle yow atale of ij or iij
And if þou list to herkene hiderward
I wol yow seyen̄ þe liif of seint Edward
Or eƚƚ first tragedies wol I telle
Of whiche I haue a C in my celle
Tragedie is to seyn a certeyn storie
As olde bokes maken memorie
Of hym þat stode in gret ꝓprosꝑperite
And is falle out of hiȝ degre
In to miserie and endith wrechidly
And þey ben v̉ersified comenly
Off six fete whiche men clepen examitrıı̄un
In prose eek ben enditith many on
And eke in metre many a soundry wyse
Lo þis declaringe ouȝte yow suffyse
Now herkenyþ if ȝe like for to here
But first I beseke yow in this maner
Þouȝ I be ordre telle not þis thingꝭes
Be it off pope Emꝑperouris or kyngis
Aftir hir agis as men writen finde
But telle hem sum bifore ⁊and sıı̄un behynde
As it now comith to my rememburaunce
Haue me excusid of myn Ignoraunce
Here endiþ þe prolog · and bigynnyþ þe monkis
tale þat is titlid calibȝ virorum illistrium
I wol be wayle in maner of tᵃragidie
Þe harm of hem þat stonde in hiȝe degre
And fallen so þat þer was no remedie
To bringe hem out of her aduersite
For certeyn̄ whanne þat fortune list to fle
Þer may no man þe cours of hir wiþhholde
Late noman triste on blynd prosꝑperite
Bewar of þese ensaumplis trewe and olde
¶ At lucifer þouȝ he an aungel were Lucifer
And not a man at him I woƚƚ bigȳnne
For þouȝ fortune may non̄ aungel dere
From hiȝ degre ȝit fel he for his synne
Doun̄ in to helle wher as ȝit he is Inne
O lucifer briȝtist of aungel alle
Now art þou satanas þou maist not twynne
Out of miserie in whiche þat þou art falle
¶ Lo adam in þe feld of damissene Adam
With goddis owne fynger wrouȝt was he
And not bigeten of mānnes sperme vnclene
And welt aƚƚ paradise saue o tre
Hadde neuer wordly man so hiȝ degree
As Adam til he for mysgouernaunce
Was dreuen out of his hiȝ prosperite
To labour and to helle ⁊and to myschaunce
¶ Lo saumpson̄ whiche þat was anunciat Sampson̄
Bi þe aungel long er his natiuite
And was to god almyȝti consecrat
And stood in nobles while he myȝt se
Was neuer siche anothir as was he
Vndir þe blee in Caunterbury way
Þei gan oure oost for to iape and pley
And seide siris what dun is in þe mire
Þer is noman for prayer ne for here
Þat is of awake oure felowis ar behynde
A þeef myȝt ful liȝtly robbe and bynde
Se how he nappyth se for cokis bones
Þat he woll falle fro his hors at onys
¶ I that Cook of london̄ wᵗith myschaunce
Do him come forth he knowᵗeth his penuaunce
For he schall telle a tale by my fay
Aƚƚ þouȝ it be not worþy abotel hay
A wake þou Cook sut vp god ȝeue þe sorwe
What eilith þe to slepe by þe morwe
Hast þou has fleen all nyȝt or art þou dronke
Or hast þou with som qwene al nyȝt swonke
So þat þou maist not holden vp þin heed
Þis cook þat was pale and noþing red
Seide to oure ost so god my soule blisse
As þer is falle on me siche heuynesse
Not I not why but me wer͗e leuer slepe
Þanne þe beeste galon̄ wyn þat is in chepe
Wel quod þe maunciple if þat I may don̄ ese
To þe sir cook and to no wiȝt displese
Which þat here ridith in þis companye
And oure oost wolde of his curtesie
I wolde as now excuse þee of þy tale
For in good feith þi visage is ful pale
Þin iȝen dasewen eke as me þenkith
And well I wote þi breeþ ful foul stinkitħ
Þat schewith well þou art not wel disposid
Of me Certeyn þou shalt not ben glosid
Se how he ganyþ se þis drunken wiȝt
As þouȝ he wolde swolwe vs anoon Riȝt
Holde cloos þi mouth for þi fadir kynite
Þe deuell of helle sette his fote þer Inne
Þi cursid breth inffect woll vs alle
Fy stynkynge swyn̄ foul mote þᵉ falle

div.l: (base) A taketh hede sires of this lusty man
(base) Now swete sire wol ye Iusten atte Fan
(base) Ther to me thynketh ye ben wel yshape
(base) I trowe that ye dronken han wyn ape
(base) And that is whan men pleyen with a straw
(base) And with his speche the Cook wax wroth and wraw
(base) And on the Manciple bigan he nodde faste
(base) For lakke of speche and doun the hors hym caste
(base) Wher as he lay til that men vp hym took
(base) This was a fair chyuachee of a Cook
(base) Allas he nadde yholde hym by his ladel
(base) And er that he agayn were in his Sadel
(base) Ther was gret showuyng bothe to and fro
(base) To lifte hym vp and muchel care and wo
(base) So vnweldy was this sory palled goost
(base) And to the Manciple thanne spak oure hoost
(base) By cause drynke hath domynacioun
(base) Vpon this man by my sauacioun
(base) I trowe he lewedly telle wolde his tale
(base) For were it wyn or old or moisty Ale
(base) That he hath dronke he speketh in his nose
(base) And fneseth faste and eek he hath the pose
(base) He hath also to do moore than ynow
(base) To kepen hym and his capil out of the Slow
(base) And if he falle from his capil eft soone
(base) Than shal we alle haue ynow to doone
(base) In liftynge vp his heuy dronken cors
(base) Telle on thy tale of hym make I no fors
(base) But yet Manciple in feith thow art to nyce
(base) Thus openly repreue hym of his vice
(base) Another day he wole par auenture
(base) Reclayme thee and brynge thee to lure
(base) I mene he speke wole of smale thynges
(base) As for to pynchen at thy rekenynges
(base) That were nat honeste if it cam to preef
(base) No quod the Manciple that were a gret mescheef
(base) So myghte he lightly brynge me in the snare
(base) Yet hadde I leuere payen for the Mare
Whiche þat he rit on þan he schulde wᵗith me stryue
I wol not wraith him as so mot I þryue
Þat I spak I seide it in my bourde
And wete ȝe what I haue here in my gourde
A drauȝt of wyn it is of a ripe grape
And riȝt anon̄ ȝe schullen se a good iape
Þis Cook schall drynke þer of if I may
Vp peyne of deeþ he wol not seie me nay
And certeynly to telle as it was
Off þis vessel þis Cook drank faste allas
What nediþ it it he drank I now byforen
And whanne he hadde poupid in horn̄
To þe maunciple he tok þe gourde ageyn
And of þat drauȝt þe cook was woundir fayn̄
And þankid him in siche wyse as he coude
Þan gan oure oost to laughe woundir loude
And seide I see weeƚƚ it is necessarie
Where þat we go good drynke with vs to carie
For þat woƚƚ turne rancour and dessese
To acord and loue and many a rancour plese
O þou bacus blissid be þi name
That so canst turne ernest in to game
Worschipp and þank to be þi deite
Off þat mater ȝe gete no more for me
Telle on þy tale maunciple I þe pᵃraye
Wel sir quod he now herkene what I seie
Whānne phebus was dwellynge in erthe adoun̄
As olde bokes maken mencioun̄
He was þe moste lusti bachelere
In all this world and eke þe beste archere
He slowz phiton̄ þe serpent as he lay
Slepynge ageyn þe sunne vp on a day
And many a noþ̉er noble worþi dede
He with his bowe wrouȝte as men mon̄ rede
Pleyen he coude on euery mynstralsie
And syngen þat it was a melodie
To heren of his clere voice þe soun̄
Certis þe kyng of thebes amphioun̄
Þat with his syngynge wallyd þe cite
Coude neuer syngen half so wel as he
Þerto he was þe semylieste man
Þat is or was sith þe world bygan
What nedith his feturis to discryue
For in þis world was non̄ so fair͗ on lyue
He was þerwith fulfillyd of gentilnesse
Of honour and of ꝑparfiȝt worthynesse
Þis phebus þat was flour of bachelerie
As wel in fredom as in chiualrie
For his disport in signe eke of victorie
Off phitoun̄ so as telliþ vs þe storie
Was wont in his hond to bere abowe
Now hadde þat phebus in his hous a crowe
Whiche in a cage he fostrid many a day
And tauȝte it speke as men teche a Iay
White was þis crowe as is a snow whit swan
And countirfete þe speche of eủery man
He coude whanne he schulde telle a tale
Þer wiþ in all þis world no nyȝtīngale
Ne coude bi an C Mᵈ dele
Syngen so woundir merly and weel
Now hadde þis Phebus in his hous awyf
Whiche þat he louede more þan his liif
And nyȝt and day dide eủere his diligence
Hir for to plese and don̄ hir reuerence
Saue only if þe soþe þat I schal seyn̄
Ielous he was and wold haue kept hir fayn̄
For him were loth bi iaped for to be
And so is eủery wiȝt in siche degre
But al for nouȝt for it a vayliþ nouȝt
A good wōmman wōmman þat is clene of werke and þouȝt
Schuld not be kept in non̄ awayte certeyn̄
And treuly þe labour is in veyn̄
To kepe a schrewe for it woll not be
This holde I for a verry nycite
To spille labour for to kepe wyves
Þus writen olde clerkis in her lyues
Now to purpoos as I first began
This worthy phebus doþ al þat he can
To plesen hir wenynge þat sich plesaunce
And for his manhood and his gouernaunce
That no man schulde haue putte hȳm fro hir gᵃrace
But god it wote þer may no man embrace
As to destreyne a þing whiche þat nature
Hath naturly sett in a creature
Take ony brid ⁊and putt it in in a cage
And aƚƚ þin entent ⁊and þi corage
To fostre it tendirly wᵗith mete ⁊and drynke
In alle deyntes þat þou canst beþenke
And kepe it as clenly as þou may
And þouȝ his cage of gold be neủere so gay
Ȝit had þis brid bi xxⁿ mˡ foold
Leuer in a forest þat is rougħ and cold
Gon eten wormes and siche wrecchidnesse
For eủere þis brid wol don̄ his besinesse
To ascape out of his cage if þat he may
His liberte þis brid desirith ay
Late take a cat and fostre hir wel wᵗith mylk
And tendir flessch and make his couche of silk
And lat him seen amous gon by þe walle
Anon̄ he weyueth mylk and flesch and alle
And eủery deynte þat is in þat hous
Such appetite haþ he to ete a mous
Lo heer hath lust his dominacioūn
And appetite flemyþ discrescioun
A sche wolf hath also a vilens kynde
Þe lewdist wolf þat sche may fynde
Or leest of reputacioun̄ þat wol sche take
In tyme whan̄e þat hir list to han a make
Alle þese ensaunplis speke I bi þese men
Þat ben vntrewe but no þing by wȳmmen
For men han eủere a likerous appetit
On lower thing to ꝑperforme hir dilite
Þan on her wyues ben þey neuer so fair͗e
Ne neuer so trewe ne debonair͗e
Flessh is so newfangel with myschaunce
Þat we ne can in noþing haue no plesaunce
Þat sownyþ in to vertu ony while
Þis phebus whiche þat þouȝte vpon no gile
Disseyued was for all his Iolyte
For vndir him anoþer had sche
A man of litil reputacion̄
Not worth to phebus in comꝑparison̄
Þe more harme is it happiþ often so
Off whiche þer comyth micħ harm and wo
And so befel whan phebus was absent
His wyf anon̄ hath aftir hir lemman sent
Hir lemman certis þis is aknauyssch speche
Forȝeue it me and þat I ȝow beseche
Þe wise plato seith as ȝe mowen rede
Þe word mote nede acorde wᵗith þe dede
If men schullen tellen proꝑperly a þing
Þe word mot Coseyn be to þe werkyng
I am a bonstus man riȝt þus seie I
Þer is non̄ oþer difference treuly
Bitwix awyf þat is of hiȝ degre
If of hir body dishonest sche be
And a pore wenche oþ̉er þan þis
If it so be þat þei werken boþᵉ amys
But þat þe gentil in estate aboue
She schal becleped his lady as in loue
And for þat oþer is a pore wōmman
Sche schal be cleped his wenche or his lemman
And god it wote myn owne der͗e broþer
Men leyn̄ þat oon as lowe as lith þᵗat oþer
Riȝt so bitwixe a titlees tiraunt
And an outlawe or a þeef erraunt
Þe same I seye þer is no difference
To alisaundir told was þis sentence
That for þe tyraunt is of gretter myght
Bi force of meyne for to sleen doun̄ riȝt
And brennen hous and hom and maken al pleyn̄
Lo þerfore is he cleped a capiteigne
And for þe outlawe hath but smale meyne
And may not don̄ so gret an harm as he
Ne brynge acontre to so gret myschef
Men clepen him an owtlawe or a þeef
But for I am a man not textuele
I wol not telle of tixtis neuer adele
I wol go to my talis as I be gan
Whan̄e phebus wiif had sent for hir lēmman
Anon̄ þey wrouȝten al hir lust volage
Þe white crowe þat heng ay in þe cage
Be hilde hir werk and seide neủere aword
And whan that hom was come phebus þe lord
Þis crowe sang kokkow kokkow kokkowe
What brid what ꝙquod phebus what song syngest þᵘou
Ne were þou went so merly to synge
Þat to myn herte it were areioysynge
To here þi voice allas what song is þis
By god quod he I synge not amys
Phebus quod he for all þi worthinesse
For al þy beute and þi gentilnesse
For al þy song and al þy minstralsie
For al þy waytynge blerid is þin iȝe
With oon of litil reputacioıı̄un
Not worth to þe in comꝑparsoun
Þe mountaunce of a a gnatte so mote I þryue
For on þi bed þi wif I saw him swyve
What wol ȝe more þe crowe anon̄ him told
By sad tokens and bi wordis bolde
How þat his wyf had don̄ hir leccherie
Him to grett schame and to grett vilonye
And told him oft he saw it with his yȝen
Þis phebus gan aweyward for to wrien
And þouȝte his sorweful herte brast atwo
His bowe he bent and sett þer Inne a flo
And in his ire his wiif þan̄e hath he slayn̄
This is þe effect þer is nomore to seyn
For sorwe of whiche he brak his mynstralsie
Boþe harpe and lute and git̉erne ⁊and sauterie
And eke he brak his arwys and his bowe
And aftir þat þus spak he to þe crowe
Traitour quod he with tunge of scorpioıı̄un
Þou hast me brouȝt to confusioūn
Allas þat I was wrowȝt whi nere I ded
O dere wyff gemme of lustihed
Þat were to me so sad and eke so trewe
Now liest þou ded wᵗith face pale of hewe
Ful gilteles þat durste I swere I wys
O racle hond to don so foul amys
O trouble witt oure recheles
Þat vnauysid smitist gilteles
O wan trust ful of fals suspeccioun̄
Where was þy witt and þi discreccioun̄
O euery man bewar of rakelnesse
Ne trow no þing wᵗith outen strong wittnesse
Smyte not to sone er þat ȝe witen why
But be auysid wel and soberly
Er ȝe don̄ ony exᵉcucioun̄
Vpon̄ ȝour͗e ire for youre suspeccioun̄
Allas a mˡ folk haþ rakel ire
Fully fordon̄ or brouȝt in þe mire
Allas for sorwe wol I my silf sle
And to þe crowe of fals þeef seide he
I wol þe quyte anon̄ þy fals tale
Þow song whilome lik an nyȝtingale
Now schalt þou fals þeef þy song forgon
And eke þy white feþ̉ers eủerychon̄
Ne neủere in al þi lyf schalt þou speke
Thus schullen men on a tᵃraitouʳ hem wreke
Þou and þin ofspringe eủere shullen be blake
Ne neuer swete noyse schullen ȝe make
But eủere crien ageyn tempest and reyn̄
In tokenynge þat þorouȝ þee my wyf is slayn̄
And to þe Crowe he sterte and þat anon̄
And pullyd hise white feþ̉eris of eủerychoun̄
And made him blak and raft him al his song
And eke his speche and out at þe dore him slong
Vn to þe deuel whiche I him bitake
And for þis caas ben alle þese crowis blake
Lordyngꝭes by þis ensaumple I ȝow pᵃraye
Bewar and take kepe how þat ȝe sey
Ne telle neủere noman in all ȝoure liif
How þat anothyr man hath diȝt his wiif
He wol ȝow haten mortaly certeyn
Daun Salamon as wise clerkis seyn
Techith aman to kepen his tunge wel
But as I seide I am no textuel
But neþeles þus tauȝt me my dame
My sone þenke on þe crow a goddis name
My sone kepe weƚƚ þy tunge and kepe þi frend
A wikkyd tunge is wors þan a feend
My sone from a feend men men mowen hem blysse
My sone god of his endeles goodnesse
Wallid a tunge with teeþ end lippys eke
For man schulde avise him what he speke
My sone ful ofte for to myche speche
Hath many aman ben spilt as clerkys teche
But for litil speche a visely
Is no man shent to speke gen̉eraly
My sone þy tunge schuldist þou restreyne
At aƚƚ tymes but whan þou dost þy peyne
To speke of god in honour and in prayere
Þe firste vertu sone if þou wolt lere
Is to restreyne and kepe wel þi tunge
Þus lern childeren whanne þat þe ben yonge
My sone of moche speche yuel auysed
Þer lasse spekyng hadde ynowȝ suffised
Comyþ myche harm thus was me told and taught
In myche speche synne ne wantiþ naugħt
Wost þou wher of aracle tunge ʆserued
Ryȝt as a swerd forkittiþ and for keruyd
An arme atwo my der͗e sone Ryȝt so
A tunge kittiþ frenschyp aƚƚ atwo
A iangeler is to god abhomynabill
Reede salamon so wis and honurable
Rede dauid in his psalmis rede senek
My sone speke nouȝt but wᵗith þin heed þᵘou beek
Dissimule as þou were deef if þat þᵘou here
A iangler speke of ꝑperlous matere
Þe flemmyng seitħ ⁊and lerne it if þee list
Þat litil ianglynge causith miche rest
My sone if þou no wicckid word hast seid
Þe thar not drede for to ben bewrid
But he þat hath mysseid y dar wel seyn̄
He may by nowey clepe his word ageyn̄
Þing þat is seid is seid and forth it gooþ
Þouȝ him repente or be hȳm leef or looþ
He is his þral to whom þat he hath sayd

div.l: BE þat the maunciple had his tale endid
The sonne froþe south lyne was descendid
So lowȝ that he was not to my siȝt
Degrees ix ⁊and xxᵗⁱ as of hiȝt
X of þe Clok it was þo as I gesse
For xj fote and litil more or lesse
My schadwe was at þilke tyme as þere
Off siche fete as my lengtħ partid were
In vj fete equalle off proporcioun̄
Ther witħ þe mones exaltacioıı̄un
Imene libra alwey gan ascende
As we weren entrynge at a þroppis eende
For whiche oure ost as he was wont to gye
As in þis caas oure ioly companye
Seide in this wise lordyngꝭes eủerychoıı̄un
Now lakkith vs no tales mo þan oon
Fulfillid is my sentence and my decre
I trow that we haue herd of eủery degre
Almost fulfillid is alle myn ordinaunce
I pray to god so ȝeue him riȝt good chaunce
Þat tellith to vs this tale lustely
Sir preest quod he art þᵘ a vicori
Or art þou a ꝑpersoun seysoþ bi thy fey
Be what þou be ne breke þou not our pley
For eủery man saue þou hath told his tale
Vnbokle ⁊and schewe us what is in þy male
For truly me þenkith bi þi chere
Þou schuldist knyt vp wel a greet matere
Telle vs afable anon for Cokkis bones
Þis ꝑpersoun answerde all at ones
Þou getist fable non told for me
For poul that writith vn to tymothe
Repreueþ hem þat weyuen soþfastnesse
And tellen fables / ⁊and suche wrechidnesse
Whi schulde I sowen draff out of my fist
Whane y may sowen whete if þat me list
For whiche I seye if ȝow list to here
Moralite ⁊and vertuous matere
And þane þat ȝe wollen yeue me audience
I wol fayn at cristis reuerence
Do ȝow plesaunce leueful as y can
But triste ȝe wel I am a soþern man
I can not geste rom ram ruf bi litt̉ere
Ne god wote ryme holde I but littil better
And þerfore if yow lyste y woll not glose
I wol ȝou telle amery tale in prose
To knytte vp al this feste and make an ende
And ihu for his gᵃce so witte me sende
To schewe ȝow þe wey in þis viage
Of þilke ꝑperfiȝt glorious pilgrymage
Þat hiȝte ierlm celestial
And if ȝe fuchesauf anon I schall
Bigynne vp my tale for whiche y pᵃy
Telle ȝoure avise I can no bettir sey
But neþeles þis meditacioun
I putt it ay vndir correccioun
Of clerkis / for y am not textuel
I take but þe sentence triste ȝe wel
Þerfore I make a protestacioun
Þat I wol stonde to correccioun .
Vp on this word we han assentid sone
For as it semed it was for to done
To enden in sum vertuous sentence
And for to ȝeue space and audience
And bede oure ost he schulde do hy seye
Þat alle we to tellen his tale hīm preye
Oure ost hadde þe wordis for vs alle
Sir preest quod he now fair yow befalle
Sey what ȝow list and wewe wol gladly here
And with þat word he seide in þis maner
Telle ȝe quod he ȝoure meditacioun
But haste ȝe ȝow þe sıı̄unne wol go doun
Beþ fructuous ⁊and þat in litil space
